'''Digital Cinema Initiatives, LLC''' ('''DCI''') is a joint venture of major motion picture studios, formed to establish a standard [[systems architecture|architecture]] for [[digital cinema]] systems.
The organization was formed in March 2002 by [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]],{{Efn | [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] withdrew as a member of DCI in May 2005, prior to the release of the DCI Specification.}} [[Paramount Pictures]], [[Sony Pictures Entertainment]], [[20th Century Fox]], [[Universal Studios]], [[The Walt Disney Company]] and [[Warner Bros.]]
The primary purpose of DCI is to establish and document specifications for an [[open architecture]] for digital cinema that ensures a uniform and high level of technical performance, reliability and quality.<ref>{{Citation | title = DCI | type = home page | url = http://www.dcimovies.com/}}</ref> By establishing a common set of content requirements, [[film distributor|distributors]], [[production company|studios]], [[movie theater|exhibitors]], d-cinema manufacturers and vendors can be assured of interoperability and compatibility. Because of the relationship of DCI to many of [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]]'s key studios, conformance to DCI's specifications is considered a requirement by [[software developers]] or equipment manufacturers targeting the digital cinema market.
==Specification== On July 20, 2005, DCI released Version 1.0 of its "Digital Cinema System Specification", commonly referred to as the "DCI Specification". The document describes overall system requirements and specifications for digital cinema. Between March 28, 2006, and March 21, 2007, DCI issued 148 errata to Version 1.0.
DCI released Version 1.1 of the DCI Specification on April 12, 2007, incorporating the previous 148 errata into the DCI Specification. On April 15, 2007, at the annual NAB Digital Cinema Summit, DCI announced the new version, as well as some future plans. They released a "Stereoscopic Digital Cinema Addendum"<ref>{{Citation | title = Stereoscopic DC | type = addendum | publisher = DCI | format = [[Portable document format|PDF]] | url = http://www.dcimovies.com/DCI_Stereoscopic_DC_Addendum.pdf}}.</ref> to begin to establish 3-D technical specifications in response to the popularity of [[3-D film|3-D stereoscopic films]]. It was also announced "which studios would take over the leadership roles in DCI after the current leadership term expires at the end of September."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2007/digital/markets-festivals/dci-announces-digital-3-d-specs-1117963138/|title=DCI announces digital, 3-D specs|last=Cohen|first=David S|date=2007-04-15|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2017-06-10|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}</ref>
Subsequently, between August 27, 2007, and February 1, 2008, DCI issued 100 errata to Version 1.1. So, DCI released Version 1.2 of the DCI Specification on March 7, 2008, again incorporating the previous 100 errata into the specification document. An additional 96 errata were issued by August 30, 2012, so a revised Version 1.2 incorporating those additional errata was approved on October 10, 2012. DCI approved DCI Specification Version 1.3 on June 27, 2018, integrating the 45 errata issued to the previous version into a new document. <ref>{{Citation | title = DCSS Version 1.3 | date = 2018-06-27 | publisher = DCI | url = http://dcimovies.com/specification/DCI_DCSS_Ver1-3_2018-0627.pdf | format = PDF}}.</ref> The previous versions are also archived on the DCI web site.
Based on many [[Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers|SMPTE]] and [[International Standards Organization|ISO]] standards, such as [[JPEG 2000]]-compressed image and "broadcast wave" [[Pulse-code modulation|PCM]]/[[WAV]] sound, it explains the route to create an entire [[Digital Cinema Package]] (DCP) from a raw collection of files known as the Digital Cinema Distribution Master (DCDM), as well as the specifics of its content protection, [[encryption]], and [[forensic identification|forensic marking]].
The specification also establishes standards for the decoder requirements and the presentation environment itself, such as ambient light levels, [[pixel]] [[aspect ratio (image)|aspect]] and shape, image [[luminance]], [[white point]] [[chromaticity]], and those [[tolerance (engineering)|tolerances]] to be kept.
Even though it specifies what kind of information is required, the DCI Specification does not include specific information about how data within a distribution package is to be formatted. Formatting of this information is defined by the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers (SMPTE) digital cinema standards and related documents.{{Efn | As of 1 January 2018, the following fifty-six SMPTE engineering guidelines, recommended practices, registered disclosure documents and standards had been adopted and published: • EG 432-1 Digital Source Processing - ==Image and audio capability overview== ===2D image=== * 2048×1080 ([[2K resolution|2K]]) at 24 frame/s or 48 frame/s, or 4096×2160 ([[4K resolution|4K]]) at 24 frame/s ** In 2K, for Scope (2.39:1) presentation 2048×858 pixels of the imager is used ** In 2K, for Flat (1.85:1) presentation 1998×1080 pixels of the imager is used ** In 4K, for Scope (2.39:1) presentation 4096×1716 pixels of the imager is used ** In 4K, for Flat (1.85:1) presentation 3996×2160 pixels of the imager is used * 12 [[color depth|bits per color component]] (36 bits per pixel) via dual [[Serial digital interface|HD-SDI]] (encrypted) ** 10 bits only permitted for 2K at 48 frame/s * [[CIE 1931 color space|CIE XYZ color space]] * [[TIFF]] 6.0 container format (one file per frame) * [[JPEG 2000]] [[image compression|compression]] ** From 0 to 5 or from 1 to 6 [[Discrete wavelet transform|wavelet]] decomposition levels for 2K or 4K resolutions, respectively ** Compression rate of 4.71 bits/pixel (2K @ 24 frame/s), 2.35 bits/pixel (2K @ 48 frame/s), 1.17 bits/pixel (4K @ 24 frame/s) * 250 [[Megabits per second|Mbit/s]] maximum image [[bit rate]]
===[[Stereoscopy|Stereoscopic 3D]] image=== * 2048×1080 (2K) at 48 frame/s - 24 frame/s per eye (4096×2160 4K not supported) ** In 2K, for Scope (2.39:1) presentation 2048×858 pixels of the imager is used ** In 2K, for Flat (1.85:1) presentation 1998×1080 pixels of the imager is used ** Optionally, in the HD-SDI link only: 10 bit color, [[Chroma subsampling|YCbCr 4:2:2]], each eye in separate stream
===Audio=== * 24 bits per sample, 48 kHz or 96 kHz * Up to 16 channels * [[WAV]] container, uncompressed [[Pulse-code modulation|PCM]]
DCI has additionally published a document outlining recommended practice for [[High Frame Rate]] digital cinema.<ref>{{Citation | publisher = DCI | url = http://www.dcimovies.com/Recommended_Practice/ | title = High Frame Rates Digital Cinema Recommended Practice}}.</ref> This document discloses the following proposed frame rates: 60, 96, and 120 frames per second for 2D at 2K resolution; 48 and 60 for stereoscopic 3D at 2K resolution; 48 and 60 for 2D at 4K resolution. The maximum compressed bit rate for support of all proposed frame rates should be 500 Mbit/s.
==Related information== The idea for DCI was originally mooted in late 1999 by [[Tom McGrath (media executive)|Tom McGrath]], then COO of [[Paramount Pictures]], who applied to the U.S. Department of Justice for anti-trust waivers to allow the joint cooperation of all seven major motion picture studios.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}}
[[Universal Pictures]] made one of the first feature-length DCPs created to DCI specifications, using their film ''[[Serenity (2005 film)|Serenity]]''.<ref>{{Citation | title = DCinemaToday | url = http://www.dcinematoday.com/dc/pr.aspx?newsID=348}}</ref> Although it was not distributed theatrically, it had one public screening on November 7, 2005, at the USC Entertainment Technology Center's Digital Cinema Laboratory in the Pacific Theatre, Hollywood. ''[[Inside Man]]'' was Universal's first DCP commercial release, and, in addition to 35mm film distribution, was delivered via hard drive to 20 theatres in the [[United States]] along with two [[trailer (film)|trailers]].
The Academy Film Archive houses the Digital Cinema Initiatives, LLC Collection, which includes film and digital elements from DCI’s Standard Evaluation Material (StEM), a 12-minute production shot on 35mm and 65mm film, created for vendors and standards organizations to test and evaluate image compression and digital projection technologies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Digital Cinema Initiatives, LLC Collection|url=http://www.oscars.org/film-archive/collections/digital-cinema-initiatives-llc|website=Academy Film Archive}}</ref>

{{Situationists |expanded=Concepts}}
[[File:Its a bore.jpg|thumb|A cigarette advertisement on a billboard turned into a ''détournement'' by defacing the cowboy image and modifying the text, probably including "Marlboro," to read "It's a bore."]] A '''détournement''' ({{IPA-fr|detuʁnəmɑ̃|lang}}), meaning "rerouting, hijacking" in [[French language|French]], is a technique developed in the 1950s by the [[Letterist International]],<ref name="nues8">{{cite web |url=http://sami.is.free.fr/Oeuvres/debord_wolman_mode_emploi_detournement.html |title=Mode d'emploi du détournement |last1=Debord |first1=Guy-Ernest |last2=Wolman |first2=Gil J. |date=May 1956 |language=French |publisher=biblioteque-virtuelle |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}</ref> and later adapted by the [[Situationist International]] (SI),<ref name="ReportManifesto57">''[[Report on the Construction of Situations]]'' (1957)</ref><ref name="SI58">{{cite journal |url=http://www.cddc.vt.edu/sionline///si/is1.html |journal=Situationist International |number=1 |title=Definitions |date=June 1958 |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}</ref> that was defined in the SI's inaugural 1958 journal as "[t]he integration of present or past artistic productions into a superior construction of a milieu. In this sense there can be no situationist painting or music, but only a situationist use of those means. In a more elementary sense, ''détournement'' within the old cultural spheres is a method of propaganda, a method which reveals the wearing out and loss of importance of those spheres."<ref name="SI58" /><ref name="si58french">{{cite journal |url=http://ubumexico.centro.org.mx/text/si/Internationale_situationniste_1.pdf |journal=internationale situationiste |title=Définitions |language=French |quote=Intégration de productions actuelles ou passées des arts dans une construction supérieure du milieu. Dans ce sens il ne peut y avoir de peinture ou de musique situationniste, mais un usage situationniste de ces moyens. Dans un sens plus primitif, le détournement à l'intérieur des sphères culturelles anciennes est une méthode de propagande, qui témoigne de l'usure et de la perte d'importance de ces sphères. |page=13 |number=1 |date=June 1958 |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}</ref>
It has been defined elsewhere as "turning expressions of the capitalist system and its [[media culture]] against itself"<ref name="Holt2010p252">Douglas B. Holt: Cultural Strategy Using Innovative Ideologies to Build Breakthrough Brands, Oxford University Press 2010, p.252</ref>—as when slogans and logos are turned against their advertisers or the political status quo.<ref>Martin Kaste [https://www.npr.org/templates/transcript/transcript.php?storyId=141526467 ''Exploring Occupy Wall Street's 'Adbuster' Origins''], ''NPR'', October 20, 2011</ref>
Détournement was prominently used to set up subversive political pranks, an influential tactic called [[situationist prank]] that was reprised by the [[punk movement]] in the late 1970s<ref name="Marrone05">Marrone, Gianfranco (2005) [https://books.google.com/books?id=0jluoyGktKsC&pg=PT43 ''Sensi alterati: droghe, musica, immagini''], p.45, quote: "...gioco al complotto, alla manipolazione dei media, alla beffa, alla "grande truffa," o al ''detournement'' – inventato dai situazionisti e ripreso dai punk – che appunto del situazionismo sono talvolta concreti continuatori. Pensiamo in questo senso al fin troppo noto caso, esagerato dai media, ma paradigmatico, del manager dei Sex Pistols, [[Malcolm McLaren]], a partire dal quale, nell'estate del 1977, si scatenò, con grande scandalo, il lancio del gruppo dei Pistols in pieno Giubileo della regina, e l'interesse della stampa per la nascente scena punk. Tuttavia, anche in questo caso non si tratta, come invece è stato spesso sostenuto, di freddo "gioco a tavolino", di cinismo, di furbo lancio di un prodotto da parte di chi aveva studiato i media e lavorava sulla guerriglia semiologica (cfr. Fabbri P. 2002, p.40), di una tattica che sarebbe poi stata facilmente sfruttata e fatta propria da quel momento in avanti dall'industria culturale ''mainstream''."</ref> and inspired the [[culture jamming]] movement in the late 1980s.<ref name="Holt2010p252"/>
Its opposite is [[recuperation (politics)|recuperation]], in which radical ideas or the social image of people who are viewed negatively are twisted, commodified, and absorbed in a more socially acceptable context.
==Definition== In general it can be defined as a variation on previous work, in which the newly created work has a meaning that is antagonistic or antithetical to the original. The original media work that is ''détourned''<!-- must check if détourned is syntactically correct --> must be somewhat familiar to the target audience, so that it can appreciate the opposition of the new message. The artist or commentator making the variation can reuse only some of the characteristic elements of the originating work.
Détournement is similar to [[satire|satirical]] [[parody]], but employs more direct reuse or faithful [[mimicry]] of the original works rather than constructing a new work which merely alludes strongly to the original. It may be contrasted with [[recuperation (sociology)|recuperation]], in which originally subversive works and ideas are themselves [[cultural appropriation|appropriated]] by mainstream media.
One could view détournement as forming the opposite side of the coin to '[[recuperation (politics)|recuperation]]' (where radical ideas and images become safe and commodified), in that images produced by the spectacle get altered and subverted so that rather than supporting the ''status quo'', their meaning becomes changed in order to put across a more radical or oppositional message.
[[Guy Debord]] and [[Gil J Wolman]] categorized détourned elements into two types: ''minor détournements'' and ''deceptive détournements''. Minor détournements are détournements of elements that in themselves are of no real importance such as a snapshot, a press clipping, an everyday object which draw all their meaning from being placed in a new context. Deceptive détournements are when already significant elements such as a major political or philosophical text, great artwork or work of literature take on new meanings or scope by being placed in a new context.<ref>[http://www.bopsecrets.org/SI/detourn.htm A User's Guide To Détournement May 1956]</ref>
Détournement is the integration of past or present artistic production into a superior construction of a milieu. In this sense there can be no situationist painting or music, but only a situationist use of these means. In a more primitive sense, détournement with the old cultural spheres is a method of propaganda, a method that testifies to the wearing out and loss of importance of those spheres.<ref name="SI58" /><ref name="si58french"/>
== Examples after the Situationist International == In the United States, [[Frank Discussion]] is widely known for his use of détournement in his works dating from the late 1970s through the present, particularly with the [[Feederz]]. The use of détournement by [[Barbara Kruger]] familiarised many with the technique, and it was extensively and effectively used as part of the early [[AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power|HIV/AIDS activism]] of the late 1980s and early 1990s.<ref>Crimp, Douglas. ''AIDS Demographics''. Bay Press, 1990.</ref> Examples of contemporary detournement include [[Adbusters]]' "[[subvertising|subvertisements]]" and other instances of [[culture jamming]], as well as poems composed collaboratively by [[Marlene Mountain]], [[Paul Conneally]], and others, in which quotations from such famous sources as the [[Ten Commandments]] and quotations by [[United States]] President [[George W. Bush]] are combined with haiku-like phrases to produce a larger work intended to subvert the original source. The comic artist [[Brad Neely]]'s reinterpretation of [[Harry Potter]], ''[[Wizard People, Dear Reader|Wizard People]],'' took Warner Brother's first Harry Potter film, ''[[Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone (film)|The Sorcerer's Stone]],'' and substituted the original soundtrack with a narration that casts the hero as a [[Nietzschean]] [[Übermensch|superman]].
The concept of détournement has had a popular influence amongst contemporary radicals, and the technique can be seen in action in the present day when looking at the work of [[Culture Jammer]]s including the [[Cacophony Society]], [[Billboard Liberation Front]], [[monochrom]], Occupy Movements<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4JD8jNCQ2gw Détournement of Bronzed Historical Icons adorns imaginary John Harvard with a Guy Fawkes mask]</ref> and [[Adbusters]], whose 'subvertisements' 'detourn' [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] adverts, for example. In this case, the original advertisement's imagery is altered in order to draw attention to said company's policy of shifting their production base to cheap-labour third-world '[[free trade zone]]s'. However, the line between 'recuperation' and 'détournement' can become thin (or at least very fuzzy) at times, as [[Naomi Klein]] points out in her book ''[[No Logo]]''. Here she details how [[corporation]]s such as Nike, [[Pepsi]] or Diesel have approached Culture Jammers and Adbusters and offered them lucrative contracts in return for partaking in 'ironic' promotional campaigns. She points out further irony by drawing attention to merchandising produced in order to promote Adbusters' [[Buy Nothing Day]], an example of the recuperation of détournement if ever there was one.
Klein's arguments about irony [[wikt:reify|reifying]] rather than breaking down power structures are echoed by [[Slavoj Žižek]]. Žižek argues that the kind of distance opened up by détournement is the condition of possibility for ideology to operate: by attacking and distancing oneself from the sign-systems of capital, the subject creates a fantasy of transgression that "covers up" his/her actual complicity with capitalism as an overarching system. In contrast, scholars are very fond of pointing out the differences between [[hypergraphics]], 'detournement', the [[postmodern]] idea of [[cultural appropriation|appropriation]] and the [[Neoist]] use of [[plagiarism]] as the use of different and similar techniques used for different and similar means, effects and causes.
The [[Neue Slowenische Kunst]] has a long history of aggressive détournement of extreme political ideologies, as do several [[industrial music|industrial music groups]], such as [[Die Krupps]], [[Nitzer Ebb]], [[KMFDM]], and [[Front 242]].
[[Chris Morris (satirist)|Chris Morris]] uses détournement and [[culture jamming]] extensively in his work, particularly in the British television series ''[[The Day Today]]'' and ''[[Brass Eye]]''.
The [[Istanbul]]-based platform InEnArt, on the occasion of the [[Istanbul Biennial|13th Istanbul Biennial]] 2013, launched a forum titled Urban Voices focusing on phenomena that are turning expressions of the system and its media culture against itself. The authors of InEnArt are regularly publishing different phenomenas of détournement and invite the online community to participate by uploading similar examples.<ref>{{cite web|title= Public Space as a Political Forum|url=http://www.inenart.eu/?page_id=11121|work=InEnArt|accessdate=24 October 2013}}</ref>

{{Lowercase title}} '''eWorkexperience''' is an online platform created by [[Digital Bananas Technology]] for its sister company [[Career Insights]]. The online platform uses eLearning, eCollaboration, eMentoring, live digital projects that are accessible remotely to help candidates apply their learning, receive hands on training and gain practical work experience in Digital project management and business analysis.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201510200054.html|title=Nigeria: Digital Bananas Technology Changing Lives of Nigerians in Diaspora and At Home - AllAfrica|date=2015-10-19|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref>{{Infobox company | name = eWorkexperience | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Use ISO 639-1 code, e.g. "fr" for French. == The eWorkexperience platform == With over 3,000+ professionals on the platform,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2016/04/want-to-start-contracing-as-a-project-management-or-business-analysis-professional-join-career-insights-free-training-to-get-a-headstart-april-23rd/|title=Career Insights Is Now In Nigeria! Using cloud based tools and software, candidates are able to build their expertise using industry standard tools and acquire skills required to secure project management and business analysis roles locally and internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://naijavibes.net/creating-digital-jobs-opportunities-in-nigeria-abroad-career-insights-launches-their-eworkexperience-platform/|title=Creating Digital jobs opportunities in Nigeria & Abroad – Career Insights launches their eWorkexperience platform - Naijavibes.Net|date=2016-07-25|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-25}}</ref>
== History == The eWorkexperience platform was officially launched in 2014, as a collaborative learning platform offered by Career Insights.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/career-insight-berths-nigeria/|title=Career Insights berths in Nigeria - The Nation|date=2016-05-05|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref> Since launching, the eWorkexperience has increased job offers by 30% from previous success in the United Kingdom and is now preparing to use the platform to help well-educated people with no work experience in [[Sub-Saharan Africa|sub-saharan Africa]] to gain international work experience.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://guardian.ng/appointments/firm-moves-to-end-unemployment-through-online-training/|title=Firm moves to end unemployment through online training - TheGuardian|date=2016-05-05|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref>
Using eLearning, along with cloud based collaborative tools available on web and mobile, the platform gets candidates to work on live projects from the convenience of their homes while being trained on the job,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bellanaija.com/2016/04/want-to-start-contracing-as-a-project-management-or-business-analysis-professional-join-career-insights-free-training-to-get-a-headstart-april-23rd/|title=Career Insights Is Now In Nigeria! Work In The UK, US, Canada, or Dubai As a Digital Project Management Or Business Analysis Professional Earning Up to £11,000 a Month|date=2016-04-19|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref> with access to cloud based tools and software. The experience gained then makes candidates employable for digital project management and business analysis roles in reputable organisations globally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lindaikejisblog.com/2016/04/career-insights-is-now-in-nigeria-work.html|title=Career insights is now in Nigeria! Work in the UK, US, Canada, or Dubai and earn up to £11,000 a month|date=2016-04-20|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://punchng.com/nigeria-gets-e-work-experience-platform/|title=Nigeria gets e-work experience platform|date=2016-04-27|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-27}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Erwin Leonard Guy Abel''' (23 October 1911 – 1 May 1995) was a New Zealand grocer, businessman, athlete and racehorse owner. He was born in [[Ohakune]], [[Rotorua/Taupo]], [[New Zealand]] on 23 October 1911.<ref name="DNZB Abel">{{DNZB|title=Erwin Leonard Guy Abel|first= Lynette J.|last= Williams|id=5a1|accessdate=23 April 2017}}</ref> Onthey opened Abel opened New Zealand's first shopping mall, The Big A Plaza, at [[Glenview, New Zealand|Glenview, Hamilton]] in October 1969.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://mp.natlib.govt.nz/detail/?id=41793 |title=Object 41793 Detail |publisher=National Library of New Zealand |access-date=28 June 2018}}</ref>
==Life== ===Early Life & career=== On 23 October 1911, Erwin Leonard Guy Abel was born in Ohakune to a farm worker and bush contractor named Leonard Guy Abel, and his wife Rosa Hunt. He was the second of four children and was known as, Wynn. Abel grew up [[Waikato Region|Waikato]] and the [[King Country]], both regions in North-Western New Zealand; he did live for a few months on [[Banks Peninsula]]. In Cambridge, Abel worked as a grocery assistant at the Farmer's Trading Company store; he was fourteen and finished with school, he would work for eight years there.
On 16 March 1933, Abel married Jean Winifred Keene in [[Auckland]]. The couple would have five children together: Four daughters and one son. It was soon after Abel's wedding that he would get a promotion at the grocery store: Able was transferred to the [[Whangarei]] branch of farmers where he was to manage the grocery department of the store.
Abel was a very precocious young man who was constantly driven by self-improvement: He studied bookkeeping, grocery retailing and business management until he was well versed in all three subjects. In fact, Abel took up a second job, for some extra money, selling correspondence classes. In 1936, Abel had received a diploma from the London-based Fern Business Institute for management. It was soon after receiving this academic accolade that he purchased his own grocery business, the Wellworth While stores; it was located in central Whangarei.
Abel found success with his grocery business in central Whangarei, credit is likely due to his business philosophy: Combining the lowest prices with the highest quality and standards of personal services, both helping to ensure quality customers that had loyalty. His business had a catch phrase that it advertised to customers: "If Abels hasn’t got it … nobody has!". This catch phrase had really captured the essence of Abel's dedication to customer service and what his business was all about.
During the [[Second World War]] Abel and his family provided and packaged its own products at his grocery store; these products included pickled onions, bottled jam, and cream biscuits. By the 1950s, Abel purchased a second store in Whangarei and had his only son—Len—manage it.
Able was truly an innovative businessman, especially for the grocery industry; he claimed to be the first grocer to take the backs out of their shop windows at the store to allow for the customers to provide themselves with self-service.
===Mid-life and career=== In 1953, Abel had won a research trip to Europe and North America to study grocery retailing, wholesaling plus the new and wildly popular supermarkets. When Abel returned from his research trip he decided to open his own supermarket with his son. On 29 November 1961, Abel and his son had chosen [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton]] as the site for their new supermarket; it opened in the Hamilton suburb of [[Hillcrest, Waikato|Hillcrest]]. It was Hamilton's first supermarket and in turn was one of New Zealand's first supermarkets. The supermarket venture became a huge success: They very next year the Abels built four new adjoining supermarkets.
On 8 October 1969, Abel and his son opened their "Big 'A' Plaza" at [[Glenview, New Zealand|Glenview]]; at the time a fast developing suburb in Hamilton. The "Big 'A' Plaza" was the first shopping mall for New Zealand: The shopping mall was another new concept in retailing during that time. The Abels had opened three new shops at the Plaza in Glenview: A juvenile boutique, an electric appliance store, and a supermarket.
The Abels continued to purchase, sell and develop business after creating the "Big 'A' Plaza" shopping mall. The family company soon became composed of Erwin Abel, his wife Jean Abel, and his son Len Abel. The new Abel team would start with the purchase of the supermarket in [[Tauranga]]. The other purchases would soon expand to two discount grocery stores, properties in Hamilton and [[Rotorua]], and the acquisition of company to manufacture household cleansers and hardware goods.
From 1958 to 1961, Abel had served on the board of directors for [[Foodstuffs|Foodstuffs Limited]], a New Zealand grocery and liquor retailer—Abel had served on the Board in Auckland. After Abel was a consultant for [[Pak'nSave|Pak n' Save]]'s development—a New Zealand retail grocery warehouse chain that provides discount goods—he was considered highly influential and the Foodstuffs Limited board of directors became re-interested and impressed with Abel; the Directors asked him to rejoined the board of directors at Foodstuffs Limited starting in 1970 and ending in 1982.
==Personal life== In 1968, Abel and his wife decided to move from their home in Hillcrest to a new property ranging 26 acres in [[Tamahere]]; the property was called Malabar Farm. One of the appeals of their new residence was that the land could support the breeding and raising of race horses. It was at this farm that the Abels would start to breed thoroughbred race horses and raised a number of winners; the most notable was Van Der Hum whom, in 1976, won the [[Melbourne Cup]].
Abel had a serious interest in athletics and in his older years became quite an accomplished athlete. His main focus and interests in athletics lied in [[Cross country running|cross-country running]] and [[Marathon|marathon running]]. In 1965, Abel ran his first marathon. In 1981, at the New Zealand [[World Masters Athletics Championships|Veteran's Championships]], Abel—at the age of 70—had competed and won in four different events: The over 400 meter run, the over 800 meter run, the over 1500 meter run, and the over 5000 meter run. In 1983, at the All-American Championships in [[Texas]], Abel had won the gold medal for the 1500 meter in the 70 – 74 age group.
In 1982, the Abel's had finally sold their last two businesses: The supermarkets in Glenview and Hillcrest. The family decision was made on a couple of factors, however, the most important reasoning was that their son, Len, died that year due to poor health; this left the Abel couple to run two businesses past their ages of retirement, a grossly unwanted burden during their time of mourning.
===Retirement & death=== In Abel's retirement he maintained his athletic endeavours (i.e. competitive cross-country running and marathon running). Both him and his wife, Jean, also continued to breed, raise, and race thoroughbreds. In addition to Abel's other activities, he enjoyed growing and maintaining an organic vegetable garden; he served as a member of the [[Soil & Health Association of New Zealand|Soil and Health Association of New Zealand]]. Abel even took up practising [[yoga]] for relaxation and to sustain mental vitality.
In 1989, Abel and his wife, Jean, sold their home—Malabar Farm—and bought a more suitable property for their senior years; they moved to the Alandale Retirement Village, just outside Hamilton, by purchasing one of its villas. On 1 April 1995, Erwin Abel died at the Waikato Hospital in Hamilton. He had suffered from [[Parkinson's disease]] for twelve years before finally succumbing to the condition. Abel was survived by his wife, Jean (whom died in 1997), and his three daughters.
==References== {{Reflist}} *Lynette J. Williams. 'Abel, Erwin Leonard Guy', from the Dictionary of New Zealand Biography. Te Ara – the Encyclopedia of New Zealand, updated 30 October 2012

{{More citations needed|date=June 2018}} [[File:Morrisons' Distribution Centre, Eurocentral Business Park, Mossend, 18 September 2011.jpg|thumb|Morrisons' distribution centre]] '''Eurocentral''' is one of the largest industrial estates in Scotland situated on the edge of Holytown and Mossend, [[North Lanarkshire]], just off the A8/M8 motorway, about {{convert|12|mi|km}} east of [[Glasgow]] city centre and {{convert|34|mi|km}} west of [[Edinburgh]]. The nearest communities to the estate are Holytown, Mossend, Chapelhall, Calderbank and Carnbroe. The closest major towns are Bellshill {{convert|4|mi|km}}, Motherwell {{convert|4|mi|km}}, Coatbridge {{convert|4|mi|km}} and Airdrie {{convert|4.5|mi|km}}.
[[File:The Big Heids, Eurocentral (geograph 2584498).jpg|thumb|"The Big Heids" sculpture]] There is a bus link to and from Glasgow city centre and Livingston, West Lothian. Eurocentral has warehouse distribution centres, factories, call centres, a railfreight centre which links with Grangemouth docks {{convert|28|mi|km}} to the north east, England to the south and beyond to mainland Europe. The estate also has a large modern hotel/restaurant (Dakota). One of the landmarks of the Eurocentral are the so-called "Big Heids" which are three red upturned shipping containers with tubes making the shape of human heads.<ref>{{cite news |title=Scottish fact of the day: M8 motorway sculptures |url=https://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/scottish-fact-of-the-day-m8-motorway-sculptures-1-3621566 |accessdate=31 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
The Maxim Office Park is a recent addition opening in March 2010. With 10 buildings totalling over {{convert|756000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}}. Built in a single phase, Maxim is also the UK’s largest speculatively built office park.
==Eurocentral factory== Eurocentral was the name given to a former factory near [[Holytown]] in [[North Lanarkshire]], [[Scotland]] operated by the Taiwanese television parts manufacturer Chunghwa Picture Tubes (中華映管). The building is sometimes referred to as ''The Chunghwa Factory''. The factory is infamous because it was built using large amounts of taxpayers’ money but was demolished within 10 years.
Originally designed as a factory to produce [[cathode ray tube]]s for use in television sets and monitors, the rapid rise in popularity of LCD and plasma televisions contributed to the huge losses made by the Chunghwa company. It is also reported that a huge water bill from [[West of Scotland Water]] also helped contribute to the eventual demise of the site. Opening in 1996 the factory was expected to create 3,000 local jobs. However employment never rose above 1,200 and the factory was empty by 2003. The company was forced to repay £8 million of the £20 million it received from the government.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
The factory was demolished and the site developed into a mixed use commercial and business park.
==Maxim Park== The £330 million park is the UK’s largest speculative office park development, comprising 10 buildings, totalling {{convert|756000|sqft}} of high quality space. The entire park was completed in March 2010. As well as Grade A office accommodation and a wide range of shops and leisure facilities the park also houses one of Scotland's largest nurseries, Papillon Nursery and one of the [[Dakota Hotels]] (although not part of the Maxim estate it is very close by and built in keeping with the park's image).
The park currently has a shuttle bus service provided by Castle Cars of Uddingston.
Current tenants include: Proact IT, Papillon Nursery, [[Scottish Environment Protection Agency|SEPA]], REGUS, Currie & Brown, Vaillant, Berits & Brown, Peppery Horse, ACS Clothing and Sure Thing Insurance, a newly incorporated insurance intermediary.
In June 2014, planning permission was granted for the addition of a sports pavilion.

'''Gopi Krishnan''' "Krish" is an Indian-origin digital leader, banking technology professional and CIO, who has earned significant credibility in the Middle East for his role in bringing digital transformations to banking institutions in the region.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnmeonline.com/cio-spotlight/wealth-of-experience/|title=Wealth of experience|date=2016-12-14|newspaper=Computer News Middle East|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref> As of 2017, he is the Chief Information Officer/ Chief Digital Officer of the [[Al Hilal Bank]] in Qatar, UAE.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=382150386&privcapId=46950358&previousCapId=46950358&previousTitle=Al%20Hilal%20Bank%20PJSC|title=Gopikrishnan Janakaraja: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref>
Krish has been a vocal advocate for the banking sector to be early adopters or fast-followers of digital technology as “a mindset of continual learning and innovation” rather than as a project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/business/banking-finance/banking-sector-needs-to-adapt-to-shift-in-digital-solutions|title=Banking sector needs to adapt to shift in digital solutions - Khaleej Times|last=D'Mello|first=Sandhya|website=www.khaleejtimes.com|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref>
In 2016, Krish was awarded the CIO of the year award at the MEFTECH Innovation Awards 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://meftech.ae/wp-content/uploads/2016/01/MEFTECH-Conference-Programme.pdf|title=MEFTECH Conference Programme|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref> The award was a recognition of his earlier career with [[Qatar Islamic Bank]], where he played a leadership role in taking a bank-wide transformation project live on its second attempt and bringing about core banking changes and [[Legacy system|legacy systems]].<ref name="bankingtech.com">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/460322/qib-goes-live-on-temenos-t24-core-banking-system/|title=QIB goes live on Temenos’ T24 core banking system » Banking Technology|website=www.bankingtech.com|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref> He was also shortlisted for the Tech Leadership Award at the Banking Technology Awards.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://awards.bankingtech.com/judged-awards-shortlist-2016/|title=Banking Technology Awards 2016 » 2016 Shortlists|website=awards.bankingtech.com|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref>
In his present position as CIO of Al Hilal Bank, Krish hopes “to connect with [[FinTech]] CEOs and explore ways to collaborate.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bankingtech.com/557232/al-hilal-banks-new-cio-looks-to-collaborate-with-fintechs/|title=Al Hilal Bank’s new CIO looks to collaborate with fintechs » Banking Technology|website=www.bankingtech.com|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref>
== Life and career == Krish was born and raised in Ambasamudram in [[Tamil Nadu]]. An interest in basic programming took him from his degree in General Science to an advanced diploma in Technology and Information Systems and a Postgraduate Diploma in International Business from the Indian Institute of Modern Management (IIMM). Over a 19-year career, Krish went on to bring changes in organizations like Thinksoft, [[Citigroup]] EMEA (2002), Baltimore’s [[Citifinancial|CitiFinancial]] (2004) and [[Fidelity Investments]] at the City of London Telecom (COLT) in 2005.<ref name=":0" />
=== Middle-East career === In 2006, Krish took up management roles in the [[First Gulf Bank]] and implementing changes in processes, program governance, change management and enforcing stricter controls. This was followed by a two-year project in a senior position at [[BankMuscat|BankMuscat International]] where major transformations in data centers, IT systems, [[Customer relationship management|CRM]], trading platform, core banking and other areas were made.<ref name=":0" />
=== iCAN Project === In 2012 Krish joined Qatar Islamic Bank (QIB), where he spearheaded the bank-wide iCAN program with the aim of replacing the bank’s 15 year old infrastructure with new core banking platforms, greater automation of operational processes etc.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.joomag.com/magazine/intelligent-cio-issue-3/0154238001452539096?page=66|title=Intelligent CIO ISSUE 3|newspaper=Joomag|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref> [[Deloitte]] and [[Temenos Group|Temenos]] were contributing partners in the project.<ref name="bankingtech.com"/> QIB acknowledged Krish’s contribution towards growth and improvement, which led to the revision and updation of existing IT policies, creation of new IT processes under the [[ITIL|ITIL Best Practices Framework]], comprehensive [[Control self-assessment|CSA]] risk management exercises along with proper tracking and logging of internal and external audits, RCA and IT incident reports, among other changes.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://bankingfrontiers.com/meftech-award-for-indian-origin-banker/|title=MEFTECH award for Indian origin banker - Banking Frontiers|date=2016-04-25|newspaper=Banking Frontiers|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-17}} </ref>
=== Awards and recognition === In the February 2016 issue of the ''Computer News Middle East'' magazine, Krish was named as one of the best CIOs of the [[MENA]] (Middle East and North Africa) region for 2015, being the only CIO from Qatar’s banking industry to receive the honor.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/computernewsme/docs/cnme-feb-16|title=Computer News Middle East February 2016|newspaper=issuu|access-date=2017-01-17}}</ref> Also in 2016, Krish received the CIO of the Year Award at the MEFTECH Innovation Awards held in [[Abu Dhabi]], for his leadership roles, improvement and growth contributions as a senior executive in the innovations achieved by QIB as a MENA-based institution.<ref name=":1" />

{{For|tendering in the public service|Civil service examination}} {{trade bloc}} '''Government procurement''' or '''public procurement''' is the [[procurement]] of [[Good (economics and accounting)|goods]], [[Service (economics)|services]] and [[construction]] on behalf of a public authority, such as a [[government]] agency. With 10 to 20% of [[GDP]], government procurement accounts for a substantial part of the global economy.<ref>[http://www.cid.harvard.edu/cidtrade/issues/govpro.html Global Trade Negotiations Home Page] at [[Harvard University]], accessed 18 December 2006</ref>
To prevent [[fraud]], [[waste]], [[Political corruption|corruption]], or local [[protectionism]], the laws of most countries regulate government procurement to some extent. Laws usually require the procuring authority to issue public [[Call for bids|tenders]] if the value of the procurement exceeds a certain threshold.
Government procurement is also the subject of the [[Agreement on Government Procurement]] (GPA), a [[plurilateral]] international treaty under the auspices of the [[WTO]].
==Overview==
=== Need for government procurement === Government procurement is necessary because governments cannot produce all the inputs for the goods they provide themselves. Governments usually provide [[public good]]s, e.g. national defense or public infrastructure. Public goods are non-rival and non-excludable, which means that one individual's consumption does not diminish the quantity or quality of the commodity available to others, and individuals cannot be prevented from freely consuming the commodity, or [[Free-rider problem|"free-riding"]]. Consequently, private markets cannot provide public goods. Instead the government provides those goods and finances them by raising taxes from all citizens.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/712588185|title=Economics|last=Mankiw|first=Nicholas Gregory|date=2011|publisher=Cengage Learning|others=Taylor, Mark P. 1958-|year=|isbn=9781844808700|edition= 2nd|location=Andover|pages=223–226|oclc=712588185}}</ref>
In addition to public goods, governments often also provide [[merit good]]s, such as education or health care. Merit goods are [[private good]]s which are rival and excludable and are therefore provided by private markets. Nevertheless, governments also provide merit goods because of reasons of [[Equity (economics)|equity]] and fairness and because they have [[Externality|positive externalities]] for society as a whole.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/39485400|title=Economics of the Public Sector|last=Stiglitz|first=Joseph|date=2000|publisher=W.W. Norton|year=|isbn=0393966518|edition= 3rd|location=New York|pages=86–88|oclc=39485400}}</ref>
In order to provide public and merit goods, the government has to buy input factors from private companies, e.g. police cars, school buildings, uniforms etc. This process is called government or public procurement.
=== Problems === Government procurement involves a high risk of [[corruption]] because of the great size of financial turnover and the complexitiy of many procurement processes in which businesses interact very closely with politicians and civil servants. Often the personal interests of the public officials are not the same as the interests of the public. Such a conflict of interest problem, known as the [[Principal–agent problem|principal-agent-problem]], increases the risk of corruption. According to [[OECD]], the highest percentage of bribery cases occur in the area of public procurement to influence the awarding of public contracts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.oecd.org/gov/ethics/Corruption-Public-Procurement-Brochure.pdf|title=Preventing Corruption in Public Procurement|last=|first=|date=2016|website=|publisher=OECD|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> Corruption in public procurement causes inefficiencies and high costs to the public. In order to prevent corruption and to ensure transparency and competition among suppliers, public procurement is subject to legal regulation.
===Scope=== Government procurement regulations normally cover all [[public works]], services and supply contracts entered into by a public authority. However, there may be exceptions. These most notably cover [[military acquisition]]s, which account for large parts of government expenditures. The GPA and EU procurement law allow of exceptions where public tendering would violate a country's essential security interests. Additionally, certain politically or economically sensitive sectors, such as public health, energy supply or public transport, may also be treated differently.<ref name="Prieß: Global Overview">{{cite journal|last=Prieß|first=Hans-Joachim|author2=Harvey, Diana|author3=Friton, Pascal|title=Global Overview|journal=Prieß (2012)|pages=3–7}}</ref>
==Regulation by jurisdiction==
===Algeria=== Presidential Decree No. 10-236 of 7 October 2010, supplemented and amended by Presidential Decree No. 12-23 of 18 January 2012, regulate public procurement in [[Algeria]].<ref>Ben Abderrahmane & Partners, [http://www.benlawyers.com/algerian-law/algerian-public-procurement-law-algerian-public-law-144.html Algerian public procurement law - Algerian public law], accessed 1 November 2018</ref>
===American Samoa=== The Office of Procurement, based in [[Tafuna]], is the central authority on procurement for the [[American Samoa]] [[Government of American Samoa|Government]] (ASG), being responsible for the procurement of all construction, goods, and services including the management, control, warehousing, and sale of stores/inventory commodities contained in its warehouse.<ref>American Samoa Government, [https://www.americansamoa.gov/office-of-procurement Office of Procurement]</ref>
===Angola=== Public procurement in [[Angola]] is governed by Law No. 20/10 of 7 September 2010, the Public Procurement Law, and Law No. 2/2011 on Public-Private Partnerships in Angola. The Public Procurement Law repealed Law No. 7/96 of 16 February 1996 and Decree No. 40/05 of 8 June 2005. Public expenditure, the provision of services, the leasing and acquisition of goods, and public works contracts regulated through the Public Procurement Law.<ref>Rodrigues, A. M. and Dias, N. M., [http://www.gla-plmj.com/xms/files/NEW_PRIVATE_INVESTMENT_LAW_CLOSE_TO_ENACTMENT.pdf The New Rules on Public Procurement], published June 2011, accessed 8 November 2016</ref>
===Ascension Island=== All goods required by the [[Ascension Island]] government are purchased through the Ascension Island Government (AIG) Stores, located just outside the [[Georgetown, Ascension Island|Georgetown]] Pier. Goods are also for sale to the general public.<ref>Ascension Island Government, [http://www.ascension-island.gov.ac/government/stores/ Stores], accessed 7 March 2018</ref>
===Australia=== The [[Australian government]]'s procurement activity is governed by the Commonwealth Procurement Rules and overseen by the [[Department of Finance (Australia)|Department of Finance]].<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/ Procurement], accessed 8 June 2018</ref> The rules were revised on 1 January 2018.<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-policy-and-guidance/commonwealth-procurement-rules/ Commonwealth Procurement Rules], accessed 8 June 2018</ref> The Procurement Coordinator is responsible for: *providing external parties with an understanding of the Commonwealth Procurement Framework; *handling of certain procurement-related complaints (although the Procurement Coordinator has no authority to compel a [[List of Australian government entities|government department]] to reconsider the conduct or outcome of tender processes for which that department is responsible);<ref>Procurement Coordinator, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-coordinator/complaints-handling-charter.html Complaints Handling Charter], 2 October 2014, accessed 10 June 2018</ref> *monitoring issues related to Australian Government procurement; and *reporting to the Minister for Finance on procurement matters where necessary.<ref>Department of Finance, [https://www.finance.gov.au/procurement/procurement-coordinator/ Procurement Coordinator], accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
The Senate Order for Entity Contracts of 20 June 2001 (amended 14 May 2015), also known as the ''[[Andrew Murray (Australian politician)|Murray Motion]]'', requires ministers to publish details of public contracts valued over [[Australian dollar|AUS$]]100,000 on the internet and to table a letter detailing such contracts in the [[Senate (Australia)|Senate]].<ref>[https://www.finance.gov.au/sites/default/files/rmg_403-meeting-the-senate-order-on-entity-contracts.pdf RMG-403: Meeting the Senate Order for Entity Contracts], published February 2017, accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
On 1 December 2016 the House of Representatives and the Senate established a Joint Select Committee to inquire into and report on the Commonwealth Procurement Framework.<ref>Parliament of Australia, [https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Former_Committees/Government_Procurement Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement], accessed 10 June 2018</ref> The Committee reported in June 2017 recommending a series of amendments to the current Commonwealth Procurement Rules.<ref>Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement, [https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Former_Committees/Government_Procurement/CommProcurementFramework/Report/section?id=committees%2freportjnt%2f024068%2f24617 ''Buying into our Future'': List of Recommendations], June 2017, accessed 10 June 2018</ref> The Australian government issued a response on 14 November 2017 accepting a number of the recommendations but rejecting others.<ref>Australian Government, [https://www.aph.gov.au/DocumentStore.ashx?id=21281bc3-f2e3-40d9-bf57-46b7a506e3db Australian Government response to the Joint Select Committee on Government Procurement report: Buying into our Future: Review of amendments to the Commonwealth Procurement Rules], 14 November 2017</ref>
[[Infrastructure Australia]] has issued a national [[Public Private Partnership]] (PPP) Policy and set of guidelines on behalf of the federal government, which apply to all PPP projects released in Australia.<ref>DLA Piper, [http://www.dlapiperrealworld.com/law/index.html?t=construction&s=forms-of-contract-procurement-methods&q=public-procurement&c=AU Public procurement in Australia], ''Real World'' website, accessed 8 June 2018</ref>
====Tasmania==== Public bodies in [[Tasmania]] are required to comply with the [[Treasurer of Tasmania|Treasurer]]'s Instructions on Purchasing and Property.<ref>Tasmanian Government, [http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/purchasing-and-property/purchasing-and-property-treasurers-instructions Purchasing and Property Treasurer's Instructions], accessed 9 July 2018</ref> The [[Department of State Growth (Tasmania)|Department of State Growth]]'s Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy has been established to ensure that (where feasible) [[Sustainable development|sustainably]] sourced [[Wood product|wood]] is fully considered within Government procurement decision-making.<ref>Department of State Growth, [http://www.purchasing.tas.gov.au/Documents/Tasmanian-Wood-Encouragement-Policy.pdf Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy], May 2017, accessed 9 July 2018</ref><ref>Tasmanian Government, [http://www.treasury.tas.gov.au/Documents/TI-1130.PDF Tasmanian Wood Encouragement Policy - Goods and Services], Treasurer’s Instruction No. 1130, effective 21 July 2017, accessed 9 July 2018</ref>
====Western Australia==== Since 1 July 2018, government departments in [[Western Australia]] have been required to award an increasing percentage of contracts to registered [[Aboriginal Australians|Aboriginal]] businesses under the state's [[Government of Western Australia|government]]'s Aboriginal Procurement Policy.<ref>Government of Western Australia, Department of Finance,[http://www.finance.wa.gov.au/cms/Government_Procurement/Policies/Aboriginal_Procurement_Policy.aspx Aboriginal Procurement Policy], accessed 5 May 2018</ref> The target is 1% of contracts initially, increasing to 2% on 1 July 2019 and 3% on 1 July 2020.<ref>Government of Western Australia, [https://www.mediastatements.wa.gov.au/Pages/McGowan/2017/12/Aboriginal-Procurement-Policy-to-drive-Aboriginal-entrepreneurship-and-business-opportunities.aspx Aboriginal Procurement Policy to drive Aboriginal entrepreneurship and business opportunities], published 19 December 2017, accessed 1 August 2018</ref>
===Bangladesh=== The [[Swiss challenge (procurement)|Swiss Challenge]] system is utilised in [[Bangladesh]] to procure infrastructure development through [[public-private partnerships]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Your Guide to Public Private Partnership in Bangladesh|url=http://www.pppo.gov.bd/download/ppp_office/Your-Guide-to-PPP-in-Bangladesh.pdf|accessdate=3 April 2016}}</ref>
=== Brazil === The procedure of government procurement in Brazil is regulated for a lot of different laws with different procedures depending on the importance and the value of the procurement. The most important law about government procurement which contains basic rules of public procurements and administrative contracts is the Law nº 8.666, 21 june 1993, which contains rules for public tenders and for restricted tenders. There are other different rules to regulate procurement public services, as Law nº 8.987, 13 february 1995 (Concession and Permission of Public Services); Law nº 12.462, 4 august 2011 (Differentiated Procurement - RDC in portuguese) and Law nº 10.520, 17 july 2002, with deal with presential auction. In the internet field (e-procurement) there are executive orders (Decretos) which regulate public procurement as Decree nº 5.450, 31 may 2005 and Decree nº 7.982, 23 january 2013. This latter regulates the procedure of specific situations of sharing acquisitions of goods or under portioned deliverings.<ref>All information can be found in https://www.comprasgovernamentais.gov.br/index.php/legislacao</ref>
===Canada=== Public procurement in Canada is regulated on various governmental levels (federal, provincial, municipal). Most federal procurement is organized by the [[Public Services and Procurement Canada]] (PSPC) agency and is governed by their Code of Conduct of Procurement in combination with principles laid out in the Federal Accountability Act and in the Financial Administration Act. Public procurement is guided by the principles of fairness, transparency, openness, and non-discrimination and complies with all international agreements that Canada is a member of (WTO [[Agreement on Government Procurement|Government Procurement Agreement]] [GPA], [[North American Free Trade Agreement|NAFTA]], [[Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement|CETA]], and various bilateral FTAs). Foreign suppliers from member nations to these agreements can bid on Canadian government procurements and are treated the same as domestic suppliers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tpsgc-pwgsc.gc.ca/app-acq/cndt-cndct/contexte-context-eng.html|title=Code of Conduct for Procurement. Context and Purpose of the Code|last=|first=|date=2018-03-09|website=|publisher=Public Works and Government Services Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
The principal statutory provisions regulating government procurement are:
*Department of Public Works and Government Services Act (1996) *Financial Administration Act (1985) and the Government Contracts Regulations <ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-87-402/index.html Government Contracts Regulations], accessed 23 May 2016</ref> *Defence Production Act 1985 (consolidated version published 2011) <ref>[http://www.wipo.int/wipolex/en/text.jsp?file_id=207971 Defence Production Act (R.S.C., 1985, c. D-1) (consolidated version of January 30, 2011)]</ref> *[[Federal Accountability Act|Federal Accountability Act, 2006]] <ref>Public Works and Government Services Canada, [https://buyandsell.gc.ca/policy-and-guidelines/supply-manual/section/1/20 Statutes and Regulations], accessed 23 May 2016</ref>
In general, bids must be solicited by the procuring department unless estimated expenditure does not exceed $25,000, or $100,000 "where the contract is for the acquisition of architectural, engineering and other services required in respect of the planning, design, preparation or supervision of the construction, repair, renovation or restoration of a work".<ref>[http://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/regulations/SOR-87-402/page-2.html#docCont Government Contracts Regulation 6b], accessed 23 May 2016</ref> For contracts above $25,000, tenders are published on the transparent Government Electronic Tendering Service (GETS). A non-competitive procurement process is only used in certain special circumstances. One such area of exception are security-related procurements. In that case the Defence Production Act applies, which allows using a special process and favouring domestic suppliers in acquiring defence supplies and conducting defence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://buyandsell.gc.ca/for-businesses/selling-to-the-government-of-canada/the-procurement-process|title=The Procurement Process|last=Engagement|first=Government of Canada, Public Works and Government Services Canada, Acquisitions Branch, Office of Small and Medium Enterprises and Strategic|website=buyandsell.gc.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
===East Timor=== The Ministry of Finance in [[East Timor]] or Timor-Leste is responsible for the oversight of government procurement.<ref>Ministry of Finance, [https://www.mof.gov.tl/government-procurement/?lang=en Procurement], accessed 13 October 2018</ref> The Government uses the Timor-Leste eProcurement Portal for purchasing.<ref>[http://www.eprocurement.gov.tl/public/indexeprtl?&lang=en Timor-Leste eProcurement Portal]</ref>
===Ethiopia=== Government procurement in [[Ethiopia]] is governed by the Ethiopian Federal Government Procurement and Property Administration Proclamation No.649/2009,<ref name=Eth>[https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4f0l6J9WQrBYzNmZmJiZjEtYjkyYS00NjhiLWFkMmEtOTA5NjdjMTdkNGEz/view Ethiopian Federal Government Procurement and Property Administration Proclamation], 9 September 2009, accessed 6 November 2011</ref> which replaced the proclamation on Procedures of Public Procurement and Establishing its Supervisory Agency, Proclamation No. 430/2005. The Public Procurement and Property Administration Agency advises the federal government on "on all public procurement and property administration policies, principles and implementation" and provides "technical assistance to the regional governments and city administrations".<ref name=Eth />
===European Union=== {{Main|Government procurement in the European Union}} Government procurement in the European Union accounts for more than EUR 2.2 trillion, or 14% of the EU GDP.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ec.europa.eu/growth/single-market/public-procurement_en|title=Public Procurement - Growth - European Commission|website=Growth|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> It has been regulated and harmonized by [[European Union law|community law]] since the 1970s in order to guarantee transparency and non-discrimination of EU companies in government procurement in all member states. EU laws apply only to tenders that exceed certain thresholds in value. These thresholds vary depending on the area the contract is for and if the procurement is done by a central government or by other public authorities (e.g. municipal government). National laws are applied for tenders below these threshold values.<ref name="Rules & procedures">{{Cite web|url=https://europa.eu/youreurope/business/public-tenders/rules-procedures/index_en.htm|title=Rules & procedures|website=Your Europe - Business|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> Relevant EU Directives regarding government procurement currently in force are [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?qid=1415011920358&uri=CELEX:32009L0081 Directive 2009/81], [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32014L0024 Directive 2014/24], and [https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/en/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32014L0025 Directive 2014/25].
There are five different procedures for public procurement:<ref name="Rules & procedures"/>
*Open procedure: any company is allowed to submit a tender *Restricted procedure: only companies that have been preselected are allowed to submit a tender *Negotiated procedure: there are direct negotiations with at least three companies *Competitive dialogue: if it is not possible to define technical specifications at the beginning, a competitive dialogue with at least three companies is started after which tenders can be submitted. This procedure is applied for complex procurements. *Electronic auctions: companies that pass a pre-evaluation process can bid in electronic auctions for public contracts
The European Commission is working on further improving efficiency and transparency in government procurement in the EU with its current public procurement strategy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/growth/single-market/public-procurement/strategy_en|title=Public procurement strategy - Growth - European Commission|website=Growth|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
====Austria==== Government procurement in [[Austria]] is regulated by the Federal Procurement Act 2017.<ref>Stalzer, J., [https://www.schoenherr.eu/publications/publication-detail/austria-imminent-implementation-of-public-procurement-directives/ Austria: Imminent implementation of public procurement directives], accessed 14 March 2018</ref>
====Belgium==== [[Belgium|Belgian]] legislation on public procurement is set out in the Act of 17 June 2016 implementing the 2014 EU procurement directives.<ref>International Comparative Legal Guide, [https://iclg.com/practice-areas/public-procurement-laws-and-regulations/belgium Public Procurement 2018: Belgium], accessed 27 March 2018</ref> The Laws of 17 June 2016 on public procurement and on concession contracts, and the Law of 16 February 2017 on remedies, failed to meet the EU's transposition deadline (18 April 2016). [[Royal order (Belgium)|Royal Decree]]s issued on 18 April 2017 for general public procurement, 18 June 2017 for procurement in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors, 22 June 2017 containing new rules on the performance of public works contracts and concession contracts for public works and 25 June 2017, for the award and performance of concession contracts, have augmented the earlier laws.<ref name=vbb>Van Bael and Bellis, [https://www.vbb.com/media/Insights_Articles/VBB_Memorandum_Public_Procurement_27_07_2017.pd.pdf New Belgian Regulatory Framework Governing Public Procurement – Overview of Main Novelties], accessed 29 October 2018</ref>
Article 51 of the Royal Decree of 18 April 2017 includes a "revolving door mechanism", which targets the situation where a person previously working for a contracting authority is now being employed by an economic operator involved in a public procurement procedure established by that contracting authority. In this type of situation the person would be presumed to have a [[conflict of interest]] for a two-year period following the termination of his/her employment with the contracting authority.<ref name=vbb />
====Bulgaria==== Government procurement in Bulgaria is a critical area in corruption risk. Public procurement contracts have been awarded to a handful of companies amid widespread irregularities, procedure violations and tailor-made selection or award criteria.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/bg.pdf|title=Public procurement in Bulgaria|work=Study on administrative capacity in the EU|publisher=European Commission|accessdate=16 July 2018}}</ref> The Bulgarian public procurement portal reported in September 2016 that since the beginning of 2016, "a total of 15,105 contracts were signed on the basis of public procurement orders".<ref>Sofia News Agency, [http://www.novinite.com/articles/176510/15%2C105+Public+Procurement+Contracts+Signed+So+Far+in+2016 15,105 Public Procurement Contracts Signed So Far in 2016], accessed 1 October 2016</ref> At the beginning of 2015, the [[Bulgarian government]] announced a 130-kilometer extension to the barbed wire [[Bulgarian border barrier|border fence]] along its border with [[Turkey]] in order to completely secure the land border. Prime Minister [[Boyko Borisov]] described the extension as "absolutely necessary" in order to prevent persons from [[Illegal immigration|illegally]] entering the European Union member state.<ref>{{cite web|title= Bulgaria to extend fence at Turkish border to bar refugee influx |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/01/14/us-bulgaria-turkey-fence-idUSKBN0KN1JG20150114 |accessdate=April 12, 2015}}</ref> The [[Bulgarian Parliament]] authorised amendments to procurement legislation to allow continued construction of the fence without launching a public procurement procedure "because of the need to safeguard national security".<ref>{{cite web|title= Parliament OKs Building of Border Fence Without Public Procurement |url=http://www.novinite.com/articles/166066/Parliament+OKs+Building+of+Border+Fence+Without+Public+Procurement |accessdate=April 12, 2015}}</ref> Overall,
====Croatia==== The first public procurement law in [[Croatia]] based on the EU Procurement Directives was enacted in 2001, but a revised legal structure for public procurement was put in place with the Public Procurement Act of 2012,<ref name=HR>European Commission, [http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/hr.pdf Public procurement – Study on administrative capacity in the EU: Croatia Country Profile]</ref> and this was superseded by the Public Procurement Act of 2016, effective 1 January 2017.<ref>Tematikon Project, [http://www.tematikon.com/en/review/published-new-public-procurement-act-16 Published new Public Procurement Act], accessed 23 May 2018</ref> Public-private partnerships (PPPs) are governed by the Act on Public-Private Partnerships.<ref>DLA Piper, [http://www.dlapiperrealworld.com/law/index.html?t=construction&s=forms-of-contract-procurement-methods&q=public-procurement&c=HR Public procurement], accessed 23 May 2018</ref> Two key Croatian institutions are the Public Procurement Office and the Public Procurement Supervisory Commission, established in 2001,<ref>Madir, J. and Rimac, L.,[http://www.ebrd.com/downloads/research/law/lit113h.pdf Croatia: reforms to meet the terms of the EU ''acquis''], accessed 12 May 2018</ref> now (since 2013) the State Commission for Supervision of Public Procurement (DKOM).<ref name=HR /> The State Commission is an independent quasi-judicial body with nine members appointed by the [[Croatian Parliament]] for a five-year term and accountable to the Croatian Parliament for its work. The High Administrative Court of the Republic of Croatia has jurisdiction over the State Commission in relation to disputes concerning procedure, but there is no right of appeal against Commission decisions.<ref>State Commission for Supervision of Public Procurement, [http://www.dkom.hr/en/about-us/1197 About us], accessed 23 May 2018</ref>
Under [[Croatian law]], procurement procedures must be carried out by authorised representatives of the contracting authority, of whom at least one must hold a valid procurement certificate.
====Cyprus==== The Public Procurement Directorate of the Treasury of the [[Republic of Cyprus]] is responsible for procurement policy.<ref>Treasury of the Republic, [http://www.treasury.gov.cy/treasury/PublicPro/ppro.nsf/dmlindex_en/dmlindex_en Public Procurement], accessed 24 May 2018</ref>
====Czech Republic==== Government procurement in the [[Czech Republic]] is regulated by Act No. 134/2016 Coll., on Public Contracts, signed by the [[President of the Czech Republic|President of the Republic]] on 22 April 2016.<ref>Zeman, M., [http://law.vozab.com/czech-en/168-new-act-no-134-2016-coll-on-public-procurement New act no. 134/2016 Coll. on public procurement], Vozáb & Co., accessed 16 June 2018</ref>
====Denmark==== [[Economic operator]]s who are dissatisfied with the conduct of public procurement activity in [[Denmark]] may complain to the Klagenævnet for Udbud (Public Procurement Complaints Board).
====Estonia==== The [[Estonia]]n [[Ministry of Finance (Estonia)|Ministry of Finance]] is responsible for public procurement policy, drafting the law, providing supervision and consultancy, and maintains a central Public Procurement Register.<ref>Ministry of Finance, [https://riigihanked.riik.ee/register/ E-Procurement Estonia: Procurement Register], accessed 14 June 2018</ref> The current legislation is the Public Procurement Act of 2017, which came into effect on 1 September 2017,<ref>Riigi Teataja, [https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/505092017003/consolide Public Procurement Act 2017], accessed 14 June 2018</ref> and which operates in conjunction with the Public Information Act of 2000, which regulates the publication of "information concerning public procurements which are being organised or have been organised by the state or local governments".<ref>Riigi Teataja, [https://www.riigiteataja.ee/en/eli/514112013001/consolide Public Information Act 2000], section 28(1)(20)</ref> Disputes are handled by the Public Procurements Appeal Committee.
Defence procurement for the Defence Forces, [[Ministry of Defence (Estonia)|Ministry of Defence]], [[Estonian Defence League|Defence League]], Defence Resources Agency and Estonian War Museum is organised by the Estonian Centre for Defence Investment, whose purpose is "to carry out procurement activities through ... professional-quality procurement and to use dedicated funds sparingly and prudently".<ref>[http://www.kaitseministeerium.ee/en/organisation-contacts/centre-defence-investments/defence-procurement Defence Procurement], accessed 2 June 2018</ref> The Centre for Defence Investment was established by the decree of the Minister of Defence on 9 November 2015 and became operational on 1 January 2017.<ref>[http://www.kaitseministeerium.ee/en/organisation-contacts/centre-defence-investment Centre for Defence Investment], accessed 2 June 2018</ref>
====Finland==== In [[Finland]] the following legislation applies to government procurement: *Act on Public Contracts and Concession Contracts (Act no. 1397 of 2016, effective 1 January 2017) <ref>Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment, [http://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2016/en20161397.pdf Act on Public Procurement and Concession Contracts], accessed 31 July 2018</ref> *Act on Public Contracts by Contracting Authorities in the Water, Energy, Transport and Postal Services Sectors (Act no. 1398 of 2016, also known as the 'Act on public contracts in special sectors') *Act on Public Contracts in the Fields of Defence and Security.<ref>[https://www.kkv.fi/en/facts-and-advice/competition-affairs/supervision-of-public-procurement/ Supervision of Public Procurement], accessed 30 July 2018</ref><ref name=Finland>The Law Reviews, [https://thelawreviews.co.uk/edition/the-government-procurement-review-edition-4/1136567/finland The Government Procurement Review, Issue 4 - Finland], accessed 11 July 2018</ref>
A Government Decree on Public Contracts was also in force until 2017.<ref name=Finland />
The [[Ministry of Economic Affairs and Employment (Finland)|Ministry of Employment and the Economy]] is responsible for the preparation of legislation concerning public procurement. The Finnish Competition and Consumer Authority (FCCA) oversees public procurement: section 139 of the Act on Public Procurement and Concession Contracts mandates the FCCA to supervise compliance with public contracts legislation and to provide 'administrative guidance' or if necessary to issue a caution to a non-compliant public authority.<ref>FCCA, [https://www.kkv.fi/en/current-issues/press-releases/2018/26.6.2018-fcca-reprimands-riihimaki-and-vaasa-for-failing-to-invite-tenders-for-procurement-contracts/ FCCA reprimands Riihimäki and Vaasa for failing to invite tenders for procurement contracts], published 6 June 2018, accessed 31 July 2018</ref> The Market Court operates as a specialist court handling public procurement cases. The Market Court's rulings in public procurement cases can be appealed to the [[Supreme Administrative Court of Finland]].<ref name=Finland />
The Act on Electronic Auctions and Dynamic Purchasing Systems of 17 June 2011, which entered into force on 1 October 2011, introduced new procurement procedures, whereby documents relating to procurement would be sent and received exclusively online. This legislation included the use of [[Eauction|eAuction]]s.<ref>European Commission, [https://joinup.ec.europa.eu/sites/default/files/document/2014-06/eGov%20in%20FI%20-%20May%202014%20-%2016.0.pdf eGovernment in Finland, May 2014], accessed 31 July 2018</ref> Electronic procurement is now covered within the 2016 Act on Public Contracts.
Transposition of the 2014 EU public procurement directive into Finnish law was delayed after the deadline (18 April 2016) with the consequence that some aspects of the directive were directly applicable from April 2016 until the new Finnish legislation was in place from 1 January 2017.<ref>Merilampi, [http://www.merilampi.com/the-reform-of-the-act-on-public-contracts-the-finnish-legislation-is-delayed/?lang=en The reform of the Act on Public Contracts – the Finnish legislation is delayed], published 28 April 2016, accessed 27 July 2018</ref>
[[Hansel Ltd.]] is a state-owned central purchasing body established by the ''Act on a Limited Liability Company Called Hansel Oy'', which operates framework agreements and supports central government departments in Finland with public procurement tasks.<ref>[https://www.hansel.fi/en/framework-agreements/ Hansel - Framework Agreements], accessed 31 July 2018</ref>
==== France ==== In France, the Department of Legal Affairs (DAJ) of the [[French Ministry for the Economy and Finance|Ministry for the Economy and Finance]] ([[French language|French]]: ''Ministère de l'Économie et des Finances'') is responsible for establishing regulations regarding public procurement (''la commande publique''). All currently relevant EU directives have been implemented into national law.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.economie.gouv.fr/daj/commande-publique|title=Commande publique|work=Le portail des ministères économiques et financiers|access-date=2018-06-09|language=fr}}</ref>
The ''Union des Groupements d’Achat Public'' (UGAP), based in [[Champs-sur-Marne]] east of Paris,<ref>[https://www.ugap.fr/ l'UGAP] (in French)</ref> operates as the only general public procurement agency in France.<ref>[https://www.cgi.com/en/CGI-selected-UGAP-France-national-procurement-agency-bring-consulting-IT-skills-public-sector CGI selected by UGAP, France’s national procurement agency, to bring its consulting and IT skills to the public sector], 4 February 2013, accessed 1 August 2018</ref>
==== Germany ==== In Germany, the [[Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy]] ([[German language|German]]: ''Bundesministerium für Wirtschaft und Energie'', abbreviated BMWi) is responsible for defining laws and principles regarding public procurement. In 2016 Germany transposed the new EU Directives of 2014 into domestic law. Thereby, processes and contracts in public procurement have become easier and more flexible. The Act against Restraints of Competition - Part IV (German: ''[[:de:Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen|Gesetz gegen Wettbewerbsbeschränkungen]]'', abbreviated GWB) and the Ordinance on the Award of Public Contracts (German: [[:de:Vergabeverordnung|V''erordnung über die Vergabe öffentlicher Aufträge'']], abbreviated VgV) regulate procurement above EU thresholds. Detailed procedures are specified in further regulations, e.g. the Procurement Regulation for Public Works (German abbreviation: [[:de:Vergabe- und Vertragsordnung für Bauleistungen|VOB]]), the Procurement Regulation for Public Supplies and Services ([[:de:Vergabe- und Vertragsordnung für Leistungen|VOL]]), and the Procurement Regulation for Professional Services ([[:de:Vergabeordnung für freiberufliche Leistungen|VOF]]).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bmwi.de/Redaktion/EN/Dossier/public-procurement.html|title=Public Procurement|last=|first=|date=|website=Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> For many contracts electronic procurement is made possible via an [https://www.evergabe-online.de/start.html?0 online platform].
For public procurement below the EU thresholds there are different regulations. At the federal level national budgetary law applies while the 16 federal German states and some municipalities have their own public procurement laws and regulations. This decentralized system reflects the political decentralization in Germany. However, sub-national level procurement regulations often take national regulations as examples and also ensure competition, non-discrimination, and transparency.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/de.pdf|title=Public Procurement - Germany Country Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref>
====Gibraltar==== Government procurement in [[Gibraltar]] is managed by the Procurement Office, an independent office of [[Her Majesty's Government of Gibraltar|Her Majesty's Government of Gibraltar]] which reports directly to the Financial Secretary.<ref>Government of Gibraltar, [https://gibraltar.gov.gi/new/procurement-office Procurement Office], accessed 5 July 2016</ref>
