====Greece==== Law 4412/2016 on public procurement and Law 4413/2016 on concessions are the main instruments of [[Greece|Greek]] legislation governing public procurement. These two laws of 2016, along with earlier reforms introduced under Law 4281/2014 on public procurement law, have radically simplified the previously complex legal regime, repealing numerous previous laws.<ref>International Comparative Legal Guides, [https://iclg.com/practice-areas/public-procurement-laws-and-regulations/greece Public Procurement 2018: Greece], published 26 January 2018, accessed 6 August 2018</ref> The European Commission's profile for [[Greece]] in its study of administrative capacity in the EU had described the public procurement system in the country as "singularly complex, ... being dispersed among as many as 400 laws, regulations, and presidential decrees".<ref name=profile>[http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/el.pdf Public procurement – Study on administrative capacity in the EU: Greece Country Profile]</ref> Public contract notices are published in the Central Electronic Registry for Public Procurement (KIMDIS).<ref>[https://www.unodc.org/documents/treaties/UNCAC/WorkingGroups/workinggroup4/2016-August-22-24/Contributions_NV/Greece_EN.pdf Hellenic Single Public Procurement Authority], accessed 6 August 2018</ref>
The Public Procurement Monitoring Unit (PPMU), established in 1997, part of the Centre of International and European Economic Law in [[Thessaloniki]], provides Greek contracting authorities with "specialised and prompt legal advisory support on awarding public works and technical services contracts falling within the scope of EU Law on Public Procurement".<ref name=profile /><ref>[http://mopadis.cieel.gr/index.jsp?extLang=LG Public Procurement Monitoring Unit: Welcome], accessed 6 August 2018</ref>
====Hungary==== The [[Hungary|Hungarian]] Public Procurement Authority was established by Act XL of 1995 <ref>[http://www.kozbeszerzes.hu/english/ Public Procurement Authority of Hungary]</ref> and the current Public Procurement Act (Act CXLIII of 2015) entered into force on November 1, 2015, implementing the 2014 EU procurement directives.<ref name=cxliii>[https://www.procurementinet.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Public-Procurement-Act-Hungary.pdf Act CXLIII of 2015 on Public Procurement], accessed 13 August 2018</ref> The objectives of the 2015 legislation are: *to secure transparency and public control of the effective use of public funds; *to establish conditions of fair competition in public procurement; *to enhance the access of local small and medium-sized enterprises to procurement procedures; and *to promote environmental protection and the social considerations of the State.<ref name=cxliii /> Concession award procedures are also covered within the same legislation, and the fundamental principles set out in Act V of 2013 on the [[Civil Code]], the "ultimate instrument relating to the operation of civil persons and economic organizations", also apply to public procurement.<ref>Borsy Association of Lawyers, [http://borsyugyveditarsulas.hu/en/magyar-az-uj-polgari-torvenykonyvrol/ The New Civil Code of Hungary], accessed 13 August 2018</ref>
====Ireland==== Government procurement in [[Ireland]] is governed by the European Communities (Award of Public Authorities' Contracts) Regulations 2006 <ref>[http://etenders.gov.ie/Media/Default/SiteContent/LegislationGuides/Public%20Sector%20Procurement%20Regulations%202006.pdf S.I. No. 329 of 2006: European Communities (Award of Public Authorities’ Contracts) Regulations 2006]</ref> and the European Communities (Public Authorities’ Contracts) (Review Procedures) Regulations 2010. [[Patrick O'Donovan|Patrick O’Donovan TD]] is the [[Ministers of State of the 32nd Dáil|Minister of State]] with special responsibility for Public Procurement.<ref>Office of Government Procurement, [http://ogp.gov.ie/wp-content/uploads/ogp-newsletterfeb2018.pdf OGP News], February 2018, accessed 2 April 2018</ref>
==== Italy ==== Public procurement in [[Italy]] is primarily regulated by the Public Contracts Code, which is administered by the [[Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport (Italy)|Ministry of Infrastructure and Transport]] ([[Italian language|Italian]]: Ministero delle infrastrutture e dei trasporti). The code was reformed in 2016 to implement the new EU directives of 2014 into domestic Italian law.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mit.gov.it/en/comunicazione/news/new-public-procurement-and-concession-contracts-code-has-entered-force|title=The new Public Procurement and Concession Contracts Code has entered into force {{!}} mit|last=|first=|date=2016-04-15|website=www.mit.gov.it|publisher=Italian Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref> In addition to the code, guidelines from the [[National Anti-Corruption Authority (Italy)|National Anti-Corruption Authority]] (Italian: ''Autorità Nazionale AntiCorruzione,'' abbreviated ANAC) and decrees from various ministries also apply to public procurement. Most public procurement on a national level is administered by the state-owned company [[Consip|Consip S.p.A.]] Larger regions have their own agencies for public purchasing.
The five regions with special autonomy ([[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]], [[Sardinia]], [[Sicily]], [[Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol|Trentino-Alto Adige]], [[Aosta Valley|Valle d’Aosta]]) can also establish regional legislation regarding public procurement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/it.pdf|title=Public procurement - Italy Country Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=European Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-06-09}}</ref>
====Latvia==== Government procurement in [[Latvia]] is regulated by the Public Procurement Law, effective 1 March 2017, and the Law on the Procurement of Public Service Providers, which came into effect on 1 April 2017. These laws transpose the EU procurement directives; one additional legal provision is that for supplier selection purposes, [[real estate]] tax debts are checked where tenderers are registered or permanently resident in Latvia. Public procurement opportunities are advertised on the Latvian ''Elektronisko Iepirkumu Sistēma'' (EIS) website.<ref>[https://www.eis.gov.lv/EIS/ Elektronisko Iepirkumu Sistēma], accessed 25 August 2018</ref>
The Procurement Monitoring Office within the [[Government institutions in Latvia#Ministry of Finance|Ministry of Finance]] oversees public procurement.<ref>Gencs Valters Law Firm, [https://baltic-lawfirm.eu/de/service-news/public-procurement-lv.html Public Procurement in Latvia], accessed 25 August 2018</ref> A deposit for filing a review application with the Procurement Monitoring Office must be paid, calculated as 0.5% of the estimated contract value, but no more than €15,000 for construction work contracts or €840 for supply and public service contracts.<ref>Tark Grunte Sutkiene, [http://tgsbaltic.com/news/knowledge/public-procurement-alert-the-new-public-procurement-law-comes-into-force-in-latvia Public Procurement Alert: The new Public Procurement Law Comes Into Force In Latvia], accessed 25 August 2018</ref>
====Luxembourg==== In [[Luxembourg]], the main policy body for public procurement is the Public Procurement Directorate within the Public Works Department of the [[Ministry of Sustainable Development and Infrastructure]] (MDDI). This department is responsible for the regulatory framework, drafting relevant legislation and monitoring its implementation, and also for representing the Luxemburgish authorities in the field of public procurement. A Tender Commission with members drawn from contracting authorities, chambers of commerce and small business sectors undertakes a consultative role in relation to public procurement.<ref>European Commission, [http://ec.europa.eu/regional_policy/sources/policy/how/improving-investment/public-procurement/study/country_profile/lu.pdf Public procurement – Study on administrative capacity in the EU: Luxembourg Country Profile], accessed 4 May 2018</ref>
The EU 2014 Directives on public procurement and utilities procurement were implemented by the Law of 8 April 2018 on public procurement, which was published in the Luxembourg official Gazette (''[[Mémorial|Mémorial: Journal officiel du Grand-Duché de Luxembourg]]'') on 16 April 2018 and entered into force on 20 April 2018.<ref>Elvinger Hoss Luxembourg Law, [https://www.elvingerhoss.lu/publications/new-public-procurement-law New Public Procurement Law], published 26 April 2018, accessed 4 May 2018</ref> Procurement in the defence and security sector is covered by the Law of 26 December 2012.<ref>[http://legilux.public.lu/eli/etat/leg/loi/2012/12/26/n13/jo Loi du 26 décembre 2012 sur les marchés publics de la défense et de la sécurité]</ref>
====Malta==== The EU Directive on public procurement is [[Transposition (law)|transposed]] into [[Law of Malta|Maltese law]] by the Public Procurement Regulations, S.L.174.04, 28 October 2016.<ref>[http://www.justiceservices.gov.mt/DownloadDocument.aspx?app=lom&itemid=9532 Public Procurement Regulations, S.L.174.04, 2016]</ref> These regulations also create the Office of the Director of Contracts (Regulation 10), who is responsible generally for the regulation and administration of public procurement procedures in [[Malta]], a General Contracts Committee, whose members are appointed by the [[Prime Minister of Malta|Prime Minister]] (Regulation 64), a Departmental Contracts Committee for each contracting authority, and in each Ministry a Ministerial Procurement Unit (Regulation 79). Under regulation 80 a Public Contracts Review Board is established. The Commercial Sanctions Tribunal (Regulation 95) is appointed to hear and determine issues relating to the [[blacklisting|black listing]] of persons unsuitable for the award of a public contract or to act as a sub-contractor to a public sector contractor.<ref>Ministry of Finance, [https://mfin.gov.mt/en/The-Ministry/Departments-Directorates-Units/cst/Pages/Commercial-Sanctions-Tribunal.aspx Commercial Sanctions Tribunal], accessed 3 April 2018</ref>
====Netherlands==== The main legislative provisions governing public procurement in the [[Netherlands]] are: *the Public Procurement Act; *the Public Procurement Decree; *the Works Procurement Regulations 2012; *the Procurement Regulations for the Utilities Sectors 2013; *the Proportionality Guide. Sector-specific procurement regulations are also included in the Passenger Transport Act 2000.<ref>The Law Reviews, [https://thelawreviews.co.uk/edition/the-government-procurement-review-edition-4/1136558/netherlands Government Procurement Review - Edition 4: Netherlands]. accessed 14 August 2016</ref> The [[Ministry of Economic Affairs (Netherlands)|Ministry of Economic Affairs]] is responsible for procurement policy.<ref>European Commission, [http://ec.europa.eu/DocsRoom/documents/17261/attachments/6/translations/en/renditions/pdf Netherlands In-Depth Country Report], published 15 June 2016, accessed 14 August 2018</ref>
====Poland==== {{Main|Public procurement law (Poland)}}
====Slovenia==== Public procurement in [[Slovenia]] is overseen by the Public Procurement Directorate within the Ministry of Public Administration.<ref>Ministry of Public Administration, [http://www.mju.gov.si/en/areas_of_work/public_procurement_directorate/ Public Procurement Directorate], accessed 28 August 2018</ref> The Slovenian Public Procurement Act, the ZJN-3, came into force on 1 April 2016, and covers both public sector and utilities procurement, implementing Directives 2014/24/EU and 2014/25/EU in one piece of legislation.<ref>Karanovic Partners, [https://www.karanovicpartners.com/knviews/Pages/2016/03/31/Slovenia-Reforms-Public-Procurement-System.aspx Slovenia Reforms Public Procurement System], published 31 March 2016, accessed 28 August 2018</ref>
====Spain==== [[Spain|Spanish]] Law 30/2007 on public sector contracts (known as the "LCSP") was substantially amended by a new Law 2/2011 on Sustainable Economy ("LES") following an infringement procedure undertaken by the [[European Commission]], which found that the LCSP "gave contracting authorities a wide, almost unlimited, power to modify essential terms of public contracts after award, in a manner which was not in line with the principles of equal treatment between bidders, non-discrimination and transparency set out in EU public procurement rules".<ref>[http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-11-430_en.htm Public procurement: Spain amends its legislation on public sector contracts following infringement procedure], Brussels, IP/11/430, 6 April 2011, accessed 9 September 2016</ref>
====Sweden==== The Swedish Competition Authority is responsible for oversight of government procurement in [[Sweden]], having taken over this role from the Board for Public Procurement ({{lang-sv|Nämnden för offentlig upphandling}}) when it was dissolved in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Konkurrenslagsstiftningens historia|url=http://www.kkv.se/t/Page.aspx?id=709|publisher=The Swedish Competition Authority|accessdate=22 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Konkurrensverket ny tillsynsmyndighet för offentlig upphandling|url=http://www.kkv.se/t/NewsPage.aspx?id=2444|publisher=The Swedish Competition Authority|accessdate=22 July 2014|language=Swedish}}</ref>
====United Kingdom==== Government procurement in the UK is governed by the Public Contracts Regulations 2015, Part 3 of the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015 <ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/26/part/3/enacted Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015, Part 3]</ref> and (in [[Scotland]]) the Public Contracts (Scotland) Regulations 2015 <ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ssi/2015/446/pdfs/ssi_20150446_en.pdf Public Contracts (Scotland) Regulations 2015]</ref> and 2016,<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/sdsi/2016/9780111030868/pdfs/sdsi_9780111030868_en.pdf Public Contracts (Scotland) Regulations 2016]</ref> which implement EU law and also contain rules known as the "Lord Young Rules" promoting access for [[small and medium enterprise]] (SMEs) to public sector contracts, based on [[David Young, Baron Young of Graffham|Lord Young]]'s Review ''Growing Your Business'', published in 2013.<ref name="Lord Young reforms">Local Government Association, [http://lg-procurement.org.uk/pcr-2015/-/journal_content/56/6281932/7638168/ARTICLE 'Lord Young' reforms], accessed 11 September 2016</ref> In November 2016 an advisory panel of 24 entrepreneurs and business figures was formed to advise the government on purchasing goods and services from SMEs, and a campaign was launched to demonstrate that "government is open for business",<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/become-a-supplier Government is open for business], accessed 22 November 2016</ref> with a target of increasing government spending with SMEs to 33% of all third-party public expenditure by 2020.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/news/government-is-open-for-business-new-advisory-panel Government is open for business: new advisory panel], published 15 November 2016, accessed 22 November 2016</ref>
Health commissioners in England are exempt from the Lord Young Rules when procuring [[medicine#Clinical practice|clinical services]] and these rules do not apply in [[Wales]] (i.e. to wholly or mainly devolved functions).<ref name="Lord Young reforms"/>
In Wales, two organisations - the National Procurement Service, established in 2013, and Value Wales - oversee Welsh public sector procurement. The role of Value Wales includes shaping procurement policy, monitoring procurement in practice, supporting, advising and developing procurement staff and ensuring compliance with procurement regulations.<ref>[http://nps.gov.wales/about-us/procurement-in-wales?lang=en Procurement in Wales], accessed 18 September 2016</ref> The Welsh government requires public sector bodies in Wales to include the delivery of social, economic and environmental benefits for the community as an integral consideration in procurement and for this purpose each public body in Wales must appoint a Community Benefits Champion.<ref>Welsh Government, [http://gov.wales/docs/prp/toolkit/june15walesprocurementpolicystatement2015v1.pdf Wales Procurement Policy Statement], revised 9 June 2015, accessed 18 January 2018</ref>
In the light of the economic downturn of 2008 onwards, sometimes referred to as the "[[Great Recession]]", the UK government adopted a series of 10 "procurement for growth" principles intended to ensure that UK government procurement would "take account of [[supply chain]] opportunities for UK companies in policy and delivery planning".<ref>Office of Government Commerce, [http://www.unpcdc.org/media/216410/ogc-the_ten_key_procurement_for_growth_principles.pdf The ten key procurement for growth principles], accessed 24 September 2016</ref>
Part 3 of the Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015 allows the Minister for the [[Cabinet Office]] or relevant [[Secretary of State (United Kingdom)|Secretary of State]] to impose further regulations on public bodies regarding how they undertake procurement.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2015/26/section/39/enacted Small Business, Enterprise and Employment Act 2015, Reg. 39]</ref> The Minister for the Cabinet Office is the minister with overall responsibility for procurement policy, which is delivered through the [[Crown Commercial Service]], an [[executive agency]] sponsored by the Cabinet Office.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/crown-commercial-service Crown Commercial Service], accessed 18 September 2016</ref>
In [[Northern Ireland]] the Central Procurement Directorate within the [[Department of Finance (Northern Ireland)|Department of Finance]] (formerly the Department of Finance and Personnel) is responsible for procurement policy. A revised public procurement policy for Northern Ireland departments, agencies, non-departmental public bodies and public corporations was adopted on 16 May 2002;<ref>[https://www.finance-ni.gov.uk/articles/introduction-ni-public-procurement-policy-document Introduction to the NI Public Procurement Policy document], accessed 19 September 2016</ref> the latest version (version 11) was issued in August 2014.<ref>[https://www.finance-ni.gov.uk/sites/default/files/publications/dfp/ni-public-procurement-policy-version-11-august-2014.pdf Northern Ireland Public Procurement Policy], accessed 19 September 2016</ref> A Concordat on Public Procurement was agreed on 1 June 2001 by the UK Government and the [[Northern Ireland Executive]] for the handling of EU, international and policy issues on public procurement.<ref>[https://www.finance-ni.gov.uk/sites/default/files/publications/dfp/pdf-concordat-on-public-procurement-2001.pdf Concordat on Co-ordination of EU, International and Policy Issues on Public Procurement], accessed 19 September 2016</ref>
The Crown Commercial Service operates a [[Mystery shopping#Public Procurement|Mystery Shopper scheme]], whose remit is to provide a route for [[vendor|suppliers]] to raise concerns about public procurement practice in England,<ref>Crown Commercial Service, [https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/mystery-shopper-scope-and-remit Mystery Shopper: scope and remit], updated 28 January 2016, accessed 15 September 2016</ref> and publishes Procurement Policy Notes from time to time which advise procurement staff in the public sector of government policy developments and best practice in relation to procurement.<ref>Crown Commercial Service, [https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/procurement-policy-notes Procurement Policy Notes]</ref>
General transparency principles applicable to government procurement were published in March 2015 and updated in February 2017, stating that there is a presumption in favour of contractual information being made publicly available (except in matters of commercial confidentiality such as pricing, intellectual property and business plans).<ref>Crown Commercial Service, ''The Transparency of Suppliers and Government to the Public'', PPN 01/17, published February 2017</ref> Tender opportunities advertised by public sector bodies in the UK are legally required to be published to the following sites: * [https://www.gov.uk/contracts-finder Contracts Finder] for England for all tenders and contracts valued over £10,000 for central government and £25,000 for sub-central authorities and the NHS.<ref>[https://www.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/539104/Procurement_Policy_Note___Legal_requirement_to_publish_on_Contracts_Finder__1_.pdf Procurement Policy Note – Legal requirement to publish on Contracts Finder], Action Note 07/16, published 18 July 2016</ref> According to ''OpenOpps'', a tender publishing company, only 27% of all UK public sector tenders were published on Contracts Finder between 2015 and 2017.<ref>Makgill, I., [https://openopps.com/blog/post/51/only-27-of-public-sector-tenders-are-on-contracts-finder/ Only 27% of public sector tenders are on Contracts Finder], published 6 June 2017</ref> * [http://www.publiccontractsscotland.gov.uk/search/search_mainpage.aspx Public Contracts Scotland] for Scotland * [http://www.sell2wales.gov.uk/ Sell2Wales] for Wales * [https://e-sourcingni.bravosolution.co.uk/web/login.shtml eSourcing NI] for Northern Ireland, in use since May 2008.<ref>eSourcing NI, [https://e-sourcingni.bravosolution.co.uk/esop/toolkit/opportunity/opportunityDetail.do?opportunityId=3650&oppList=PAST Project: project_5 - DEL - Skills Monitoring Survey 2008], accessed 2 February 2018</ref>
The Public Contracts Regulations 2015 provide that public sector buyers must pay prime contractors within 30 days and must ensure that any subcontracts through the supply chain include a similar provision. In 2014-15 at least 33 [[NHS trusts]] paid fewer than half of their trade invoices on time, up from 23 in 2015-16 and 11 in 2014-15. Under the Better Payment Practice Code, they should pay at least 95% of non-NHS invoices within 30 days.<ref>{{cite news|title=One in four hospital trusts routinely pay suppliers late|url=https://www.hsj.co.uk/finance-and-efficiency/exclusive-one-in-four-hospital-trusts-routinely-pay-suppliers-late/7021054.article?|accessdate=28 December 2017|publisher=Health Service Journal|date=16 November 2017}}</ref>
Under the draft agreement on the [[Withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union|withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the EU]] it is proposed that procurement procedures commenced under the EU regulations before the end of the transitional period should continue to be governed by the relevant regulations up to the issue of a contract award notice.<ref>European Commission, [https://ec.europa.eu/commission/sites/beta-political/files/draft_withdrawal_agreement.pdf Draft Withdrawal Agreement on the withdrawal of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland from the European Union and the European Atomic Energy Community], TF50 (2018) 33 – Commission to EU 27, 28 February 2018, accessed 31 March 2018</ref> If there is no agreement with the EU following withdrawal, the government has stated that it will establish "a UK-specific e-notification service" as a replacement. Contracting authorities and entities would be expected to ensure that their contract notices are published on the new e-notification service as well as the relevant site listed above.<ref>Cabinet Office, [https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/accessing-public-sector-contracts-if-theres-no-brexit-deal/accessing-public-sector-contracts-if-theres-no-brexit-deal Accessing public sector contracts if there’s no Brexit deal], published 13 September 2018, accessed 29 September 2018</ref>
===Fiji=== The [[Fiji]] Procurement Office was established under Section 4 of the Fiji Procurement Regulations 2010 <ref name=FijiRegs>Procurement Regulations 2010 (www.finance.gov.fj/legislation.html?download=199)</ref> and commenced operations on 1 August 2010. The establishment of the Office and the new Fiji Procurement Regulations were a direct result of the re-organisation of the Government Supplies Department by the [[Government of Fiji|Fijian government]]. The main functions of the Fiji Procurement Office are to regulate and administer the procurement of goods, service and works for the government.<ref>Ministry of Economy, [http://www.economy.gov.fj/sections/fiji-procurement-office.html Fiji Procurement Office], accessed 28 February 2018</ref> The Government Tender Board is "constituted with authority to approve all procurement of goods, services and works valued at [[Fijian dollar|FJ$]]30,001 and more".<ref name=FijiRegs />
===Ghana=== Public procurement in [[Ghana]] is undertaken and overseen by the Public Procurement Authority of Ghana.<ref>[http://www.ppaghana.org/default.asp Public Procurement Authority of Ghana]</ref> The Public Procurement Board is the central body for policy formulation on procurement. The existing Public Procurement Act 2003 (Act 663) was amended by the Public Procurement (Amendment) Act 2016 (Act 914), which came into effect on 1 July 2016.<ref>[http://www.ppaghana.org/Public-Notice-Amendment-PD.pdf Public Notice: Passage of the Public Procurement (Amendment) Act 2016 (Act 914)], accessed 15 September 2016</ref>
===Guernsey=== Public procurement opportunities in [[Guernsey]] are advertised on the Channel Islands Procurement Portal, which was launched in April 2008 and is shared with [[Jersey, Channel Islands|Jersey]].<ref name=CIPP>[http://www.channelislandtenders.com/ Channel Islands Procurement Portal], accessed 30 January 2018</ref>
===Guyana=== Public procurement in [[Guyana]] is overseen by the Public Procurement Commission,<ref>[https://ppc.org.gy/ Public Procurement Commission]</ref> appointed under the Public Procurement Commission Act 2003. Due to lengthy delay in identifying and agreeing commission members, the commission was not appointed until 2016.<ref>[https://www.cips.org/supply-management/news/2016/august/guyana-hands-procurement-to-commission/ After 14 years, Guyana establishes procurement commission], "Supply Management", 12 August 2016, accessed 1 October 2016</ref> The PPC is based in the Queenstown area of [[Georgetown, Guyana|Georgetown]].<ref>Public Procurement Commission, [https://ppc.org.gy/contact/ Contact], accessed 16 October 2018</ref> The National Procurement and Tender Administration of Guyana (NPTA), established under section 16(1) of the Procurement Act 2003, undertakes administrative processes for high value governmental tenders.<ref>National Procurement and Tender Administration, [http://www.npta.gov.gy/npta.html About the NPTA], accessed 16 October 2018</ref>
===Iceland=== Act No. 84/2007 on Public Procurement (2007) has three objectives: *to ensure the equal treatment of companies during public procurement *to encourage efficiency in public operations through active competition and *to promote innovation and development in the public procurement of goods, labour and services.<ref>[https://eng.fjarmalaraduneyti.is/media/skjal/Act_nr_84_2007_on_Public_Procurement_28102013.pdf Act No. 84/2007 on Public Procurement, Article 1]</ref> The law applies to "the [[Government of Iceland|Icelandic State]], [[Politics of Iceland#Administrative divisions|local authorities]], their institutions and other public entities" and to "associations formed by one or more of such authorities".<ref>[https://eng.fjarmalaraduneyti.is/media/skjal/Act_nr_84_2007_on_Public_Procurement_28102013.pdf Act No. 84/2007 on Public Procurement, Article 3]</ref> An independent Public Procurement Complaints Commission has power to investigate complaints and may declare a contract "ineffective" if its award was not compliant with the legislation.<ref>[https://eng.fjarmalaraduneyti.is/media/skjal/Act_nr_84_2007_on_Public_Procurement_28102013.pdf Act No. 84/2007 on Public Procurement, Articles 91-100]</ref>
===Isle of Man=== The [[Isle of Man]] [[Government of the Isle of Man|government]] promotes competition in procurement under the ''Council of Ministers’ Procurement Policy for Government'' published in 2017.<ref>[https://www.gov.im/media/1358209/iom-government-procurement-policy-2017.pdf Isle of Man Government Procurement Policy], accessed 18 January 2018</ref>
===Israel=== In [[Israel]], the Mandatory Tenders Law of 12 March 1992, 5752-1992 (as amended), governs [[Government of Israel|government]] procurement procedures. Oversight of the legislation lies with the [[Ministry of Finance (Israel)|Ministry of Finance]] in conjunction with the [[Knesset]] Constitution, Law and Justice Committee. The government may, with the approval of the Knesset [[Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee]], direct that a state or a government corporation may not enter into a contract with a particular foreign country or with a particular foreign supplier for reasons of [[Foreign policy of Israel|foreign policy]].<ref>[https://www.mr.gov.il/Information/Training%20materials/Mandatory%20Tenders%20Law.pdf Mandatory Tenders Law, 5752-1992: Complete up-to-date version], accessed 11 March 2018</ref>
===Jamaica=== The [[Government of Jamaica]] Procurement Guidelines apply to government procurement in [[Jamaica]],<ref>Ministry of Justice, [http://moj.gov.jm/procurement-and-office-services Procurement and Office Services], accessed 21 August 2018</ref> and the Public Sector Procurement Policy of November 2010 reflects "the government’s ... strategy to further reform the public procurement system that is aligned to international best practices and promote fair competition for government contracts".<ref name=Jam-policy>Ministry of Finance and the Public Service, [http://www.ncc.gov.jm/website_files/gpphandbook_ver4/procurement_policy-101230.pdf Public Sector Procurement Policy, November 2010], accessed 23 August 2018</ref>
Until 1996, Jamaica operated a centralised procurement system coordinated by the Central Supply Division of the Ministry of Finance, and procurement activity was regulated by the Financial Administration (Supplies) Regulations 1963 supplemented by directives from the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry of Finance and the Public Service is now responsible for oversight of procurement policy. A Procurement Policy Implementation Unit was established within the Ministry of Finance in September 1999.<ref name=Jam-policy />
The Office of the Contractor-General (OCG), based in [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]], was established in 1983 under the Contractor General Act of that year.<ref>[http://ocg.gov.jm/ocg/ Office of the Contractor-General], accessed 21 August 2018.</ref>The Contractor General is appointed by the [[Governor-General of Jamaica|Governor General]]. In December 2008, three members of the procurement committee of the [[Jamaica Urban Transit Company]] resigned following reports of procurement breaches identified by the Contractor-General, Greg Christie.<ref>Brown, G., [http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/news/html/20081205t160000-0500_143402_obs_jutc_fallout.asp Jamaica Urban Transit Company (JUTC) fallout], [[Jamaica Observer]], 6 December 2008</ref>
The National Contracts Commission (NCC) was established in October 1999.<ref name=Jam-policy /> Members of the NCC are also appointed by the Governor-General.<ref>[http://ocg.gov.jm/ocg/sites/default/files/The%20Laws%20%20Jamaica%20-%20CG%20ACT.pdf Contractor-General Act, section 23B and Schedule 3]</ref>
===Jersey=== The [[States of Jersey]]'s procurement opportunities are advertised on the Channel Islands Procurement Portal, which was launched in April 2008 and is shared with [[Guernsey]].<ref name=CIPP/>
===Kenya=== {{Main|Public procurement in Kenya}} Public procurement in [[Kenya]] is governed by the Public Procurement and Asset Disposal Act 2015.
===Laos=== Public procurement in the [[Lao People's Democratic Republic]] is governed by the [[Prime Minister of Laos|Prime Minister]]'s Decree on Procurement of Goods, Works, Maintenance and Services No. 03/PM, dated 9 January 2004, and the Implementing Rules and Regulations on Government Procurement of Goods, Works, Maintenance and Services No. 063/PM, dated 12 March 2004. <ref name=Laos>United Nations, [http://unpan1.un.org/intradoc/groups/public/documents/un-dpadm/unpan041909.pdf E-Governmental Procurement in Lao PDR], accessed 23 September 2018</ref> Amendments were made to some of the articles of the Implementing Rules and the Decree by Update 0861/MOF of 5 May 2009.<ref>Ministry of Public Works and Transport, [https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/project-documents//45041-002-pp-en.pdf Vientiane Sustainable Urban Transport Project: Procurement Plan], published 10 March 2018, accessed 23 September 2018</ref> Procurement activities are overseen by the Procurement Monitoring Office (PrMO) within the Ministry of Finance.<ref name=Laos />
===Liberia=== Government procurement in [[Liberia]] is governed by the Public Procurement Act. The Public Procurement and Concessions Commission (PPCC) was established in 2005 to "regulate all forms of Public Procurement and Concessions and provide for institutional structures for public procurement and concessions".<ref name=PPCCFAQ>Public Procurement and Concessions Commission, [http://ppcc.gov.lr/2content.php?sub=67&related=1&third=67&pg=sp Frequently Asked Questions about PPCC], accessed 29 April 2018</ref> The PPCC operates an online Vendors' Register.<ref>[http://ppcc.gov.lr/vr/ PPCC eProcurement Platform: Vendors Register]</ref>
Procurement is decentralised, but the [[Ministry of Finance, Liberia|Ministry of Finance]] is required "to take part in the negotiations and signing of contracts over US $250,000" and such contracts must "be attested to by the Ministry of Justice".<ref name=PPCCFAQ />
===Maldives=== Government procurement in the [[Maldives]] is subject to the Public Finance Law (Law No. 3/2006) and chapter 10 of the Public Finance Regulation. The approval of the National Tender Board is required before contracts in excess of [[Maldivian rufiyaa|MVR]] 2.5m can be awarded.<ref>World Bank, [http://pubdocs.worldbank.org/en/285821490813157571/e-GP-in-South-Asia-achievements-Maldives.pdf Public Procurement in the Maldives], accessed 26 April 2018</ref>
===Mexico=== Public procurement is included in Article 134 of the [[Mexican Constitution]]. Article 134 is implemented by the Law of Public Sector Acquisitions, Leasing and Services ("Acquisition Law") and the Law of Public Works and Related Services ("Public Work Law"). At a local level, each of the 31 [[States of Mexico|states]] and the [[Federal District (Mexico)|Federal District]] has different public procurement laws.<ref>European Commission, [http://madb.europa.eu/madb/barriers_details.htm?isSps=false&barrier_id=10184 Market Access Database - Mexico], published (updates) 21 February 2017, accessed 22 April 2018</ref>
===Mozambique=== Decree no. 5/2016, ''Public Procurement Regulations'' governs public procurement in [[Mozambique]].<ref>International Comparative Legal Guides, [https://iclg.com/practice-areas/public-procurement-laws-and-regulations/mozambique Public Procurement 2018: Mozambique], accessed 6 August 2018</ref>
===New Zealand=== The [[New Zealand]] Government Procurement Branch of the [[Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment]] is responsible for the Government Procurement Rules, Government Rules of Sourcing <ref name=sour>[https://www.procurement.govt.nz/procurement/principles-and-rules/government-rules-of-sourcing/ Government Rules of Sourcing], accessed 20 April 2018</ref> and Principles of Government Procurement.<ref>[http://www.nzlii.org/nz/legis/bill/owofb2016281.pdf Our Work Our Future Bill]</ref> The aim of the Government Rules of Sourcing is to "support good practice for procurement planning, approaching the supplier community and contracting".<ref name=sour /> The 66 rules were initially introduced in 2013. The principles apply to all governmental procurement activity but the rules only apply to projects or purchases exceeding $100,000 or construction projects valued over $10 million.<ref name=sour />
Purchasers of certain common goods or services are required to use "All-of-Government contracts" (AoG) established by the Government Procurement Branch, overseen by the Procurement Functional Leader and managed by appointed procurement Centres of Expertise. Where a public agency wishes to opt out of the use of an AoG contract it must obtain the approval of approval the Procurement Functional Leader: if the agency and the Procurement Functional Leader fail to agree on an opt-out, the [[State Services Commissioner]] will decide.<ref>[https://www.procurement.govt.nz/procurement/principles-and-rules/government-rules-of-sourcing/other-rules-you-need-to-know/rule-55/ Rule 55: All-of-Government contracts], accessed 3 November 2018</ref>
===Peru=== [[Peru]]vian public procurement law was formerly set out in the Government Procurement Act (approved by Legislative Decree No. 1017) and the Regulation of the Government Procurement Act (approved by Supreme Decree No. 184-2008-EF), which were replaced by a new Government Procurement Act (Law N° 30225) in 2014.<ref>OECD Competition Committee,[https://www.indecopi.gob.pe/documents/20182/198224/WP3-1_law_and_government.pdf Laws and Government Procurement Practices in Peru], Report to Council on the Bid-Rigging Recommendation, Contribution from Peru elaborated by Jean Sanchez and Yamilet Gallardo, members of the Economic Studies Management of ''Indecopi'', the National Institute for the Defense of Free Competition and the Protection of Intellectual Property, accessed 24 March 2018</ref><ref>Indecopi, [https://www.indecopi.gob.pe/web/indecopi_ingles/sobre-el-indecopi About Indecopi]</ref> Peruvian [[President of Peru|President]] [[Pedro Pablo Kuczynski]] resigned on 21 March 2018 following allegations that public works contracts had been [[Corruption in Peru|corruptly]] awarded to [[Brazil]]ian conglomerate [[Odebrecht]].<ref>Rochabrun, M. and Casey, N., [https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/21/world/americas/peru-kuczynski-resigns.html Peru’s President Offers Resignation Over Vote-Buying Scandal], New York Times, 21 March 2018, accessed 24 March 2018</ref>
===Russia=== {{Main|Government procurement in Russia}} [[Russia]]n Federal Law N44-ФЗ of 05.04.2013 require all federal, regional and municipal government customers to publish all information about government tenders, auctions and other purchase procedures on special public government websites.
===Rwanda=== In [[Rwanda]], the public procurement process is managed on daily basis by an autonomous organ, the Rwanda Public Procurement Authority (RPPA),<ref>Law N°25/2011 of 30/06/2011 establishing the Rwanda Public Procurement Authority (RPPA) and determining its mission, organization and Functioning</ref> which operates under the Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning (MINECOFIN). Public procurement is regulated by the Law N°12/2007 of 27/03/2007 on public procurement <ref>Published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Rwanda, N°8 of 15/04/2007</ref> which was modified and complemented by the Law N°05/20013 of 13/02/2013.<ref>Published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Rwanda, N°16 of 22/04/2013</ref> The law is implemented by a Ministerial Order N°001/14/10/TC of 19/02/2014 establishing Regulations on Public Procurement, Standard Bidding Documents and Standard Contracts.<ref>Published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Rwanda, N°10 of 10/03/2014</ref>
Rwanda has a decentralized public procurement system whereby procuring entities (central government organs, local government entities, government projects, commissions, public institutions, parastatals, agencies or any other government entity charged by the Chief Budget Manager to manage public funds) have the power to conduct directly their public procurement process. The main mission of RPPA is (1) to process the establishment and improvement of public procurement legal framework, (2) provide public procurement legal advisory services, (3) conduct audit and monitoring of public procurement activities carried out by procuring entities(tender award and contract management) and (4) build the capacity of public officials involved in public procurement activities.<ref>[http://www.rppa.gov.rw Rwanda Public Procurement Authority]</ref>
The public procurement system in Rwanda is governed by 6 fundamental principles namely (1) transparency, (2) competition,(3) economy, (4) efficiency, (5) fairness and (6) accountability.<ref>Article 4 of the Law N°12/2007 of 27/03/2207 on public procurement as modified and complemented to date</ref> In the national system, bidders have the right to appeal against public procurement procedures they may think were not conducted appropriately. In that connection, the legal framework provides for the Independent Review Panels at National Level (National Independent Review Panel) and at District Level (Independent Review Panel at District Level).<ref>Article 14 of the Law N°05/2013 OF 13/02/2013 modifying and complementing the Law N°12/2007 of 27/03/2007 on public procurement</ref> The Independent Review Panels are composed of members from the Private Sector, Civil Society and the Public Sector, and the members from the Public Sector cannot form the majority of members of the Panel. The Independent Review Panel at National Level is under the supervision of the Minister of Finance and Economic Planning whereas the Independent Review Panel at District Level is under the supervision of the District Council.
In order to make the procurement sector a profession in Rwanda, there is an Association of Procurement Professionals which was established by the Law N°011/2016 of 02/05/2016.<ref>Published in the Official Gazette of the Republic of Rwanda, N°21 of 23/05/2016</ref>
Rwanda introduced an e-procurement system in 2016. For more information about Rwanda's e-procurement system please visit [http://www.umucyo.gov.rw www.umucyo.gov.rw]; for more information about public procurement in Rwanda in general, please visit [http://www.rppa.gov.rw www.rppa.gov.rw].
===Singapore=== {{See also|GeBIZ}} [[Singapore]]'s [[Ministry of Finance (Singapore)|Ministry of Finance]] is responsible for the Government Procurement policy framework, which governs how government agencies undertake their procurement.<ref name=Singapore>Ministry of Finance, [https://www.mof.gov.sg/Policies/Government-Procurement Government Procurement], accessed 16 April 2018</ref> In 2014, the [[Public Accounts Committee]] of the [[Parliament of Singapore]] criticised the state of government procurement in Singapore, identifying a number of irregularities in procurement procedures including: *weak rationales invoked when waiving competitive processes; *allowing some bidders to amend their tenders after tenders had closed; *not disclosing evaluation criteria to bidders within tender documentation; *improper procedures for tender evaluation; *lax oversight and monitoring of outsourced projects.<ref>Green, W., [https://www.cips.org/en-GB/Supply-Management/News/2014/April/Public-procurement-in-Singapore-prone-to-lapses/ Public procurement in Singapore ‘prone to lapses’], ''Supply Management'', 15 April 2014, accessed 7 April 2018</ref>
[[GeBIZ]] is a [[Government-to-business]] (G2B) [[Public eProcurement]] business centre where suppliers can conduct [[electronic commerce]] with the [[Singapore]]an Government. All of the public sector's invitations for quotations and tenders (except for security-sensitive contracts) are posted on GeBIZ.<ref name=Singapore /> Suppliers can search for government procurement opportunities, retrieve relevant procurement documentations and submit their bids online.
===South Africa=== Section 217 of the [[Constitution of South Africa|Constitution]] of the [[Republic of South Africa]], 1996 (Act 108 of 1996) provides the basis for government procurement: :''When an organ of state in the national, provincial or local sphere of Government, or any other institution identified in national legislation, contracts for goods or services, it must do so in accordance with a system which is fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost effective.''
The Public Finance Management Act 1999 also refers to the duty of the Accounting Officer of a Department to have and to maintain an appropriate procurement and supply system which is "fair, equitable, transparent, competitive and cost effective".<ref name=KwaZuluNatal>KwaZulu Natal Provincial Treasury, [http://www.kzncomsafety.gov.za/LinkClick.aspx?link=Documents%2fSCM%2fSCM+03-2006+-+8-2-06+-+Guide+for+Bid+Committees.pdf&tabid=223&mid=605 Guideline for Bid Committee Members: Practice Note Number: SCM-03 of 2006], 22 February 2006, accessed 4 December 2017</ref>
===Ukraine=== The [[Ministry of Economic Development and Trade (Ukraine)]] is an executive authority in charge of coordination of procurement of goods, works and services for public funds.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://tender.me.gov.ua/EDZFrontOffice/menu/en/|website=tender.me.gov.ua|title=Web Portal on Public Procurement of Ukraine}}</ref> The Law “On public procurement” is one of the core legislative bases of the procurement regulations. It made electronic public procurement procedures and use of e-procurement system [[Prozorro]] mandatory for all procuring entities after August 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ukraine.nlembassy.org/binaries/content/assets/postenweb/o/oekraine/netherlands-embassy-in-kiev/import/the_embassy/departments/economic_department/pp-roadmap-ukraine_jeantet_220316.pdf|website=ukraine.nlembassy.org|title=Public Procurement Roadmap - Ukraine}}</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== Federal government procurement within the [[United Arab Emirates]] is governed by ''Cabinet Resolution No. 32 of 2014 on Federal Government Procurement Regulation and Storehouse Management in Federal Government'', which applies to all supply, works and services purchasing undertaken by the federal government and the federal ministries and governmental agencies (except the Ministry of Defence), and also to independent federal entities such as the General Authority for Civil Aviation, Emirates Real Estate Corporation, FEWA, ESCA, Insurance Authority, Emirates Post Group Holding, National Transport Authority, Telecommunications Regulatory Authority, [[UAE University]] and [[Zayed University]].<ref name=Lysenko>Lysenko, V., [http://www.hadefpartners.com/News/7/NEW-FEDERAL-PROCUREMENT-AND-WAREHOUSE-MANAGEMENT-REGULATION New federal procurement and warehouse regulation], Hadef and Partners, published 26 November 2014, accessed 2 July 2018</ref> UAE Federal Decree No. 12 of the Deputy Supreme Commander of the Armed Forces (1986) applies to armed forces procurement.<ref>AP Consulting, [http://mideastlaw.com/middle_eastern_laws_uae.html Doing Business in the U.A.E.], accessed 29 August 2018</ref>
Conditional preferential treatment is afforded under Resolution 32 to corporate suppliers whose capital does not exceed [[United Arab Emirates dirham|AED]] 10 million and in which the UAE national [[Shareholder|shareholding]] is not less than 51%, and to facilities which are financed by SMEs-supporting funds and governed by federal or local law.<ref name=Lysenko />
===United States=== {{Main|Government procurement in the United States}} Government procurement by public authorities in the United States accounts for about USD 7 trillion annually.<ref name="Prieß: Global Overview" /> Federal procurement is governed by the [[Federal Acquisition Regulation]]. FedBizOpps <ref>[https://www.fbo.gov/ FedBizOpps.gov]</ref> and USASpending.gov are websites where federal contracts are shown. Public announcements of awards has several exemptions, including contracts less than $3.5 million.<ref>[http://sunlightfoundation.com/blog/2013/05/17/update-on-fedbizopps-data/ Update on FedBizOpps data]. Sunlight Foundation.</ref> Historically, the procurement data has been criticized for deficiencies leading to a number of reforms.<ref name=Halchin2013>Halchin LE. (2013). [http://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/misc/R43111.pdf Transforming Government Acquisition Systems: Overview and Selected Issues]. Congressional Research Service.</ref> In 2013, eight legacy databases were merged into a single system called "[[System for Award Management]]" (SAM), where companies interested in doing business with the federal government may register their interest.<ref>General Services Administration, [https://www.sam.gov/portal/SAM/#1 System for Award Management]</ref>
Contracts are not posted online, although two agencies have explored the possibility.<ref name=Halchin2013/>
In January 2014, the [[Office of Inspector General (United States)|Office of Inspector General]] at [[NASA]] released a report criticizing the agency's lack of strategic sourcing.<ref>{{cite web|last=Martin|first=Paul|title=NASA's Strategic Sourcing Program|url=http://oig.nasa.gov/audits/reports/FY14/IG-14-010.pdf|publisher=NASA Office of Audits|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref> Because IT departments were spending autonomously, NASA spent $25.7 million on similar purchases.<ref>{{cite web|last=Busch|first=Jason|title=NASA, or Need Another Sourcing Act: IT Security Spending Horror Stories|url=http://spendmatters.com/2014/03/04/nasa-need-another-sourcing-act-security-spending-horror-stories/|publisher=Spend Matters|accessdate=5 March 2014}}</ref>
The National Institute of Governmental Purchasing and the [[Federal Acquisition Institute]] are active in procurement certification and training. A specialized program in procurement law in the United States is located at [[The George Washington University Law School]].
===Vatican City=== Purchasing is overseen by the [[Secretariat for the Economy (Holy See)|Secretariat for the Economy]], which is responsible for setting purchasing policies and procedures, while responsibility for expenditure is devolved to individual [[Dicastery|dicasteries]] and administrations.<ref>Holy See Press Office, [http://visnews-en.blogspot.com/2014/07/new-economic-framework-for-holy-see.html New Economic Framework for the Holy See], published 9 July 2014, accessed 2 June 2018</ref>
===Zambia=== Public procurement in [[Zambia]] is governed by the Public Procurement Act No. 12 of 2008 and the Public Procurement Regulations of 2011. Prior to 2008, public procurement was governed by the Zambia National Tender Board Act, Act No. 30 of 1982.<ref>[http://www.csprzambia.org/images/documents/CSOProcurementMonitoring.pdf Public Procurement System in Zambia], accessed 11 January 2017</ref>
===Zimbabwe=== [[Zimbabwe]] established a public procurement law in 1999.<ref>World Bank, [http://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2015/05/13/zimbabwe-begins-public-procurement-modernization Zimbabwe Begins Public Procurement Modernization], 13 May 2015, accessed 19 September 2016</ref> The Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Act, 2017 repealed the Procurement Act of 1999 and abolished the State Procurement Board.<ref name=ZAct2017>[[Free Access to Law Movement|Zimbabwe Legal Information Institute]], [https://www.zimlii.org/zw/legislation/act/2017/5 Public Procurement and Disposal of Public Assets Act (Chapter 22:23)]</ref> On 9 January 2018, President [[Emmerson Mnangagwa]] appointed an eight-member Procurement Regulatory Authority of Zimbabwe which replaced the Board.<ref>Republic of Ghana Public Procurement Authority, [http://www.ppaghana.org/Documents/Bulletins/PPAE-Bulletin_JanFeb_2018.pdf?story_id=1278 Electronic Vol. 9, Issue 1 Bulletin Jan — Feb 2018], accessed 22 February 2018</ref> The legislation incorporates a "domestic preference" section empowering procuring entities to "give preference to bids from Zimbabwean or local suppliers and manufacturers" and provides for a Special Procurement Oversight Committee to be established to oversee "certain especially sensitive or especially valuable contracts".<ref name=ZAct2017 />
==See also== *[[Best value procurement]] *[[Contract awarding]] *[[Open Contracting Data Standard]] *[[Public eProcurement]] *[[Standstill period]] *{{cite book|editor-last=Prieß|editor-first=Hans-Joachim|title=Public Procurement 2012: An overview of regulation in 40 jurisdictions worldwide|year=2012|edition= 8.|issn=1747-5910|publisher=Getting the Deal Through}}
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''Hotel Elysée''' is a [[New York City]] hotel situated on 60 East [[54th Street (Manhattan)|54th Street]] between [[Madison Avenue|Madison]] and [[Park Avenue]]<nowiki/>s. The hotel was founded in 1926 as a [[Europe]]an-style hotel for the carriage trade by [[Swiss people|Swiss]]-born Max Haering.
==History== Hotel Elysée was founded in 1926 as a [[Europe]]an-style hotel for the carriage trade by [[Swiss people|Swiss]]-born [[Max Haering]].<ref>{{Citation |author=Jean Nathan |publication-date=December 18, 1994 |title=Monkey Business |work= [[New York Times]] |page=662 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/12/18/magazine/monkey-business.html |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref> New York's leading hatcheck concessionaire, Mayer Quain, purchased the hotel out of bankruptcy in 1937. After the War, his children eclectically designed every room so that no two rooms were alike. In lieu of traditional numbers, the rooms were named to reflect their personality, such as the "Sayonara" suite assigned to [[Marlon Brando]] after his starring role in ''Teahouse of the August Moon''. [[Tennessee Williams]] lived in the hotel for fifteen years and died in the "Sunset" suite.
Columnist [[Jimmy Breslin]], who regards the Elysée as "a great hotel, a genuine New York landmark," succeeded Ruark as the hotel's unofficial chronicler. Upon Tennessee Williams's death at the Elysée in February 1983, Breslin recalled the story of a transient guest who called the front desk at 5:00 am complaining that someone in the next suite was keeping her awake by typing all night. "They knew right away who the culprit was, but they couldn't very well ask Mr. Williams to stop playwriting, so we simply moved the guest to another room."
In November 1948, Tallulah Bankhead celebrated President [[Harry S. Truman]]'s stunning victory over [[Thomas E. Dewey]] by throwing a noisy party at the hotel that ran non-stop for five days and nights.
==The Monkey Bar== The Elysée is known for the Monkey Bar, a [[piano bar]] just off the lobby. Opened in the 1940s, it became known to the cognoscenti as "the place to go where jokes die," especially off-color jokes and double-entendre songs spun by such performers as [[Johnny Payne (musician)|Johnny Payne]] (1934-1964), Marion Page (1950-1965) and [[Mel Martin]] (1945-1983). Johnny Andrews played the piano at cocktail hour for over 50 years (1936-1990).
Starting out as just another dimly lit hotel piano bar with mirrored paneling, the tiny room was expanded in the early 1950s when the mirrors were replaced by wraparound hand-painted [[mural]] by [[caricaturist]] Charlie Vella . Eight more monkeys were added to the bar mural in 1984 by artist Diana Voyentzie "to remind customers of their behaviour."<ref>{{Citation |author=Elizabeth Quinn Brown |publication-date=August 2013 |title=New York's Narrative |work= [[Quest (lifestyle magazine)|Quest]] |page=141 |url=http://issuu.com/questmag/docs/quest_aug2013 |accessdate=January 8, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Citation |publication-date=2013 |title=Mizner Palm Beach Bricktops |work =dianevoyentziemonkeys.com|url=http://dianevoyentziemonkeys.com/aboutthemonkeys.html |accessdate= January 8, 2014}}</ref> In 1995, when the bar was redesigned by the architect David Rockwell, all of the monkeys were unified by Voyentzie with more monkeys and palm trees and foliage. The monkeys in the mural depict decidedly human features riding [[elephant]]s, crouching under a Christmas tree, mixing up [[banana daiquiri]]s for tough-looking monkey-like customers, etc. In successive years, other artists have added to the tableau.

{{Infobox person | name = Héctor Horacio Magnetto | image = Héctor Magnetto 1978-07-31 (cropped).jpg | caption = Magnetto in 1978 | image_size = 160px | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1944|7|9}} | birth_place = [[Chivilcoy]], [[Buenos Aires Province]] | nationality = Argentine | occupation = [[CEO]], [[Grupo Clarín]] | networth = | alma_mater = [[University of La Plata]] | spouse = | children = | residence = [[Buenos Aires]] | salary = }}
'''Héctor Horacio Magnetto''' (born July 9, 1944) is an Argentine executive [[CEO]] of the [[Grupo Clarín|Clarín Group]], the country's largest media company.
==Life and career== Magnetto was born in [[Chivilcoy]] in 1944, and enrolled at the [[University of La Plata]], where he earned a degree in [[accountancy]] with high honors.<ref name=clarin>[http://www.grupoclarin.com/content/dir_magnetto_01.html Grupo Clarín: Héctor Magnetto] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608070940/http://www.grupoclarin.com/content/dir_magnetto_01.html# |date=2011-06-08 }} {{es icon}}</ref> He became affiliated with the pro-industry political party, the [[Integration and Development Movement]] (MID), and on March 2, 1972, was hired as an advisor to [[Ernestina Herrera de Noble]], the director and majority owner of ''[[Clarín (Argentine newspaper)|Clarín]]'', the most widely circulated newspaper in Latin America.<ref name=funding>[http://www.fundinguniverse.com/company-histories/Grupo-Clariacute;n-SA-Company-History.html Funding Universe: Grupo Clarín]</ref> Despite its large circulation, ''Clarín'' suffered financial difficulties when Mrs. Noble inherited the director's post from its founder, [[Roberto Noble]], as his widow. She turned to one of the latter's most prominent allies, economist and wholesaler [[Rogelio Julio Frigerio]], who lent ''Clarín'' US$10 million in 1971. The paper continued to endorse Frigerio's centrist MID platform, which centered on government support for infrastructure investment and [[import substitution industrialization]]. On Frigerio's advice, Mrs. Noble brought in Magnetto, who took later charge of the newspaper's finances.<ref name=funding/>
The young accountant persuaded Mrs. Noble to shed superfluous assets, such as a company helicopter, and to begin negotiations with the Mitre, Paz, and Peralta Ramos families (owners of ''[[La Nación (Buenos Aires)|La Nación]]'', ''[[La Prensa (Buenos Aires)|La Prensa]]'' and ''[[La Razón (Buenos Aires)|La Razón]]'', respectively) to take part in a federally sponsored establishment of a [[newsprint]] manufacturer. The plan, which would cut costs by eliminating the need for imported newsprint, ultimately resulted in the inaugural of the ''[[Papel Prensa]]'' newsprint facility in 1978.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1007629 ''La Nación'': Más que un hombre de negocios] {{es icon}}</ref>
Magnetto served as CEO of Papel Prensa, on an alternating basis with the director of ''La Nación'', during subsequent years. He displaced most of his fellow MID-oriented colleagues at the newspaper in 1981, and afterwards became President and CEO.<ref>[http://artepolitica.com/comunidad/jorge-asis-sobre-clarin/ Arte Política: Jorge Asís sobre Clarín] {{es icon}}</ref> Keen to political trends, Magnetto spearheaded Clarín's vocal opposition to the administration of the populist-turned-conservative President, [[Carlos Menem]], after the latter's re-election in 1995. He nevertheless maintained cordial relations with the runner-up of that campaign, [[Justicialist Party]] Governor [[Eduardo Duhalde]], who was appointed President by the [[Argentine Congress]] following the [[December 2001 riots in Argentina]] that led to his predecessor's ([[Fernando De la Rua]]) resignation. Magnetto was able to parlay this understanding into Duhalde's support for a "Law of Preservation of Cultural Patrimony," which limited foreign ownership of local media to 30%, and thus protected the Clarín Group's core businesses. The group had suffered steep losses during the [[Argentine economic crisis|1999-2002 crisis]], and the bill (passed in July 2003, and dubbed the "Clarín Law" by detractors), helped solidify its finances.<ref name=que>[http://www.queescomunicacion.com.ar/Noticias/NoticiaMuestra.asp?Id=1386 ''Qué es Comunicación'': Radiocomunicación o teledifusión] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025173546/http://www.queescomunicacion.com.ar/Noticias/NoticiaMuestra.asp?Id=1386# |date=2008-10-25 }} {{es icon}}</ref>
The company recovered alongside the [[Argentine economy]] in subsequent years, and by 2006, had acquired Cablevisión, its Multicanal cable unit's leading competitor.<ref name=que/> Magnetto, however, was beset by worsening health problems, chief among them a dignosis of [[esophageal cancer]] in early 2007, which for a time led to speculation as to his continuity as CEO of the Clarín group, as well as to a possible dispute over his 30% share in the company. Magnetto reacted positively to treatment, and underwent subsequent [[speech therapy]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revista-noticias.com.ar/comun/nota.php?art=406&ed=1587|title=La enfermedad que sacude al poder|publisher=''Noticias''}}</ref>
He was on hand for the October 22, 2007, Clarín [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] in the [[Buenos Aires Stock Exchange]], and continued to preside over the group.<ref>[http://www.clarin.com/diario/2007/10/22/um/m-01524573.htm ''Clarín'' (22 Oct 2007)] {{es icon}}</ref> Former President [[Néstor Kirchner]] alleged that, during the [[2008 Argentine government conflict with the agricultural sector]], Magnetto offered a supportive spin on the administration's case for higher export [[tariff]]s, in exchange for an amenable treatment of the media group's acquisition of a significant stake in [[Telecom Argentina]] (a potential [[anti-trust law]] violation); the hitherto cordial relations between [[Kirchnerism]] and the Clarín Group [[Controversies between Clarín and Kirchnerism|soured during the conflict]].<ref>[http://www.tradingmarkets.com/news/stock-alert/grcnl_-argentina-ex-president-clarin-offered-spin-for-telephone-co-725534.html Trading Markets: Argentina Ex-President: Clarín Offered Spin For Telephone Co]{{dead link|date=November 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Subsequently, Magnetto was one of 200 individuals investigated by the government for [[money laundering]], mainly related to [[tax evasion]].<ref>[http://www.criticadigital.com/index.php?secc=nota&nid=21260 ''Crítica de la Argentina'': Los 200 investigados por lavado de dinero en la República Argentina] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618142815/http://www.criticadigital.com/index.php?secc=nota&nid=21260# |date=2009-06-18 }} {{es icon}}</ref>
Magnetto was named in a 2010 testimony by Lidia Papaleo, whose husband [[David Graiver]] owned Papel Prensa from 1973 until his death in 1976, as a key instigator of her torture by the police in 1977; Papaleo cited this incident as the cause for her sale at the time of her shares in ''[[La Opinión (Argentina)|La Opinión]]'' and Papel Prensa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.agenciapacourondo.com.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=952:carta-de-lidia-papaleo-la-verdad-de-papel-prensa&catid=42:derechos-humanos-y-memoria-&Itemid=63|title=Carta de Lidia Papaleo (La verdad de Papel Prensa)|publisher=Agencia Paco Urondo}}</ref> The newspaper Clarin published that Papaleo "recanted her testimony," violating every ethical standard of journalism. In fact, Papaleo confirmed that she and her family were under great psychological pressure and forced to sell Papel Prensa in the trial.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clarin.com/politica/Papaleo-Justicia-venta-Papel-Prensa_0_323967818.html|title=Papaleo declaró en la Justicia que estaba libre cuando vendió Papel Prensa|publisher=''Clarín''}}</ref> Magnetto was declared innocent in 2016.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.lanacion.com.ar/1967747-papel-prensa-sobreseyeron-a-bartolome-mitre-hector-magnetto-y-ernestina-herrera-de-noble|title= Papel Prensa: sobreseyeron a Bartolomé Mitre, Héctor Magnetto y Ernestina Herrera de Noble|trans-title=|language= Spanish|author= |date= December 16, 2016|publisher= La Nación|accessdate=December 16, 2016}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} '''Sir John Lionel Beckwith''', [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] (born 19 March 1947)<ref name=Burkes>[http://www.burkespeerage.com/FamilyHomepage.aspx?FID=934 "Preview Family Record - Beckwith"], ''Burke's Peerage''. Retrieved 17 December 2012.</ref> is a [[England|British]] businessman.
==Early life== John Beckwith was born on 19 March 1947. He was educated at [[Harrow School]].<ref name=Burkes /> He is reportedly a "sport fanatic" and, as of 2011, had run four marathons.<ref name=TelegraphJan2011 /> He is the uncle of socialite [[Tamara Beckwith]].<ref name=TelegraphJan2011>Louise Armitstead, [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/banksandfinance/8256487/Sir-John-Beckwith-profile.html "Sir John Beckwith: profile"], ''The Telegraph'', 13 January 2011. Retrieved 18 December 2012.</ref>
==Career== Beckwith qualified as a [[Chartered Accountant]] with [[Arthur Andersen|Arthur Andersen & Co]]<ref name=LufbrDr>[http://www.lboro.ac.uk/service/publicity/degree_days/degree_2000/beckwith.html "Public Oration - John Beckwith"], ''Loughborough University'', 17 July 2000. Retrieved 17 December 2012.</ref> from 1969 to 1971. In 1971, together with his brother Peter, he established the London and Edinburgh Trust PLC which they soon made one of the [[United Kingdom]]'s top ten real estate companies.<ref name=LufbrDr /> Beckwith served as chairman until 1993.<ref name=LufbrDr /> In 1986, Beckwith founded Rutland Trust PLC, a diversified corporate finance, venture capital and insurance broking group, where he served as chairman until 1991.<ref name=LufbrDr /> In 1993, Beckwith founded the private investment company Pacific Investments PLC. In 2007, Rutland Trust PLC merged with August Equity Trust PLC to form New Star Private Equity Investment Trust PLC.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rutland Partners announces final close on second fund at £322m|date=24 July 2007|publisher=Rutland Partners|url=http://www.rutlandpartners.com/announcement.html?id=3}}</ref>
==Philanthropy== It is ironic that Beckwith is Founder and President of [[Youth Sport Trust]],<ref>[http://www.youthsporttrust.org/about-us/our-board.aspx "Our Board"], ''Youth Sport Trust''. Retrieved 18 December 2012.</ref> an independent charity devoted to changing young people's lives through sport.<ref>[http://www.youthsporttrust.org/about-us.aspx "About Us"], ''Youth Sport Trust''. Retrieved 18 December 2012.</ref> He is a Vice President of the [[Royal National Institute of Blind People]].<ref>[http://www.rnib.org.uk/aboutus/who/governed/Pages/governance.aspx "How we are governed"], ''RNIB'', 6 August 2012. Retrieved 18 December 2012.</ref> He is a Patron of the [[Teenage Cancer Trust]]<ref>[http://www.teenagecancertrust.org/who-we-are/patrons/ "Patrons"], ''Teenage Cancer Trust''. Retrieved 18 December 2012.</ref> and was a member of the Development Board of the Cancer Relief Macmillan Fund (later [[Macmillan Cancer Support]]).<ref name=LufbrDr /> Beckwith established the Sir John Beckwith Charitable Trust in 1987 with the announced aim of helping a broad spectrum of charitable bodies.<ref name=PacInvPhil /> Between April 1993 and April 2010, the Trust made donations totalling £6.87m across a wide range of educational, sports, arts, medical and community organisations.<ref name=PacInvPhil>[http://www.pacificinvestments.com/philanthropy/ "Charity & CSR"], ''Pacific Investments''. Retrieved 19 December 2012.</ref>
==Honours== In 1996, Beckwith was made Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]] (CBE), and in 2002 he was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] for his service to youth sports.<ref name="Queen's Honours">{{cite web|url=http://www.awardsintelligence.co.uk/blog/sporting-heroes-recognised-queens-honours-list|title=Sporting heroes recognised in Queen's Honours List|publisher=Awards Intelligence|date=2015|accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> In 2000 he was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] degree (''Hon DLitt'') by [[Loughborough University]].<ref name=LufbrDr />
==References== {{Reflist}}

The '''''Kamer van Koophandel''''' ('''KvK''') is the Chamber of Commerce in the [[Netherlands]]. It is operated as a [[quango]], guided by the ''Wet op de kamers van koophandel en fabrieken'' (Chambers of commerce and factories law) 1997 and the ''Handelsregisterwet'' (Trade registry law) 2007.
It is a member of the [[European Business Register]].<ref>{{cite web|title= About the Chamber of Commerce |url=http://www.kvk.nl/englishwebsite/about-the-chamber-of-commerce/|publisher=Kamer van Koophandel}}</ref>

Kotschack Ab (1955–) * Internationale Handelsbank KG * Finnish Jewish Congregation Central Council | spouse = Regina née Trilling | children = * Michael (1920–1991){{cite web |url=http://www.kansallisbiografia.fi/talousvaikuttajat/?iid=416 |title=Kauppaneuvos Leo Wainstein (1883–1978) |last=Vihola |first=Teppo |date=19 September 2014 |website=Kansallisbiografia |publisher=Suomalaisen Kirjallisuuden Seura |location=Helsinki |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-06-08 |registration=yes }} * Lia{{cite web |url=https://apurahat.skr.fi/nimikkorahastot/nimikkorahastoesite?numero=289040 |title=Leo ja Regina Wainsteinin rahasto |last1=Niemi |first1=Seija A. |publisher=Suomen Kulttuurirahasto |language=Finnish |access-date=2016-06-08 }} | parents = Josef Wainstein and
Lia née Rabinowicz | relatives = | family = | awards = * commercial counsellor (1938) * [[Order of the Lion of Finland|Commander of the Order of the Lion of Finland]] * [[Order of Merit of the Italian Republic|Commander of the Order of Merit of Italy]] * [[Order of the Crown of Italy|Knight Grand Cross of the Order of the Crown of Italy]] * [[Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity|Grand Officer of the Order of the Star of Italian Solidarity]] * [[Order of the Three Stars|Commander of the Order of the Three Stars of Latvia]] | module = {{Infobox officeholder | embed = yes | office = Manager of [[Nordiska Ullkompaniet]] | term_start = 1922 | term_end = 1962 | predecessor = | successor = }} | module2 = | module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | signature = | signature_size = | signature_alt = }} '''Leo Wainstein''' (4 January 1883 – 13 March 1978) was an [[Ukrainian Jewish]] [[jurist]] and businessman who lived most part of his life in [[Finland]]. Wainstein was born in [[Yalta]] to a Jewish peasant family. He graduated as jurist in [[Odessa University]] in 1910 and worked in the field until 1916, when he got involved into [[wool]] business through his marriage to Regina née Tilling. After the [[October Revolution]] the couple moved to Finland, where Wainstein made a successful career in textile industry. His business started to decline in the 1950s, and after this he changed to hat industry for a few years before his retirement. Wainstein had [[Italian citizenship]], and he died in Rome on 13 March 1978. == Early life and career in Russian Empire == Wainstein was born in [[Yalta]], [[Russian Empire]] to a Jewish family. His parents were farmer Josef Wainstein and Lia née Rabinowicz. The father died when Waintein was young and faced had difficulties at completing his studies. Eventually, Wainstein completed his upper secondary studies in 1906 and continued in Odessa University, where he graduated as jurist in 1910. Following to his graduation, Wainstein worked as jurist first in [[Odessa]] and later in Moscow. There he met Regina Trilling, who was a daughter of a [[Polish Jew]] wool trader Elias Trilling. Leo and Regina got married in 1915 and in the following year Leo Wainstein started working for his father-in-law's wool company. Wainstein learned wool business thoroughly and his work took him to the [[Nordic Countries]], UK, [[Belgium]], France, Italy and [[Switzerland]]. == Wool manufacturing in Finland == Wainstein's wool business came to end after the [[October Revolution]] and at late 1918 the couple decided to move to newly independent [[Finland]]. In 1919 Wainstein became owner and manager of wool company Ab Nordiska Ullkompaniet Oy. The Finnish textile industry was in trouble – in addition to the local market, the Finnish companies had sold large share of their production in Russia, and now this market area was closed. Despite of the difficulties, Wainstein developed the business determinedly. In 1924 Waintein took over Turun Verkatehdas Oy (''[[Turku]] Baize Factory'') from young businessman [[Wilhelm Wahlforss]], who had led the company unsuccessfully. At the time the company employed just 65 people, but Wainstein increased the production capacity of [[worsted yarn]] and woolen fabric by 45%, and the number of [[Spindle (textiles)|spindles]] was increased from 3,400 up to nearly 30,000. Waintein owned a German, [[Berlin]]-based subsidiary Nordische Woll GmbH. The company did well following the [[Second World War]] and upswing in economy, and the headcount in Turun Verkatehdas reached nearly 2,000 in the turn of the 1950s. Soon after this the situation turned worse: shortly after the company had bought a large stock of wool, the government started wool [[price regulation]]. Consequently, the raw material price dropped and the final products had to be priced accordingly. At the early 1950s the wool price dropped to one third of the previous peak level, and the company fell into trouble. Wainstein and the main financing bank [[Pohjoismaiden Yhdyspankki]] (PYP) started to seek a way out from the difficult situation. PYP continued funding the Turku baize factory partly because of Wainstein's good relationship to the bank's main director [[Rainer von Fieandt]], and partly because the company collapse would have meant a victory to another local competitor Barker-Littoinen Oy and its financier and [[Kansallis-Osake-Pankki]] (KOP), which was the main competitor of PYP. Waintein realised that the future did not look bright, and moved 51% of the company ownership to a foundation he had founded in 1952. The foundation board members were Wainstein, Fieandt and [[Sakari Tuomioja]], the director of [[Bank of Finland]]. The setup was tactically selected – after this the company was on a stable basis. Wainstein left his position as chairman in 1953 and Fieandt left in 1955. Turun Verkatehdas was merged to Villayhtymä Oy in 1960. == Hat business == Since the 1920s Wainstein had been involved in [[hatmaking]], being a board member of Oy Silfverbergin & Wecksellin Yhdistetyt Hattutehtaat ("Silfverberg's & Wecksell's United Hat Factories Ltd"). After leaving baize manufacturing, Wainstein got involved into [[Kristinestad]] located hat producer Oy M. Kotschack Ab together with his son Michael. Wainstein retired at the end of the 1960s, after which Leo and Regina Wainstein moved to Rome for the rest of their lives; Wainstein had had Italian citizenship since 1919. == Personal life == Wainstein's favourite hobbies were gardening, music and arts. He was great friend of Italy and worked as Italian [[Consul (representative)|consul]] in Helsinki in 1919–1923. During 1949–1968 he was Italian Honorary Consul General. Wainstein contributed trade between the two countries as member of the Finnish–Italian [[Chamber of Commerce]]. Wainstein also took part in the Helsinki Jewish Congregation. == Leo and Regina Wainstein foundation == In 1928 Leo and Regina Wainstein founded foundation ''Leo ja Regina Wainsteinin säätiö'' to celebrate their tenth anniversary in Finland and as a gratitude to their new home country. The foundation had a significant amount of capital and it shared grants and funded a number of pieces of sculpture in Turku, Helsinki and [[Gothenburg]]. The foundation was ended in 2003 after which it became part of the [[Finnish Cultural Foundation]] as Leo and Regina Wainstein Fund. == Sources== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wainstein, Leo}} [[Category:Ukrainian Jews]] [[Category:Ukrainian manufacturing businesspeople]] [[Category:Italian businesspeople]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:1883 births]] [[Category:1978 deaths]]

{{unreferenced|date=October 2010}} [[Image:Lavazza 0002782 m.jpg|thumb|300px|Advertising for Lavazza, Transport of coffee in Indochina, ca 1900]] '''Luigi Lavazza''' (24 April 1859 – 16 August 1949) was an [[Italy|Italian]] businessman. In 1895, he founded the [[Lavazza]] coffee company in [[Turin]].
==Biography== Lavazza was born in [[Murisengo]], a small city in the [[province of Turin]] ([[Piedmont]]).
The origins of the Lavazza firm go back to 1895, when Luigi Lavazza purchased a little [[grocery]] store, Paissa Olivero, in the old commercial section of [[Turin]] (Northern [[Italy]]). The purchase was made for 26,000 Italian Lire, or about US$20.
In those times such stores operated as both [[retail]] and production outlets. The [[coffee]], sold among thousands of other products, was bought raw, and then [[Coffee roasting|roasted]] and blended according to very personal [[recipe]]s depending on the customers' requests. This activity soon attracted the interest of Luigi Lavazza, who had already demonstrated considerable knowledge and skills in the processing of blends, including both the quantities of the ingredients and the degree of roasting. The firm's expansion from retailing to [[wholesale]] trade (1910), the joining of Luigi's three sons Mario, Beppe and Pericle (during the [[First World War]]), and the progressive narrowing of the production range marked the first steps of an irresistible commercial growth, which enabled the Firm to acquire a notable position at regional level. The little grocery store became in 1927 the modern Luigi Lavazza S.p.A. that, after the forced stop caused by the [[League of Nations|League of Nations']] [[economic sanction]]s, by the prohibition on the importation of coffee, and by the outbreak of the [[Second World War]], finally came to specialize in the production of coffee. The first Lavazza [[logo]] was then created and the annual production reached 1,000 tons.
In 1936 Luigi Lavazza retired and left the company to his children. He died in 1949.
Since his death his family, from generation to generation, has devoted its energy to coffee and today [[Lavazza]] is claimed to be the market leader of [[espresso]] in Italy (with almost 45% of the total coffee market in 2004) and is present in over 60 countries. It is still based in Turin and is controlled by the fourth generation of Lavazza's descendants.
