'''Rick L. Edgeman''' (born 1954) is an American statistician and quality professional, and Professor of Sustainability & Performance at [[AU Herning]] and in the [[Interdisciplinary Center for Organizational Architecture]], at [[Aarhus University, School of Business and Social Sciences]]. He primarily known for his work on [[Quality Management]], [[Performance Management]], and within the recent years Sustainable Enterprise Excellence (SEE).<ref>{{cite web|title=AU staff profiles: Rick L. Edgeman|url=http://pure.au.dk/portal/en/persons/rick-edgeman(7a63be96-1bdd-4cb8-bab8-2d1eeef0d7eb)/cv.html?id=45059654|website=Aarhus University|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref>
== Biography == Before [[Aarhus University]] prior posts include Statistical Science Department Professor & Chair at the [[University of Idaho]] (2004-2011), QUEST Professor & QUEST Honors Program Executive Director in the [[Robert H. Smith School of Business]] at the [[University of Maryland]] (2001-2004), Professor of Computer Information Systems & Director of the Center for Quality & Productivity Improvement (CQPI) at [[Colorado State University]] (1988-2001), and early career stints at the [[University of North Texas]], [[Bradley University]], and in the Center for Quality & Applied Statistics at the [[Rochester Institute of Technology]]. A [[Six Sigma|Six Sigma Black Belt]], Rick was a Visiting Professor in the Quality & Environmental Management Division at [[Luleå University of Technology|Luleå University]] (Sweden) and Invited Professor at the Versailles Business School, [[Versailles Saint-Quentin-en-Yvelines University|University of Versailles Saint-Quentin en Yvelines]] (France). Invited lectures and keynotes include ones at [[Oxford University]], the [[Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology]], and on behalf of the [[National Science Foundation]]. In 1992 he was a Special Congressional Fulbright Senior Scholar under the Securing Eastern European Democracy (SEED) Program to [[Comenius University]] in Czechoslovakia, although delayed notification prevented appointment acceptance.
'''EDUCATION'''<ref>{{cite web|title=AU staff profiles: Rick L. Edgeman|url=http://pure.au.dk/portal/en/persons/rick-edgeman(7a63be96-1bdd-4cb8-bab8-2d1eeef0d7eb)/cv.html?id=45059654|website=Aarhus University|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref> * 2004 - [[Villanova University]] (USA) - [[Six Sigma|Six Sigma Black Belt]] * 1983 - [[University of Wyoming]] (USA) - [[Statistics education|Ph.D. Statistics]] * 1979 - [[University of Northern Colorado]] (USA) - M.S. Research & Statistical Methods * 1977 - [[Colorado State University-Pueblo]] (USA) - B.S. [[Experimental Psychology]]
== Work == Edgeman's research addresses [[Quality (business)|quality]], [[innovation]], [[consciousness]], [[six sigma]] innovation & design, [[sustainability]], and statistical methods for quality & reliability engineering He has served on the Editorial Review Boards of [[Total Quality Management & Business Excellence]], The Six Sigma Forum, Quality Engineering, International Journal of Product Development, International Journal of Manufacturing Technology & Management, [[International Journal of Business Performance Management]], and the Business & Entrepreneurship Journal.<ref>{{cite web|title=AU staff profiles: Rick L. Edgeman|url=http://pure.au.dk/portal/en/persons/rick-edgeman(7a63be96-1bdd-4cb8-bab8-2d1eeef0d7eb)/cv.html?id=45059654|website=Aarhus University|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref>
== Selected publications == * Edgeman, Rick. "Strategic resistance for sustaining enterprise relevance: A paradigm for sustainable enterprise excellence, resilience and robustness", International Journal of Productivity and Performance Management, Vol. 64 Iss: 3, p. 318 (2015) * Edgeman, Rick; Williams, Joseph A. "Enterprise self-assessment analytics for sustainability, resilience and robustness", The TQM Journal, Vol. 26 Iss: 4, p. 368 (2014) * Edgeman, Rick L.; Eskildsen, Jacob."Modeling and Assessing Sustainable Enterprise Excellence", Business Strategy and the Environment, Vol. 33 Iss: 3, p. 173 (2013) * Edgeman, Rick. "Sustainable Enterprise Excellence: towards a framework for holistic data-analytics", Corporate Governance, Vol. 13 Iss: 5, p. 527 (2013) * Edgeman, Rick L.; Klefsjö, Bengt; and Wiklund, Håkan. "Six Sigma Seen as a Methodology for Total Quality Management", Measuring Business Excellence, Vol. 5, Iss: 1, p. 31 (2001) * Edgeman, Rick L.."BEST business excellence:: an expanded view", Measuring Business Excellence, Vol. 4 Iss: 4, p. 15 (2000)
[http://pure.au.dk/portal/en/persons/rick-edgeman(7a63be96-1bdd-4cb8-bab8-2d1eeef0d7eb)/publications.html Link to full list of publications]

'''Silicon Fen''' (sometimes known as the '''Cambridge Cluster''') is the name given to the region around [[Cambridge]], [[England]], which is home to a large [[business cluster|cluster]] of [[high-tech]] [[businesses]] focusing on [[software]], [[electronics]] and [[biotechnology]]. Many of these businesses have connections with the [[University of Cambridge]], and the area is now one of the most important technology centres in [[Europe]].
It is called "Silicon Fen" by analogy with [[Silicon Valley]] in [[California]], because it lies at the southern tip of the [[The Fens|English Fenland]]. The interest in technology in the area started with [[Acorn Computers]].<ref name="zdnet cambridge">{{cite news | url=http://www.zdnet.co.uk/news/it-strategy/1998/12/01/us-report-old-cambridge-targets-high-tech-success-2070082/ | title=US Report: Old Cambridge targets high-tech success | work=[[ZDNet]] | date=1 December 1998 | accessdate=15 December 2011 | author=Jones, Kevin | quote=The focus on technology in the so-called Silicon Fen started two decades ago with Acorn Computer PLC, which became the U.K.'s leading personal computer maker until the advent of Windows. The Fen also spawned a couple of successes, such as Advanced RISC Machines Ltd., a virtual chip designer; Cambridge Display Technologies Ltd., a monitor maker [...]}}</ref>
==Business growth== More than 1000 high-technology companies established offices in the area during the five years preceding 1998.<ref name="nytimes Ibrahim 1998">{{cite news | url=http://partners.nytimes.com/library/cyber/week/010498cambridge.html | title=In Old England a Silicon Fen: Cambridge as a High-Tech Outpost | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=4 January 1998 | accessdate=13 June 2012 | author=Ibrahim, Youseff M.}}</ref> Some early successful businesses were [[Advanced RISC Machines]] and [[Cambridge Display Technology]].<ref name="zdnet cambridge" /> In 2004, 24% of all UK [[venture capital]] (8% of all the EU's) was received by Silicon Fen companies, according to the Cambridge Cluster Report 2004 produced by [[Library House]] and [[Grant Thornton]].
The so-called ''Cambridge phenomenon'', giving rise to start-up companies in a town previously only having a little light industry in the [[electrical engineering|electrical sector]], is usually dated to the founding of the [[Cambridge Science Park]] in 1970: this was an initiative of [[Trinity College, Cambridge|Trinity College, Cambridge University]] and moved away from a traditional low-development policy for Cambridge.
The characteristic of Cambridge is small companies (as few as three people, in some cases) in sectors such as [[computer-aided design]]. Over time the number of companies has grown; it has not proved easy to count them, but recent estimates have placed the number anywhere between 1,000 and 3,500 companies.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} They are spread over an area defined perhaps by the CB [[postcode]] or 01223 [[telephone]] [[area code]], or more generously in an area bounded by [[Ely, Cambridgeshire|Ely]], [[Newmarket, Suffolk|Newmarket]], [[Saffron Walden]], [[Royston, Hertfordshire|Royston]] and [[Huntingdon]].
In 2000, then [[Chancellor of the Exchequer]] [[Gordon Brown]] set up a research partnership between [[MIT]] and Cambridge University, the [[Cambridge–MIT Institute]], in order to increase international collaboration between the two universities and to strengthen the economic success of Silicon Fen.
In February 2006, the [[Judge Business School|Judge Business School, Cambridge University]] reported estimates that suggested that at that time, there were around 250 active start-ups directly linked to the University, valued at around US$6 billion. Only a tiny proportion of these companies have so far grown into [[multinational corporation|multinational]]s: [[ARM Ltd|ARM]], [[Autonomy Corporation]] and [[AVEVA]] are the most obvious examples, and more recently [[Cambridge Silicon Radio|CSR]] has seen rapid growth due to the uptake of [[Bluetooth]].
It was found in 2012 that strong employment growth was hampered due to the concentration on [[research and development]]. This was because of limited competition in manufacturing capability and its consequent cost.<ref name="hbs andersen 2012">{{cite web|last=Andersen|first=Christian|author2=Bailey, Jonathan|author3=Heal, Adam|author4=Munn, Oliver|author5=O'Connell, Bryan|title=IT Hardware cluster: Cambridge, United Kingdom|url=http://www.isc.hbs.edu/pdf/Student_Projects/2012%20MOC%20Papers/20120504%20MOC%20UK%20Cambridge%20IT%20hardware%20cluster%20-%20Final%20project%20paper.pdf|work=Final Paper; Microeconomics of Competitiveness, Harvard Business School|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=18 June 2012|date=4 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120619111115/http://www.isc.hbs.edu/pdf/Student_Projects/2012%20MOC%20Papers/20120504%20MOC%20UK%20Cambridge%20IT%20hardware%20cluster%20-%20Final%20project%20paper.pdf|archivedate=19 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Recent work by [http://www.cambridgeahead.co.uk Cambridge Ahead], the business and academic membership organisation dedicated to the successful growth of the city region in the long-term, has shown that in 2015-16, growth of Cambridge companies continued at around 7% on a one, three and five-year view. Global turnover of Cambridge companies increased by 7.6% to £35.7bn, up from £33bn the previous year, and global employment grew by 7.6% to 210,292. The number of companies with their home base within 20 miles of Cambridge has grown from 22,017 to 24,580.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cambridgeahead.co.uk/2017/01/latest-data-cambridge-ahead-reveals-unabated-growth-cambridge-companies/|title=Latest data from Cambridge Ahead reveals unabated growth of Cambridge companies|last=|first=|date=2017-01-24|website=www.cambridgeahead.co.uk|publisher=Cambridge Ahead|access-date=2017-05-14}}</ref>
What is striking about the data is that 2015-16 was just another typical 7% growth year for Cambridge. Over the past five years (2010-11 to 2015-16) the turnover of Cambridge companies has grown by 7.5% per annum, and employment by 6.6% per annum.
The growth of Silicon Fen is best revealed by the [http://www.camclustermap.com Cambridge Cluster Map], a new data tool that accurately maps the growth of the Cambridge sub-region over time and reveals the true extent of the success of the ‘Cambridge Phenomenon’. The map was created and launched in July 2016 by Cambridge Ahead in partnership with Barclays, working with the Centre for Business Research (CBR) at the University of Cambridge, and is an updated version of the previous Cluster Map covering the Tech sector launched in 2012.
The new dataset identifies and locates companies and certain research facilities that are active within a 20-mile radius of the centre of the city and shows three types of organisations: Cambridge-based companies, Cambridge-active companies, and Non-corporate Knowledge-intensive (KI) organisations.
==Area characteristics== The region has one of the most flexible job markets in the technology sector, and people are often employed by other companies after a start-up fails. Although everyone wants their company to succeed, failures are tolerated, indeed almost expected.
One reason for the area's success is that after some time such an employment market is self-sustaining, since employees are willing to move to an area that promises a future beyond any one company. Another factor is the high degree of 'networking', enabling people across the region to find partners, jobs, funding, and know-how. Organisations have sprung up to facilitate this process, for example the [[Cambridge Network]].
Another factor is the academic pre-eminence of [[Cambridge University]], which is one of the top 5 universities in the world, a high [[standard of living]] available in the county, and good transport links, for example to London and with [[Cambridge Airport]] having a full service business jet centre. Many graduates from the university choose to stay on in the area, giving local companies a rich pool of talent to draw upon {{Citation needed|date=November 2008}}. The high-technology industry has little by way of competition, unlike say in [[Oxfordshire]] where many other competing industries exist. Because Cambridgeshire was not until recently a high-technology centre, commercial rents were generally lower than in other parts of the UK, giving companies a head-start on those situated in other more expensive regions; this has, however, recently changed and Cambridgeshire now has one of the highest costs of living in the UK outside London.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}}

[[File:Silvio Denz Wikipedia.jpg|thumb|Silvio Werner Denz]]
'''Silvio Werner Denz''' (born 14 September 1956 in [[Basel]], [[Switzerland]]) is a Swiss entrepreneur and collector of wine and art, currently living in Switzerland. He worked for various companies in Switzerland and the United States in finance, retail and marketing.<ref>Valli Marie-Pierre. [http://www.lemonde.fr/journalelectronique/donnees/libre/20140411/index.html?cahier=LIV "Silvio Denz épouse son temps"], ''[[Le Monde]]'', Paris, 2014-04-11 2014. Retrieved 2014-11-05.</ref> He now operates mainly in the fields of luxury goods and wine. The Swiss business magazine ''Bilanz'' <ref>https://www.bilanz.ch/people/300-reichste</ref> ranks him among the 300 wealthiest Swiss citizens and, more recently, among the 100 most important figures of the Swiss economy.<ref>https://www.bilanz.ch/people/luxus</ref>
==Entrepreneur==
===Perfume, cosmetics=== In 1980 Silvio Denz took over the management of [[Zurich]]-based Alrodo AG,<ref>{{cite web|author=Kolesnikov-Jessop Sonia |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2014/09/01/business/international/covering-the-skill-basics-at-big-companies.html?_r=0 |title=Covering the Skill Basics at Big Companies |publisher=International New York Times |date=2014-09-01 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref> at that time was owned by his father and uncle. Initially with eight employees, the company purchased perfumes and cosmetics for imported perfumery retailers. After acquiring all the equity in Alrodo in 1984, he built up the company over the next 20 years to become Switzerland's largest perfumery chain, with 120 branches. Between 1980 and 2000, the number of employees rose from 8 to 800. In 2000 Denz sold Alrodo to the French perfumery chain Marionnaud.<ref>{{cite web|author=Carole Bellemare |url= http://www.lefigaro.fr/decideurs/nomination/2015/10/21/33002-20151021ARTFIG00429-silvio-denz-l-esthete-et-epicurienqui-redonne-du-lustre-a-lalique.php |title=Silvio Denz, l'esthète et épicurienqui redonne du lustre à Lalique |publisher=Le Figaro |date=2015-10-21 |accessdate=2014-12-19}}</ref> In the same year he founded Lalique Group (formerly known as Art & Fragrance) specializing in the creation, production and marketing of perfume and cosmetic brands such as Perfumes [[Alain Delon]], [[Parfums Grès]], Perfumes Lalique, Jaguar Fragrances, Bentley Fragrances and Ultrasun.<ref>Bilanz 31 May 2005; "Silvio Denz: Rastloser Schlossherr"; by Corinne Amacher</ref> The company has been listed on the stock exchange since 2007. It was first listed on the BX Berne eXchange and since June 2018 the Group has been listed on SIX Swiss Exchange. ===Luxury=== Silvio Denz accumulated the world's largest private collection of vintage perfume bottles designed by [[René Lalique]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Samantha Brooks |url= http://robbreport.com/Art-Collectibles/Crystal-Revelations |title= Crystal revelations |publisher=Robb Report |date=2010-11-10 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Sonia Kolesnikov-Jessop |url= http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/998924/the-collector-silvio-denz-and-his-lalique-glass-menagerie |title= The Collector: Silvio Denz and his Lalique Glass Menagerie |publisher=Blouinartinfo.com |date=2014-01-03 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> comprising over 650 original pieces.<ref>Watch Your Time, supplément Montres du Monde, page 15, 11 April 2014, Marie-Pierre Valli</ref> In 2008 the company acquired the French crystalware house Lalique S.A. The group became profitable again after being restructured, with branding focused on art, decorative items, interior design, jewellery, perfume and hospitality.<ref>Le Point, 1st January 2015, Marine de la Horie, „L’art et la matière“</ref> Co-branding projects were developed between Lalique and various other luxury brands (including [[Bentley]], [[The Macallan]] and [[Steinway & Sons]]). Collaborations were also signed with artists such as [[Zaha Hadid]], [[Jean-Michel Jarre]], [[Damien Hirst]], and [[Elton John]],<ref>{{cite web|author=Emily Adams |url= http://issuu.com/runwildmedia/docs/mayf_nov_15 |title= The Butterfly Effect |publisher=The Mayfair Magazine |date=2015-11-01 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> resulting in collections for the company, in some cases. In 2011, the Lalique museum in Wingen-sur-Moder ([[Alsace]]) opened to display more than 650 pieces designed by [[René Lalique]] and his successors, including jewellery, crystal and decorative glass.<ref>{{cite web|author=Eve M. Kahn |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2011/06/24/arts/design/among-antiques-lalique-snuffboxes-and-soviet-film-posters.html?_r=0 |title=Suddenly, Lalique is back in Vogue |publisher=New York Times |date=2011-06-11 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> Denz loaned 230 pieces from his personal collection, mostly perfume bottles.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.musee-lalique.com/en/collections-presented-mus%C3%A9e-lalique |title=The collections presented at the Musée Lalique |publisher=Musée Lalique |accessdate=2016-01-08}}</ref> Denz also converted René Lalique's villa in Wingen-sur-Moder into a luxury hotel and restaurant, which opened in September 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=Carol Lewis |url= http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/property/interiors/article4586117.ece |title=Like the furniture? Then buy it|publisher=The Times |date=2015-10-16|accessdate=2016-01-06}}</ref>
===Wine=== In 1994 Silvio Denz, along with Franz Wermuth and five other partners, founded Les Grand Vins Wermuth S.A., now split into Denz Weine (distribution) and Wermuth Auktionen AG (auctions)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wermuth.ch |title=Les Grands Vins Wermuth SA, Weinhandel, Weinauktionen |publisher=Wermuth.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> in Zurich. In 1998, acting with the same partners, he bought the Clos d'Agon<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.closdagon.com |title=Clos d'Agon |publisher=Closdagon.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> estate on the [[Costa Brava]], which is overseen by the oenologist [[Peter Sisseck]] ([[Dominio Pingus]]).
In 2005, on the recommendation of his friend Count Stephan von Neipperg ([[Château Canon-la-Gaffelière]] and [[La Mondotte]]), Denz bought the Château Faugères estate, six kilometers east of [[Saint Emilion]]. Faugères, which has 30 employees,<ref>http://www.châteaufaugeres.com{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> comprises three vineyards: Château Faugères, Château Péby Faugères, both lying in the Saint-Emilion appellation, and Château Cap-de-Faugères in Côtes de Castillion. In 2010, he and Peter Sisseck took over the vineyard of Château Rocheyron in Saint-Emilion. The estates in [[Bordeaux]] cover a total of 120 hectares.<ref>Schweizerische Weinzeitung; Ausgabe 3 März 2012;"Silvio Denz: Unternehmer und leidenschaftlicher Sammler von Weingütern"</ref> Silvio Denz also owns the Montepeloso winery in Italy (which he acquired with Fabio Chiarelotto in 2007).
The winery at Château Faugères was designed by the architect [[Mario Botta]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.botta.ch |title=mario botta architetto |publisher=Botta.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>Sonntagszeitung; GenussTrend 18 October 2009</ref> He describes his creation as a "cathedral of wine".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/ |title=Actualité à la Une |publisher=Le Monde.fr |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref> Using modern technology coupled with traditional methods, such as gravity-filling, the wines are aged in oak barrels.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-01-04-2012?id=f31eada9-0218-4cc3-bb6e-f8263bcbfa36 |title=cash TV vom 01.04.2012 - cash TV - TV - SRF Player - Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen |publisher=Srf.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140225201746/http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-01-04-2012?id=f31eada9-0218-4cc3-bb6e-f8263bcbfa36 |archivedate=25 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 2012 Château Faugères and Château Péby Faugères were awarded the status of Grand Cru Classé of Saint-Emilion. According to the wine critic [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]], Château Péby Faugères today ranks among the finest Bordeaux wines.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.erobertparker.com/entrance.aspx |title=The Independent Consumer's Guide to Fine Wine |publisher=eRobertParker.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140819083230/https://www.erobertparker.com/entrance.aspx |archivedate=19 August 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wineinvestment.com/wine-blog/2015/06/parker-s-top-100-2005-bordeaux-wines/|title=Parker's Top 100 2005 Bordeaux Wines |publisher=wineinvestment.com}}</ref> In 2015 the influential Parker's Wine Buyer's Guide rated Château Péby Faugères Vintage 2005 100/100.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.comptoirdesmillesimes.com/blog/les-meilleurs-vins-robert-parker |title= Les 300 vins ayant obtenu la note de 100/100 par Robert Parker |publisher=Le blog de comptoir de millésimes |date=2015-09-25 |accessdate=2015-12-28}}</ref> In February 2014, Silvio Denz acquired [[Château Lafaurie-Peyraguey]], one of the few Premiers Grands Crus Classés of 1855 and one of the oldest vineyards in Sauternes. Silvio Denz's wine businesses are held in Art & Terroir.
On September 17, 2017, Silvio Denz was inducted as a Saint-Emilion Jurat.<ref>https://en.vins-saint-emilion.com/about/jurade-saint-emilion Sain-Emilion Jurat</ref> The Jurade of Saint-Emilion currently consists of 127 Jurats and more than 3000 Saint-Emilion wine ambassadors worldwide. In October 2017, he was awarded a Special Jury Prize from Fond’Action Alsace <ref>Fond’Action Alsace http://www.fondaction-alsace.com/les-laureats.html Fond’Action Alsace</ref> for his active involvement in the Alsace region. In the same month, he then went on to receive the Guillon d’Or award from the Guillon d’Or award,<ref>Confrérie du Guillon http://www.guillon.ch/fr/Activites/Guillon-d-Or-CDC/Guillon-d-Or-CDC.html</ref> a Vaudois wine brotherhood founded in 1954, commending his passion and performance in the world of wine.
===Property=== In 2003 Silvio Denz entered the real estate business in London. Working with local partners, he buys, renovates, and then resells traditional town houses in Mayfair, Knightsbridge and Kensington.<ref>Financial Times 1/2 August 2009; "Art and architecture are my passions"; by Rebecca Duke</ref>
==Collector==
===Pictures=== Silvio Denz collects works of art via his company Art & Trade.<ref>Handelszeitung/Special/Casa/Nr38/22–28 September 2010; "Schlossherr Silvio Denz"; Esther Bullmann {{dead link|date=October 2014}}</ref>
===Wine=== He has been buying vintage wines for over 30 years, mainly from Bordeaux. His private cellar contains more than 35,000 bottles.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/998924/the-collector-silvio-denz-and-his-lalique-glass-menagerie |title=The Collector: Silvio Denz and his Lalique Glass Menagerie |publisher=blouinartinfo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-06-02}}</ref>
===Crystal=== His interest in perfume bottles dates from his time at Alrodo. Today, he is the owner of the world's largest private collection of bottles by the celebrated French glass artist [[René Lalique]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.srf.ch/player/tv/cash-tv/video/cash-tv-vom-07-10-2012?id=fdd387ca-69b5-4d55-8ecc-ee8fb9dac01c |title=cash TV vom 07.10.2012 - cash TV - TV - SRF Player - Schweizer Radio und Fernsehen |publisher=Srf.ch |date= |accessdate=2013-10-14}}</ref><ref>Dernières Nouvelles d'Alsace (DNA) 2 July 2011; "Inauguration du Musée Lalique/Déja une référence"; by Jean Luc Will</ref>
==Awards and Memberships== Member of the Board of Directors Lindt & Sprüngli (2018)<ref>http://www.lindt-spruengli.com/investors/events-presentations/annual-general-meeting/</ref>; Member "Chaîne des Rôtisseurs", Alsace (2018) <ref>http://france.chainedesrotisseurs.com/?lang=en</ref>; Saint-Emilion Jurat, The Jurade of Saint-Emilion 17 September (2017);<ref>https://en.vins-saint-emilion.com/about/jurade-saint-emilion</ref> Special Jury Prize, Fond’Action Alsace (2017);<ref>http://www.fondaction-alsace.com/les-laureats.html</ref> The Guillon d’Or award, Confrérie du Guillon (2017);<ref>http://www.guillon.ch/fr/Activites/Guillon-d-Or-CDC/Guillon-d-Or-CDC.html</ref> Member "Keepers of the Quaich", Scotland(2015);<ref>https://www.keepersofthequaich.co.uk/</ref> Honorary member, Confrérie Saint-Etienne d'Alsace (2017);<ref>http://www.confrerie-st-etienne.com/fr/</ref> Member "Club Prosper Montagne" (2016)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.club-prosper-montagne.ch/default.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-01-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180110174334/http://www.club-prosper-montagne.ch/default.aspx |archivedate=10 January 2018 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox NRHP | name = South Street Seaport | nrhp_type = hd | image = South Street Seaport, Detroit Photographic Company (0616).jpg | image_size= 287px | caption = South Street and Brooklyn Bridge (c.1900) | location= Bounded by Burling (John St.) and Peck Slips, Water St. and [[East River]] in [[New York City]], [[United States]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|22|N|74|0|12|W|region:US-NY_type:landmark|display=title}} | locmapin = Lower Manhattan#Manhattan#New York City#New York#USA | nocat = yes <!-- to prevent locmapin placing the page in the non-existent [[Category:Historic districts in Lower Manhattan]] --> | built = | architect = multiple | architecture = [[Greek Revival architecture|Greek Revival]] | added = October 18, 1972 | area = {{convert|3.5|acre|sigfig=2}} | governing_body = private | refnum = 72000883<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2009a}}</ref> {{Infobox NRHP | name = South Street Seaport Historic District | embed=yes | image = | caption = | location= Roughly bounded by East River, Brooklyn Bridge, Fletcher Alley, and Pearl and South Streets, [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]], [[United States]] | built = | architecture = Greek Revival, [[Romanesque revival architecture|Romanesque]] | added = December 12, 1978 | area = {{convert|41|acre|sigfig=2}} | governing_body = | refnum = 78001884<ref name="nris"/> }} }} The '''South Street Seaport''' is a historic area in the [[New York City]] [[borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Manhattan]], centered where [[Fulton Street (Manhattan)|Fulton Street]] meets the [[East River]], and adjacent to the [[Financial District, Manhattan|Financial District]]. The Seaport is a [[List of New York City Designated Landmarks in Manhattan below 14th Street#Historic Districts|designated historic district]], and is distinct from the neighboring Financial District. It is part of [[Manhattan Community Board 1]] in [[Lower Manhattan]], and is bounded by the Financial District to the west, southwest, and north; the East River to the southeast; and [[Two Bridges, Manhattan|Two Bridges]] to the northeast.
It features some of the oldest architecture in downtown Manhattan, and includes the largest concentration of restored early 19th-century commercial buildings in the city. This includes renovated original mercantile buildings, renovated sailing ships, the former [[Fulton Fish Market]], and modern tourist malls featuring food, shopping, and nightlife.
==History==
===As port=== The first pier in the area appeared in 1625, when the [[Dutch West India Company]] founded an outpost here.<ref name="report ">{{cite web |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/SOUTH_STREET_SEAPORT_HISTORIC_DISTRICT.pdf |title=South Street Seaport Historic District DesignationReport |publisher=nyc.gov |date=1977 |accessdate=May 12, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk10Ndoa?url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/lpc/downloads/pdf/reports/SOUTH_STREET_SEAPORT_HISTORIC_DISTRICT.pdf |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> With the influx of the first settlers, the area was quickly developed. One of the first and busiest streets in the area was today's [[Pearl Street (Manhattan)|Pearl Street]], so named for a variety of coastal pearl shells.<ref name=encnyc>{{cite encnyc}}, pp. 1214–1215</ref> Due to its location, Pearl Street quickly gained popularity among traders.<ref>{{Cite book |author=Linda S. Cordell |title=Archaeology in America: An Encyclopedia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=arfWRW5OFVgC |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2008 |page=123 |isbn=0313021899|display-authors=etal}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/nyregion/south-street-seaport-has-begun-storm-recovery.html?_r=0 |title=Water and Land, Past and Present |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |author=Sarah Harrison Smith |date=January 11, 2013 |accessdate=May 13, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Gk10weBW?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/13/nyregion/south-street-seaport-has-begun-storm-recovery.html?_r=1& |archivedate=May 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The East River was eventually narrowed. By the second half of the 17th century, the pier was extended to Water Street, then to [[Lower Manhattan|Front Street]], and by the beginning of the 19th century, to [[South Street (Manhattan)|South Street]].<ref name = "report" /> The pier was well reputed, as it was protected from westerly winds and ice of the [[Hudson River]].<ref name=encnyc/>
In 1728, the [[Schermerhorn|Schermerhorn Family]] established trade with the city of [[Charleston, South Carolina]]. Subsequently, [[rice]] and [[Indigofera tinctoria|indigo]] came from Charleston.<ref>Kroessler 2002, pp. 36–37</ref> At the time, the port was also the focal point of delivery of goods from [[England]]. In 1776, during the [[American Revolutionary War]], the British occupied the port, adversely affecting port trade for eight years. In 1783, many traders returned to England, and most port enterprises collapsed.<ref name = "report" /> The port quickly recovered from the post-war crisis. From 1797 until the middle of 19th century, New York had the country's largest system of maritime trade.<ref name = "report" /> From 1815 to 1860 the port was called the Port of New York.
On February 22, 1784, the ''[[Empress of China (1783)|Empress of China]]'' sailed from the port to [[Guangzhou]] and returned to [[Philadelphia]] on May 15, 1785,<ref>{{Cite book |last1=Berube |first1=Claude G. |last2=Rodgaard |first2=John A. |title=A Call To The Sea |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a6F90OzIaMEC |publisher=Potomac Books |date=2005 |page=7 |isbn=1612342299}}</ref> bringing along, in its cargo, [[green tea|green]] and [[black tea]]s, [[porcelain]], and other goods.<ref>{{Cite book |author=Jyh-Ming Yang |title=Lost in Transliteration: The Tolerance of Unintelligibility in Chinese Bibliographic Records in Western Libraries |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uAktDoGM_iMC |work=The University of Wisconsin -Madison |publisher=ProQuest |year=2008 |page=61 |isbn=0549801332}}</ref> This operation marked the beginning of trade relations between the newly formed United States and the [[Qing Empire]].<ref>Kroessler 2002, p. 52</ref>
On January 5, 1818, the 424-ton transatlantic packet ''[[Black Ball Line (trans-Atlantic packet)|James Monroe]]'' sailed from [[Liverpool]], opening the first regular trans-Atlantic voyage route, the Black Ball Line.<ref>{{Cite book |author=Patrick Bunyan |title=All Around the Town: Amazing Manhattan Facts and Curiosities, Second Edition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ytpzn0EfA-YC |edition=2 |publisher=Fordham Univ Press |year=2010 |series=Empire State Editions Series |pages=52–53 |isbn=0823231747}}</ref> Shipping on this route continued until 1878.<ref>Kroessler 2002, p. 70</ref> Commercially successful transatlantic traffic has led to the creation of many competing companies, including the [[Red Star Line]] in 1822.<ref>McKay 1969, p. 130</ref><ref>{{Cite book |title=Encyclopedia of American Business History |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5dGig0fYlj8C |author=Charles R. Geisst |publisher=Infobase Publishing |year=2009 |pages=389 |isbn=1438109873}}</ref> Transportation significantly contributed to the establishment of the New York one of the centers of world trade.<ref name = "report" />
[[File:Fish Market, South Street, Manhattan (NYPL b13668355-482702).jpg|thumb|left|The Fish Market during the [[Great Depression]]]] [[File:207-209-211 WATER STREET IN CENTER FOREGROUND (Note identical height and architectural features) - South Street Seaport Museum, 207-211 Water Street, New York, New York County, HABS NY,31-NEYO,141-1.tif|thumb|left|The port in the late 1970s]]
One of the largest companies in the South Street Seaport area was the [[Fulton Fish Market]], opened in 1822. In 2005, it was moved to the area of [[Hunts Point, Bronx]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ny.curbed.com/archives/2012/05/15/vintage_photos_of_the_fulton_fish_market_in_its_glory_days.php |title=Vintage Photos of the Fulton Fish Market in its Glory Days |publisher=Curbed NY |author=Jessica Dailey |date=May 15, 2012 |accessdate=April 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/11/11/nyregion/11cnd-fish.html?_r=0 |title=On Fish Market's Last Day, Tough Guys and Moist Eyes |publisher=The New York Times |author=Andrew Jacobs |date=November 11, 2005 |accessdate=April 16, 2014}}</ref>
In November 1825, the [[Erie Canal]], located upstate, was opened.<ref>Kroessler 2002, p. 74</ref> The canal, connecting New York to the [[western United States]], facilitated the economic development of the city.<ref>{{Cite book |author=Howard B. Rock |title=The New York City Artisan: 1789 – 1825; a Documentary History |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gn5gGklOxAcC |publisher=SUNY Press |year=1989 |series=SUNY series in American labour history |page=113 |isbn=1438417594}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book |author=Randall Gabrielan |title=New York City's Financial District in Vintage Postcards |url=https://books.google.com/books?Id=YQ1A-Hz3ml4C |publisher=Arcadia Publishing |year=2000 |series=The postcard history series |page=90 |isbn=0738500682}}</ref> However, for this reason, along with the beginning of the shipping era, there was a need to lengthen the piers and deepen the port.<ref>{{Cite book |author=Ann L. Buttenwieser |title=Manhattan Water-bound: Manhattan's Waterfront from the Seventeenth Century to the Present |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KB2MsihpwRQC |edition=2 |work=Syracuse University Press |year=1999 |series=New York City History and Culture Series |page=41 |isbn=0815628013}}</ref>
On the night of December 17, 1835 a large fire in New York City destroyed 17 blocks,<ref>Kroessler 2002, p. 81</ref> and many buildings in the South Street Seaport burned to the ground. Nevertheless, by the 1840s, the port recovered, and by 1850, it reached its heyday:<ref name = "report" />
{{quote|1= Looking east, was seen in the distance on the long river front from [[Coenties Slip]] to Catharine Street {{sic}}, innumerable masts of the many Californian clippers and London and Liverpool packets, with their long bowsprits extending way over South Street, reaching nearly to the opposite side.<ref>{{cite book |author=Thomas Floyd-Jones |title=Backward glances: reminiscences of an old New-Yorker |url=https://archive.org/stream/backwardglancesr00floy |publisher=Unionist Gazette Association |year=1914 |pages=7–8}}</ref>}}
At its peak, the port hosted many commercial enterprises, institutions, ship-chandlers, workshops, boarding houses, saloons, and brothels. However, by the 1880s, the port began to be depleted of resources, space for the development of these businesses was diminishing, and the port became too shallow for newer ships. By the 1930s, most of the piers no longer functioned, and cargo ships docked mainly on ports on the [[West Side (Manhattan)|West Side]] and in [[Hoboken, New Jersey|Hoboken]].<ref name=encnyc/> By the late 1950s, the old [[Ward Line]] docks, comprising Piers 15, 16, and part of 17, were mostly vacant.{{citation needed|date=July 2015}}
===As museum=== [[File:Schermerhorne Row sunny morn north jeh.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Part of Schermerhorn Row, early 19th-century mercantile buildings]] [[File:US Navy 050529-N-7676W-006 ONR Afloat Lab YP-679 Starfish at South Street Seaport Pier 17 during 18th annual Fleet Week New York.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Pier 17 before demolition]] [[File:Pier 17 2018-03 jeh.jpg|thumb|250px|Newly renovated Pier 17 in 2018]] The '''South Street Seaport Museum''' was founded in 1967 by Peter and Norma Stanford. When originally opened as a museum, the focus of the Seaport Museum conservation was to be an educational historic site, with shops mostly operating as reproductions of working environments found during the Seaport's heyday.
In 1982, redevelopment began to turn the museum into a greater [[tourist attraction]] via development of modern shopping areas. The project was undertaken by the prominent developer [[James Rouse]] and modeled on the concept of a "[[festival marketplace]]," a leading revitalization strategy throughout the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fordham.edu/academics/colleges__graduate_s/undergraduate_colleg/fordham_college_at_l/special_programs/honors_program/seaportproject/rest/development.html |title=Fordham College at Lincoln Center |author=Fordham |publisher= |accessdate=March 14, 2016}}</ref> On the other side of Fulton Street from Schermerhorn Row, the main Fulton Fish Market building, which had become a large plain garage-type structure, was rebuilt as an upscale [[shopping mall]]. Pier 17's old platforms were demolished and a new glass shopping pavilion raised in its place, which opened in August 1983.
The original intent of the Seaport development was the preservation of the block of buildings known as [[Schermerhorn Row Block|Schermerhorn Row]] on the southwest side of Fulton Street, which were threatened with neglect or future development, at a time when the history of New York City's sailing ship industry was not valued, except by some [[antiquarian]]s. Early historic preservation efforts focused on these buildings and the acquisition of several sailing ships. Almost all buildings and the entire Seaport neighborhood are meant to transport the visitor back in time to New York's mid-19th century, to demonstrate what life in the commercial maritime trade was like. Docked at the Seaport are a few historical sailing vessels, including the [[Wavertree (ship)|''Wavertree'']]. A section of nearby Fulton Street is preserved as cobblestone and lined with shops, bars, and restaurants. The [[Bridge Cafe]], which claims to be "The Oldest Drinking Establishment in New York" is in a building that formerly housed a brothel.
In 2012, [[Hurricane Sandy]] heavily damaged the Seaport; tidal floods (seven feet deep in places) inundated much of the Seaport causing extensive damage that forced an end to plans to restore the Museum's fortunes by merging it into the [[Museum of the City of New York]].<ref name=Pogrebim>{{cite news |last1=Pogrebin |first1=Robin |title=Susan Henshaw Jones to Leave Museum of the City of New York |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/16/arts/design/susan-henshaw-jones-to-leave-museum-of-the-city-of-new-york.html |accessdate=16 April 2015 |publisher=New York Times |date=15 April 2015}}</ref> Many of the businesses closed, and the remaining businesses suffered from a severe drop in business after the storm.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20121102/south-street-seaport/south-street-seaport-businesses-struggle-recover-from-sandy-flooding |title=South Street Seaport Businesses Struggle to Recover from Sandy Flooding |work=DNAinfo New York |accessdate=March 14, 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923225203/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20121102/south-street-seaport/south-street-seaport-businesses-struggle-recover-from-sandy-flooding |archivedate=September 23, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> The South Street Seaport Museum re-opened in December 2012. [[The Howard Hughes Corporation]], the Seaport's owner, announced that it would tear down the Seaport's most prominent shopping area, Pier 17, as part of a broader redevelopment of the neighborhood. The new pier, containing retail, restaurants, and a rooftop performance venue, is set to open in summer 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2018/2/27/17058526/pier-17-south-street-seaport-april-2018-opening|title=South Street Seaport's Pier 17 will start opening this April|work=Curbed NY|access-date=2018-05-02}}</ref>
==Ownership and management== The Seaport is currently owned and managed by [[Howard Hughes Corporation]]. Formerly, it was run by General Growth Properties, which acquired the Seaport's longtime owner, [[The Rouse Company]], in 2004.<ref name=NREI04>{{cite news |title=General Growth Buys Rouse Co. in $12.6 Billion Deal |first=Kurt |last=Hazlett |date=August 20, 2004 |url=http://nreionline.com/news/general-growth-buys-rouse-co-126-billion-deal |work=National Real Estate Investor}}</ref> As part of its restructuring, General Growth spun off the Howard Hughes Corporation.<ref name=BaltSun10>{{cite news |title=General Growth Properties emerges from bankruptcy |date=November 9, 2010 |url=http://articles.baltimoresun.com/2010-11-09/business/bs-bz-general-growth-emerges-20101109_1_general-growth-mall-operator-chief-executive-adam-metz}}</ref>
==Constituent parts==
===Museum=== Designated by Congress in 1998 as one of several museums which together make up "America's National [[Maritime Museum]]", South Street Seaport Museum sits in a 12 square-block historic district that is the site of the original port of New York City.<ref>[http://www.theorator.com/bills108/s674.html America's National Maritime Museum Designation Act] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402014813/http://www.theorator.com/bills108/s674.html |date=April 2, 2009 }}, TheOrator.net. Accessed September 18, 2007.</ref> The Museum has over {{convert|30000|sqft|m2}} of exhibition space and educational facilities. It houses exhibition galleries, a working 19th-century print shop, an archeology museum, a maritime library, a craft center, a marine life conservation lab, and the largest privately owned fleet of historic ships in the country.
===Shopping mall and tourist attraction=== [[File:Ground floor escalators 2018 Sept Pier 17 jeh.jpg|thumb|Pier 17 shopping mall, Sept 2018]] At the Seaport a [[shopping mall|mall]] and [[tourist attraction|tourism center]], is built on Pier 17 on the [[East River]]. It was reconstructed in the 2010s and reopened in June 2018.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.metro.us/things-to-do/new-york/lower-manhattan-pier-17-open|title=Lower Manhattan's hot new Pier 17 is open for business|last=|first=|date=2018-06-15|work=Metro US|access-date=2018-08-12|language=en}}</ref> Decks outside on pier 15<ref>{{cite web |last1=Official Guide Staff |title=pier 15, south street seaport |url=http://www.nycgo.com/venues/pier-15-south-street-seaport |website=NYC Official Guide |accessdate=5 February 2016}}</ref> allow views of the East River, [[Brooklyn Bridge]], and [[Brooklyn Heights]]. The Paris Cafe, within the South Street Seaport historic area, is claimed to be one of the oldest [[Bar (establishment)|bar]]s in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.southstreetseaport.com/directory/|title=DIRECTORY|publisher=southstreetseaport.com}}</ref>
At the entrance to the Seaport is the [[Titanic Memorial (New York City)|Titanic Memorial lighthouse]].
===ESPN studios=== Sports broadcaster [[ESPN]] opened a radio and television studio at Pier 17 in April 2018, covering {{Convert|17000|ft2|m2}}.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2017/10/09/espn-to-debut-glimmering-nyc-studios-next-spring/|title=ESPN to debut glimmering NYC studios next spring|last=Cuozzo|first=Steve|date=2017-10-09|work=New York Post|access-date=2017-10-14|language=en-US}}</ref>

==Transportation==
South Street Seaport is currently served by the {{NYC bus link|M15|M15 SBS}} [[New York City Bus]] route.<ref>{{Cite NYC bus map|M}}</ref>
[[New York Water Taxi]] directly serves South Street Seaport on Fridays, weekends, and holidays during the summer, while other New York Water Taxi, [[NYC Ferry]], and [[SeaStreak]] ferries serve the nearby [[ferry slip]] at [[Pier 11/Wall Street]] daily.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Ferry Information |work=NYCDOT |publisher= |date= |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/dot/html/ferrybus/ferintro.shtml |accessdate=October 17, 2011}}</ref>
The [[Fulton Street (New York City Subway)|Fulton Street]]/[[Fulton Center]] station complex ({{NYCS trains|Fulton Center}}) is the closest [[New York City Subway]] station.<ref>{{NYCS const|map}}</ref> A new subway station, provisionally called [[Seaport (IND Second Avenue Line)|Seaport]], has been proposed as part of the unfunded Phase 4 of the [[Second Avenue Subway]]. Although this station will be located only 3 blocks from the [[Fulton Street (New York City Subway)|Fulton Street]] station, there are no plans for a free transfer between them.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://web.mta.info/capital/sas_alt.html |title=MTA Capital Construction – Second Avenue Subway: Project Description |publisher=[[Metropolitan Transportation Authority]] |accessdate=April 30, 2010}}</ref>
==In popular culture== '''Film:''' *The seaport is a crucial location in the film ''[[I Am Legend (film)|I Am Legend]]'' (2007), in which [[Will Smith]]'s character broadcasts that he will be there each day at noon, to meet any fellow survivors of a virus outbreak.<ref>[[Bob Mondello|Mondello, Bob]]. [https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=17260869 "''I Am Legend'' a One-Man American Metaphor"], [[NPR]], December 14, 2017. "There's not a person in sight anywhere — except Robert Neville, who travels, when the sun is highest in the sky, to the South Street Seaport, to broadcast the same message he's been broadcasting for almost three years: 'If anyone is out there, I can provide food, shelter, security. If there's anybody out there ... you are not alone.'"</ref> *The seaport was also used as a location in the 2011 film ''[[The Adjustment Bureau]]'' and is seen in the final shot of the 2002 film ''[[Gangs of New York]]''.
'''Games:''' * In the video game ''[[Crysis 2]]'' (2011), Pier 17 was featured as a multi-player map.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mycrysis.com/news/crysis_2/crysis-2-map-focus--pier-17 |title=Pier 17 – Crysis 2 Map Focus |publisher=[[EA]] |accessdate=March 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110214071559/http://www.mycrysis.com/news/crysis_2/crysis-2-map-focus--pier-17 |archivedate=February 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
'''Music:''' * The original [[Sub Pop Records|Sub Pop]] version of [[Nirvana (band)|Nirvana]]'s "[[In Bloom]]" video was filmed here in 1990. The video features Kurt, Krist, and Chad clowning around inside the South Street Mall as well as on Wall Street. * The venue is home to the [[Seaport Music Festival]] each summer.

'''Talal Abu-Ghazaleh''' ({{lang-ar|طلال أبوغزاله}}) is the [[chairman]] and founder of the international Jordan-based organisation, the [[Talal Abu-Ghazaleh Organization]] (TAG-Org). Dubbed as the godfather of [[Arabs|Arab]] [[accounting]], Abu-Ghazaleh has also been credited for promoting the significance of [[Intellectual Property]] in the [[Arabs|Arab]] [[region]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/power100/profile/1044?clr=2&sort=rank|title=Talal Abu-Ghazaleh|date=April 2009|author=arabianbusiness.com}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}</ref>
== Biography == Born on April 22, 1938 in [[Jaffa]], [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]], Abu-Ghazaleh eventually moved to the [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] village of [[Ghaziyeh]].
Whilst still an [[undergraduate]], he worked as a [[teacher]] and [[translator]]. His first job after graduating was at [[Saba & Co. IP]]. <ref>http://www.tag-publication.com/UploadFiles/Azaidan/Chairman/Book/Blankets_Become_Jackets.pdf</ref>
In 1969, upon hearing a speech on [[intellectual property]] (IP) at a Time-Warner conference in [[San Francisco]], USA, Abu-Ghazaleh decided to launch a career in the fields of [[Intellectual property|Intellectual property rights]] (IPRs) and accounting.
In 1972, two [[business entity|firms]] - Talal Abu-Ghazaleh Company (TAGCO) and Abu-Ghazaleh Intellectual Property (AGIP) - were set up, specializing in the fields of accounting and IP respectively. Since then, Abu-Ghazaleh founded a total of 140 professional service firms specialized in various sector fields such as [[management]], [[Consultant|consulting]], [[legal services]], IT and much more.
Over the years, Abu-Ghazaleh managed to establish close [[partnerships]] with global [[organizations]] such as the [[UN]] and the [[WTO]].
On April 4, 2007, [[UN Secretary General]] [[Ban Ki Moon]] appointed Abu-Ghazaleh, as deputy chairman of the [[UN Global Compact]] during its second meeting held at the [[UN headquarters]] in [[New York City|New York]]. <ref>[http://www.jordan-business.net/magazine/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=57&Itemid=40]</ref>
On October 24, 2007, Abu-Ghazaleh was inducted to the IP Hall of Fame in Chicago, USA, to become the first expert from outside the G8 countries to join the world's most prominent figures in IP.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ameinfo.com/132266.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2007-12-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080218210719/http://www.ameinfo.com/132266.html |archivedate=2008-02-18 |df= }} [http://www.iphalloffame.com]</ref>
On June 17, 2009, UN appoints Abu-Ghazaleh Chair of UN [[Global Alliance for ICT and Development]]. After receiving a letter from the Under-Secretary General of the United Nations Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UNDESA) HE Sha Zukang inviting him to lead the Alliance, composed of representatives from public, private and civil society sectors as well as international organizations.<ref>[http://www.ameinfo.com/200482.html]</ref>
On November 25, 2010, HE Senator Talal Abu-Ghazaleh, chairman and CEO of Talal Abu-Ghazaleh Organization (TAG-Org) was appointed a member of the Upper House according to a Royal Decree by His Majesty King Abdullah II . <ref>[http://www.tagorg.com/news.aspx?id=1532&group_key=news&lang=en ]</ref>

The Entertainer is privately owned and has offices in the UAE, Qatar, Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia, South Africa, Cyprus and the UK.
In early 2012, [[Abraaj Capital]] announced their purchase of 50% of the Entertainer. In March 2012, the Entertainer announced a significant investment from Abraaj Capital’s small to mid cap investment arm – RED Investments.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Entertainer continues its expansion in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/296406.html|accessdate=4 July 2012|newspaper=AMEinfo.com|date=April 9, 2012}}</ref>
In November 2013, the Entertainer launched a smartphone app.<ref>{{cite news|title=Wall Street Journal|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/middleeast/2014/06/09/digital-app-so-far-agrees-with-the-entertainer/}}</ref> In addition to all the offers in the printed books, the App includes access to even more exclusive offers added each month, which includes brunches, new restaurant openings and special promotions. Features include GPS mapping, advanced search capabilities allowing you to filter against certain attributes, social sharing and integration with Trip Advisor and Careem.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dubai Chronicle|url=http://www.dubaichronicle.com/2015/11/11/entertainer-2016-launches-with-exceptional-value-enhanced-app/}}</ref>
In 2015, the average Dubai customer saved over AED 6,000 (US$1,600) with the Entertainer App, which has seen over 2 million buy one get one free mobile offers redeemed in the UAE alone.<ref>{{cite news|title=7 Days|url=http://7days.ae/uae-entertainers-mobile-move-proving-popular|date=13 November 2015}}</ref>
The Entertainer signs up restaurants, leisure attractions, spas, gyms, hotels and more to sign up each year. Each merchant provides three buy one get one free offers to be featured (apart from hotels who can feature just one offer). Merchants must provide these offers with few restrictions so that they can be used 7 days a week (excluding public holidays and approved dates).

{{Infobox company | name = Tori Richard, Ltd. | logo =Tori_Richard_Ltd_logo.png | type = [[Family business|Family Business]] | genre = | foundation = 1956 | founder = Mortimer Feldman, Janice Moody and Mitsue Aka. | location_city = [[Honolulu|Honolulu, Hawaii]] | location_country = [[United states|United States of America]] | location = | locations = | area_served = [[United states|50 American states]], [[Puerto rico|Puerto Rico]], [[Guam]], [[Mexico]], [[Caribbean Sea|the Caribbean]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]] and [[Australia]] | key_people = Joshua Feldman, [[Ceo|CEO]] | industry = [[Fashion]] and [[Leisure]] | products = [[Aloha shirt]]s, [[resort wear]] and [[Fashion accessory|accessories for women and men]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | owner = | num_employees = 140 | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | caption = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.toririchard.com/}} | footnotes = | intl = }}
'''Tori Richard''' is a [[Honolulu]], [[Hawaii]]-based [[company]] which produces men's and women's resort wear. In its nearly 60-year history, the Tori Richard line has gone from exclusively women's [[fashion]]s (featured in ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]], [[Harper's Bazaar|Harper’s Bazaar]], [[Mademoiselle (magazine)|Mademoiselle]], [[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]], [[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]], [[Life (magazine)|Life]]'' and other national publications)<ref name="Fujii2006a">{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 22–23 }}</ref> to a line of upscale [[Resort wear|resort apparel]], including sport shirts, [[Aloha shirt]]s, tropical dresses, [[swimwear]], separates, [[handbag]]s, interior accents and a range of fashion and lifestyle accessories.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = }}</ref> Tori Richard resort wear targets those who enjoy art, [[travel]] and a casually upscale lifestyle.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 109 }}</ref> The collections are introduced biannually in showrooms on the east and west coasts.
Founder Mort Feldman, an avid collector of Japanese [[antiques]] and screens, translated his passion into the [[East–West dichotomy|East-West]] fabric prints that remain the Tori Richard signature.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 18 }}</ref> Textile print as an art form still defines the brand, as do fabrication, construction and attention to detail.
[[CEO]] Josh Feldman, Mort Feldman's son, leads the locally owned [[family business]] as it approaches its 60th year.<ref name="themohs">{{Cite web | last = Meyers | first = Aviva | title = Tori Richard | url = http://www.themohs.org/Tori_Richard.html | publisher = | year = 2009 | accessdate = 5 February 2013 }}</ref> In two generations, the company has gone from designing primarily women's wear to becoming an international brand. Through its 10 retail stores, website and 2,500 wholesale accounts, Tori Richard is sold in all [[United states|50 states]], [[Mexico]], [[Puerto rico|Puerto Rico]], [[Guam]], [[Europe]], [[Asia]], [[Australia]] and [[Caribbean Sea|the Caribbean]].<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser">{{Cite web | last = Rath | first = Paula | title = Flashback | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Apr/26/il/FP604260302.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 26 April 2006 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> The newest Tori Richard concept stores, primarily women's stores, are in Honolulu's Kahala Hotel & Resort and Mashpee Cape Cod, Massachusetts. More than 80 percent of Tori Richard sales are [[Continental United States#Hawaii|U.S. mainland-driven]].<ref name="hawaiibusiness">{{Cite web | last = Ro | first = Lisa | title = Patterns of Success | url = http://www.hawaiibusiness.com/Hawaii-Business/July-2006/Patterns-of-Success/ | publisher = Hawaii Business | date = July 2006 | accessdate = 12 February 2013 }}</ref>
==Prints==
[[File:Tori Richard Store in Waikiki.png|thumb|Tori Richard Store in Waikiki]]As many as 100 hours may be required to conceive, design and colorize the design and make each new design printable.<ref name="Fujii2006">{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 44 }}</ref> Tori Richard gathers concept art year-round from company artists, [[studio]]s, art collections, trade shows, retail outlets and private collections throughout [[Europe]], [[Asia]] and the [[United states|U.S.]]<ref name="Fujii2006" /> An in-house art and design team at the Honolulu [[headquarters]] expands on the concepts to create original Tori Richard resort prints.<ref name="hawaiibusiness" /> They adhere to specific criteria in design, color and placement, aiming for proportion, visual balance, and originality of the final design.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 42 }}</ref> When finalized, each TR print is copyrighted, named, and remains the exclusive property of the company.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 43 }}</ref> About 400 new prints are added annually to the TR archive, now numbering at least 25,000 designs.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 42, 64 }}</ref>
[[File:Tori Richard Truck.png|thumb|Tori Richard Truck]]Vital to each print is the number of color screens required.<ref name="Fujii2006" /> Printing a design on silk may require up to 22 screens, and for [[viscose]], 17. Patterns are repeated every 24 to 30 inches, while in the larger “engineered” prints, a single image can take up an entire 60-inch panel.<ref name="Fujii2006" /> Designs range from tightly patterned images to broad, painterly, artistic motifs in both printed and, in the men's Hawaiian shirts, embroidered images. Various visual elements—palette, proportion, mood, message, soft or hard edges—affect the image selection and final print design.
The motifs range from bold geometric prints to botanical, nature-inspired and lifestyle-inspired images. Past designs of Tori Richard's apparel include images of maps, ocean sports, Kiplingesque animals and abstract designs, as well as crisp paisleys and tapa motifs in various fabrications. Variations of popular designs from past collections are sometimes brought back by popular demand. From the beginning, the Japanese aesthetic—stylized waves, water, cranes, fans, chrysanthemum petals, bamboo, textures and brushstrokes—has been prominent in the line.<ref name="themohs" />
Tori Richard has recently released its vintage-inspired 56 series, with its own signature themes, fabrications and a more tapered cut. Emblematic of 56 is the cotton, treated for the vintage-washed effect aimed towards the younger demographic. The Tori Richard line also includes seasonal themes in high-end fabrics, with embroidered, engineered designs in heavyweight silks.
Tori Richard pioneered the matched [[pocket]]s and fronts, now an industry standard. This feature matches the print so there is no interruption in design at the pocket or front seams.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 54 }}</ref>
==Fabrications and Styles== Tori Richard fabrics include [[silk]]s, silk blends, [[Pima cotton]], cotton blends, [[linen]] and linen blends, [[tencel|Tencel©]], cotton jacquard and spun viscose, as well as a fine proprietary Egyptian cotton called cotton lawn, giving a finish exclusive to Tori Richard.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" /><ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_a">{{Cite web | last = Rath | first = Paula | title = Resort Style | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Aug/07/il/hawaii908070318.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 7 August 2009 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> High-end silks, such as silk jacquard, also appear in single, bold embroidered patterns comprising the more luxurious end of the men's line. Some of the fabrics are made in Japan, unusual among retailers today.
==Details and Workmanship== The details of a Tori Richard shirt include laser-etched [[Mother of pearl|mother-of-pearl]] [[Button (clothing)|button]]s, French [[Seam (sewing)|seams]] (raw edges turned in, sewn and invisible), matched pockets, and [[Collar (clothing)|collars]] with interlining, an extra layer of fabric fused to the inside of the collar to add crispness and prevent droop.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 56 }}</ref>
==Women's Fashion== [[File:The Tori Richard store in the Hilton Hawaiian Village.png|thumb|The exterior of the Tori Richard store in the Hilton Hawaiian Village, Waikiki, Honolulu, Hawaii]]Tori Richard's women's line includes dresses, [[capris]], tops, [[tunic]]s, peplum tanks, beach cover-ups, [[sarong]]-style and asymmetrical skirts, as well as shorts and modernized caftans in black, exotic prints and casual geometrics.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 87 }}</ref> Colors are inspired by the dunes of Marrakech, the deserts of Africa, autumn in the northeast, nature and deep ocean. The women's resort wear goes from day to evening and from beach to dinner, casual to elegant.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 86–87 }}</ref> Styles range from off-shoulder, one-shoulder, strapless and spaghetti-strap dresses to skinny, shirred and dolman-sleeved tops paired with skinny pants in all lengths and contemporary cuts.
Fabrics include cotton, cotton [[crape|crepe]], [[rayon]], [[jersey knit]] blends, cotton-spandex [[Piqué (weaving)|piqué]], and silk and silk blends, selected for drape, comfort and versatility.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Rath | first = Paula | title = Fashion News | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/May/15/il/hawaii905150325.html | date = 15 May 2009| accessdate = 16 February 2013 }}</ref> Prints for the women's line range from tapa-inspired tribal prints, botanical motifs, abstract geometricals and art-inspired motifs for a global resort market.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_a" />
Jessica Burgess, formerly of Lilly Pulitzer and Shoshanna, heads up the women's division.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Hughes | first = Beth | title = Museum celebrates Hawaii fashion master | url = http://www.sfgate.com/style/article/Museum-celebrates-Hawaii-fashion-master-3923229.php | publisher = SFGate | date = 8 October 2012 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref>
==History== While known for its resort wear and Hawaiian shirts, Tori Richard got its beginnings in women's wear.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_b">{{Cite web | last = Nakaso | first = Dan | title = Mortimer Feldman | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Aug/16/ln/hawaii908160318.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 16 August 2009 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> Founder Mort Feldman, an apparel manufacturer from Chicago, flew to the Territory of Hawaii in 1953 on [[Pan American Airways|Pan American's]] [[China Clipper]], intending to retire.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_b" /> He established the company in 1956.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_b" /> With partners Janice Moody, formerly a sportswear designer for Catalina, and Mitsue Aka, Moody's pattern maker, he formed Tori Richard with one sewing machine and practically no capital.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_b" /> They named the company after Victoria (Tori, Moody's daughter) and Richard, Feldman's oldest son.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" />
Their first office, at Pier 7 in Honolulu, was known to have floorboards that became damp from the tide rising in [[Honolulu harbor|Honolulu Harbor]].<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" /> Among its early offices were a [[Quonset hut]] and the historic [[Primo Brewing & Malting Company|Primo Brewery]], damaged by fire in 1973 and rebuilt to remain the company headquarters for 17 more years.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Gordon | first = Mike | title = Mort Feldman of Tori Richard | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2004/Nov/12/ln/ln59p.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 12 November 2004}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 30 }}</ref>
Soon after its 1956 launch, Tori Richard became nationally known for the unfussy [[Silhouettes#Fashion and fitness|silhouettes]], bright colors and dramatic prints of the dresses, culottes, beachwear, caftans and lounge wear of its high-fashion resort women's line, made largely of imported European fabrics at the time.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 23 }}</ref> Offices in key mainland markets—[[New York (state)|New York]], [[California]], [[Florida]], [[Dallas]] and [[Chicago]]—attracted attention from high-end retailers, such as Saks Fifth Avenue, Lord & Taylor, Bergdorf Goodman, Gimbel's, I. Magnin, Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom, Best & Co. and Marshall Field.<ref name="Fujii2006a" />
[[File:The interior of the Tori Richard store in the Hyatt Regency Waikiki.png|thumb|The interior of the Tori Richard store in the Hyatt Regency Waikiki]]In the 1960s and ‘70s, [[Fifth avenue#Shopping|Fifth Avenue]] windows and top national fashion magazines featured Tori Richard in features and ads, many of them photographed on location in Hawaii.<ref name="Fujii2006b">{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 22 }}</ref> As the leisure life was the zeitgeist of the era, the Tori Richard fashions—tunics, harem pants, hostess sets, shifts, caftans, culottes, sarong swimsuits and Capri pants—catered to the cocktail, beach and patio parties that were popular at the time.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 25 }}</ref> The esthetics—streamlined and dramatic—departed from the tropical “aloha wear” for which Hawaii was known.<ref name="Fujii2006b" /> Customers ranged from [[Lucille ball|Lucille Ball]] to the [[List of rulers of Morocco|King of Morocco]] to department store customers across the country.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 20 }}</ref>
In 1966, Mort Feldman and a fellow Hawaii fashion executive, Howard Hope, lobbied the [[Hawaii Legislature|Hawaii State Legislature]] to establish “Aloha Friday” as a state-sanctioned island practice.<ref name="themohs" /> The effort succeeded, and businesses throughout the state wear aloha attire on Fridays, and, increasingly, on the other days of the week.
The company grew during the boom years of Hawaii [[tourism]]. From the early 1960s, soon after [[Hawaii statehood|statehood]] in 1959 and the introduction of jet travel to Hawaii, fashion emerged as the third largest export of the state, with Tori Richard as one of the biggest fashion exporters.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = | first = | title = Hawaii's Glamour Garments | journal = Beacon | volume = | issue = April | year = 1962 | pages = 8 | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 27 }}</ref> At the request of a Hawaii retailer named [[Liberty House (US)|Liberty House]], Tori Richard, using prints from its women's line, introduced its men's shirts in 1969.<ref name="themohs" /> By the mid-1970s, the men's segment of the business was significant, and today the shirts and resort apparel, some of it avidly collected, are carried in all 50 states.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" />
[[File:Joshua Feldman.png|thumb|Joshua Feldman, CEO of Tori Richard and son of founder Mortimer Feldman.]]Cotton lawn, now a staple of the company with its proprietary finish, debuted in the 1970s and became a mainstay of the men's line.<ref name="Fujii2006c">{{Cite book | last1 = Fujii | first1 = Jocelyn K. | title = Tori Richard: The First Fifty Years | year = 2006 | publisher = Tori Richard | location = Honolulu, Hawaii | isbn = 978-0-9785466-0-1 | pages = 63 }}</ref>
In the 1980s, menswear eclipsed women's wear in the Tori Richard line.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" /> In 1983, Mort Feldman retired to New Zealand, to return to the U. S. three years later. His son, Josh, a graduate of [[Punahou School]] and the [[UC San Diego|University of California at San Diego]], with a degree in art and a degree in political science, dropped his ambitions for [[law school]] and joined Tori Richard in 1994.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Kam | first = Nadine | title = Tori Five-O: The clothing company Tori Richard recaptures its storied early success | publisher = Honolulu Star-Bulletin | date = 5 October 2006 }}</ref> Under the younger Feldman's leadership, the company grew by over 600 percent.<ref name="Fujii2006c" />
Upon his return in 1994, Josh Feldman managed the print and product division of the company. He re-introduced the engineered print to the product line in 1995 and redoubled efforts to identify Tori Richard as a print house.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser" />
In 2002, the women's line was relaunched, and a year later, the first Tori Richard retail store opened at the [[Hyatt|Hyatt Regency Waikīkī]].<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = One To Watch: Tori Richard's new womenswear designer brings a fresh feel to the iconic island brand | url = http://www.honolulumagazine.com/Honolulu-Shops-Waikiki/June-2012/One-To-Watch/ | publisher = Honolulu Magazine | date = June 2012 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> Today there are Tori Richard shops at [[Ala Moana Center]], The Shops at Wailea, [[Royal Hawaiian Hotel]], [[Hilton Hawaiian Village]] and Whaler's Village in Ka‘anapali.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Tori Richard | first = | title = Find A Store | url = http://www.toririchard.com/page.cfm/LOCATIONS.html | publisher = Tori Richard | date = | accessdate = 8 February 2013 }}</ref> The year 2006 saw the company's 50th anniversary and was also the year Tori Richard received the “Resort Retailer of the Year” award from Retail Merchants Hawaii.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Advertiser Staff | first = | title = Jeans Warehouse wins Retailer of Year | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2006/Oct/28/bz/FP610280329.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 28 October 2006 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> In 2012, the readers of the ''[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]]'' voted Tori Richard “Best of the Best” in the aloha shirt category.<ref>{{Cite web | last = | first = | title = Hawaii's Best 2012 | url = http://www.staradvertiser.com/specialprojects/2012/hawaiisbest2012/hawaiisbest2012.html?id=171852751 | publisher = Honolulu Star-Advertiser | date = 24 June 2012 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref>
==Appearances== The company recently received film credit for creating [[George clooney|George Clooney's]] shirts in “[[The Descendants]],” the [[84th Academy Awards|2012 Academy Award]] winner for “Best Adapted Screenplay.”<ref>{{Cite web | last = Zimmerman | first = Malia | title = The Obama Snub That Has Everyone Talking | url = http://www.hawaiireporter.com/celebrities-alex-oloughlin-and-george-clooney-wear-tori-richard-alohawear-but-president-obama-snubs-the-companys-shirt-made-exclusively-for-21-world-leaders-at-apec/123 | publisher = Hawaii Reporter | date = 14 November 2011 | accessdate = 7 February 2013 }}</ref> Working with costume designer Wendy Chuck, CEO Josh Feldman and his team provided George Clooney's shirts for many of the movie scenes.
Tori Richard also provides shirts for [[Alex O'Loughlin|Alex O’Loughlin]] (Steve McGarrett) and [[Daniel Dae Kim]] (Chin Ho Kelly) in “[[Hawaii Five-0 (2010 TV series)|Hawaii Five-0]],” as it did for [[Jack Lord|Jack Lord's]] Steve McGarrett in the original television series from 1968 to 1980.<ref>{{Cite web | last = Magin | first = Janis L. | title = Island businesses ride 'Hawaii Five-0's' promotional wave | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/2012/03/island-businesses-ride-hawaii.html | publisher = Pacific Business News | date = 20 March 2012 | accessdate = 7 February 2013 }}</ref>
Musicians, such as [[Sammy Hagar]] and, [[Jimmy Buffett]], have worn Tori Richard shirts in their performances, and some artists have worn them on their [[album cover]]s.
Tori Richard designed the signature shirts for the more than 2,000 volunteers and staff of the [[Apec|Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC)]], spearheaded by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] in Honolulu in November 2011.<ref name="bizjournals">{{Cite web | last = Magin | first = Janis L. | title = Tori Richard CEO: APEC shirts were 'expensive gamble' | url = http://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/blog/2011/11/tori-richard-ceo-apec-shirts-were.html?page=all | publisher = Pacific Business News | date = 14 November 2011 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> Tori Richard also designed and created an exclusive [[aloha shirt]] for Obama and the 21 world leaders in attendance, an effort that required an original design, special limited print run, custom labeling and hand-sewing in Hawaii.<ref name="bizjournals" /> The shirt was given to the delegation but was never worn at the official gathering.<ref name="bizjournals" />
==Company Environmental Conservation Efforts== In 2008, the company installed a $1.1-million, 154-[[Kilowatt#Kilowatt|kilowatt]] system at its corporate headquarters and warehouses in Honolulu, becoming one of the world's first [[Photovoltaic system|solar-powered]] manufacturers and retailers.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_c">{{Cite web | last = Advertiser Staff and News Services | first = | title = Tori Richard goes photovoltaic | url = http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2008/Oct/29/bz/hawaii810290395.html | publisher = Honolulu Advertiser | date = 29 October 2008 | accessdate = 6 February 2013 }}</ref> The system meets 94 percent of the company's electricity needs in its Honolulu headquarters.<ref name="the.honoluluadvertiser_c" /> In 2011, the company installed an additional 105 KWH system on an adjacent property, effectively offsetting 100% of its [[carbon footprint]].
